PHR: Our awareness about the deleterious effects of intersectional stigma on entry into the HIV prevention continuum are at odds with the availability of viable solutions. Standardized patients (SP) provide a way to objectively measure intersectional stigma enacted in healthcare settings, and in so doing unlock novel strategies for intervening on its underlying causes. This research will evaluate a stigma intervention informed by SP observations to reduce barriers experienced by gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men, as well as people living with HIV in countries of low- and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The objective of the proposed NIH SBIR Phase I research and development (R&D) effort is to address the public health endemic of police murders against black males by improving police training with an innovative artificial intelligent (AI) enabled Juxtopia® CAMMRAD Police De-Escalate Virtual Reality e-training simulation. Specifically, the Juxtopia® AI police educator, “BES” (i.e., Ancient Egyptian God of Domestic Protection) will autonomously e-train and e-evaluate police trainees on culturally competent, ethical, and empathetic de-escalation skills using non-lethal force within a multi-user and interactive VR simulation; built upon the Juxtopia® Context-Aware Mobile Mixed Reality Assistive Device (CAMMRAD) VR software platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Radiation accidents at nuclear power plants or after the detonation of a nuclear weapon or radioactive bomb can result in delayed injury to the gastrointestinal tract, including tissue fibrosis. The overall goal of this project is to define novel mechanisms by which Type I interferon signaling impacts radiation-induced intestinal fibrosis in female vs. male mouse models and to build upon this knowledge to develop novel countermeasures against delayed tissue fibrosis from acute radiation exposure.

PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness in the world and disproportionately impacts minorities, specifically Asian and Black African Americans. 231 Sheep is developing Ocuelar, a holistic solution consisting of a Smart EyeCup device, phone application, and database that aims to improve patient compliance with eye drops for the treatment of glaucoma. By preventing unnecessary vision loss, Ocuelar will disproportionately benefit Chinese and Korean Americans, thus creating more equitable health outcomes. 2

PHR: Projection Narrative Dysregulated neuronal maturation leads to neurological disease such as childhood blindness and autism. The results will reveal novel epigenetic mechanisms to enrich our understanding of relevant neuronal diseases.

PHR: One in four Veterans has diabetes. Foot ulcers are a common and feared complication for people with diabetes because they reduce mobility and independence. People who recently healed a diabetic foot ulcer are considered “in remission” as opposed to “cured” because the underlying medical conditions which led to their ulcer are still present. Once in remission, the current practice is to slowly increase walking with appropriate shoes. The problem is that people “in remission” rarely return to a recommended level of walking. The ability to stay active is critical as people grow older. There are few studies on exercise during “remission”. This study will test whether a home-based exercise regimen can safely increase activity. Like a person who has recently recovered from a heart attack, this is a critical time to intervene to improve activity and safely restore function to improve long term health outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the importance of improving naloxone access among laypersons, we have surprisingly limited information about the share of people who carry naloxone, where and how those who carry naloxone obtained the medication, barriers and perceived barriers to purchasing or otherwise obtaining naloxone, optimal price points, and so on. We will field two national surveys to gather this information with particular emphasis on tracking the impacts of the new over-the-counter naloxone products to provide time-sensitive evidence. We will focus specifically on new barriers to access as these products become more widely available and on understanding the possible role of prices in hindering additional naloxone use.

PHR: This proposal addresses a significant healthcare issue that affects Veterans, military personnel, and their families disproportionately. In this regard, the incidence of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is increasing in Veterans at disproportionate rates than the general population. Dr. Singh’s research program is focused on the investigation of mechanism/s of IBD to discover novel biomarkers and/or therapeutic targets to curb disease severity in IBD patients, and its progression to colon cancer. Both, IBD and colon cancer represent major clinical challenges in the VA health care system, since effective therapeutic interventions are lacking. Similar to IBD, incidence of PTSD is increasing in Veterans at disproportionate rates. Applicant’s lab aims to provide a better understanding of mechanism/s of increasing risk for PTSD and its causal role in promoting IBD to increase opportunities for the development of novel biomarkers and treatment paradigms.

PHR: Project Narrative Rural young men who have sex with men (YMSM) have a significant burden of HIV, representing 20% of new HIV cases in nonmetropolitan areas of the United States in 2020. Implementation science will be used to understand how recently approved long-acting injectable pre-exposure prophylaxis (LAI PrEP) can be incorporated into the HIV prevention toolkit for rural YMSM. Using a convergent mixed methods design, we will determine salient patient-level implementation determinants and identify implementation strategies for LAI PrEP among rural YMSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In 2020 an estimated 1.5 million people acquired HIV, highlighting the urgent need for a prophylactic vaccine to combat the ongoing health crisis. This project will investigate how genetic variation at the immunoglobulin gene loci impacts the ability of rhesus macaques, the gold standard preclinical model for studying HIV, to develop high levels of neutralizing antibody titers against particular epitopes of HIV envelope immunogens. Such studies are essential to understand how humoral vaccine responses vary between individuals, to inform the design of HIV vaccine constructs, and to gain a deeper understanding of antibody responses to HIV proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The interplay between anti-phage defense systems in bacteria and counter-defense strategies in phages can determine phage infection outcomes, which in turn have widespread impacts on the evolution and treatment of infectious disease. Most defense and counter-defense systems in nature have not been identified, so we will apply a novel functional selection scheme to identify these systems from various metagenomes and libraries of synthesized phage genes. We will then use genetic and functional techniques to characterize these systems mechanistically and reveal fundamental insights into the molecular arms race between bacteria and phage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: With an estimated 1.5 million people newly infected with HIV in 2021 alone, HIV remains a critical global health threat and prevention of acquisition through vaccine development remains a priority. This project aims to characterize the role of monocytes in the development of HIV vaccine response using a systems biology approach, for use in future vaccine development. The training plan will provide me with the knowledge and experience to transition to an independently funded physician scientist working in systems biology and HIV vaccine development.

PHR: Public Relevance Statement The proposed study pilot tests the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of an adapted intervention (ESTEEM) for Arab immigrant sexual minority men in the US to be delivered in an online and group format. Through consultations with mental health experts and Arab immigrant sexual minority men, we will revise the original ESTEEM intervention protocol to address intersectional stigma and minority stress reactions in order to reduce co-occurring HIV risks and poor mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The obligate intracellular bacterial pathogen Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of human Q fever. We propose to elucidate the molecular mechanisms behind Coxiella’s ability to survive in the acidic intracellular niche, the Coxiella Containing Vacuole (CCV). Understanding how C. burnetii initiates replication under acid stress and actively regulates CCV pH to maintain viability is critical to identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The downstream behavioral impacts of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions remain unknown in the US and globally, so they are not yet included in the US federal “social cost of carbon,” a metric used to quantify the human damages associated with a one-ton increase in greenhouse gas emissions. This proposed project evaluates the hypothesized behavioral costs of carbon for substance use, sleep outcomes, and physical activity. Characterizing how observed changes in climate, caused by each additional unit of greenhouse gas emissions today, impact future human health behaviors can have major implications for climate and health policies, which currently do not consider the behavioral costs of societies' emissions choices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative. Low-grade gliomas are tumors originating in the young adult brain and patients experience many years of survivorship without active disease. Most patients experience impaired cognition which limits social, vocational, and emotional health. These studies will offer deeper and new therapeutic insight into understanding how gliomas disrupt information processed in the brain and suggest new approaches to their treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite years of effective suppressive antiretroviral therapy (ART), latent HIV-infected cells can persist in people with HIV (PWH) and reintroduce disseminated HIV infection after cessation of ART, preventing the functional cure of HIV-infected individuals. The anti-HIV-1 immune response in most patients is inadequate to effectively eliminate reactivated cells, necessitating the development of strategies to boost the anti-HIV immune response to enable it to clear the reservoir after reactivation. We postulate that by redirecting CD8 T cells that are highly effective in controlling chronic latent CMV infection to target and kill HIV-infected cells, we can boost the HIV- specific immune response in PWH to prevent recurrent viremia after the cessation of ART and contribute to providing a functional cure of HIV infection.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunoglobulin heavy chain germline gene IGHV6-1 encodes a multi-donor class of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) to the highly conserved stem region of hemagglutinin (HA). This proposed study aims to characterize the sequence features and affinity maturation pathways of IGHV6-1 HA stem bnAbs. The results will provide important mechanistic insight into the development of universal influenza vaccines.

PHR: Service members and veterans are disproportionally affected by acute knee injuries that can lead to career- ending and life-altering post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA). Absent early intervention or the targeting of only a single aspect of the diverse pathologic cascade in PTOA has proven insufficient for joint-level chondroprotection and attenuation of disease progression. In this proposal, we will develop an intra- articular therapeutic that combines mechanically activated microcapsules (MAMCs) within a hydrogel carrier to control the spatial and temporal release of bioactive factors following an acute knee injury. Successful completion of this study will advance our understanding of the veteran PTOA phenotype using clinical data, create a field-leading large animal model of PTOA, and validate an injectable therapy for future translational evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Influenza virus can damage the heart, though this is a poorly understood aspect of influenza pathogenesis. We are investigating how and why specific virus strains traffic to the heart from the lung, how these viruses damage the heart, and how the immune system provides both beneficial and nonbeneficial effects during infection. This work will identify new strategies to prevent or treat influenza-associated cardiac dysfunction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic viral infections affect millions of people worldwide and post a major public health challenge. This proposal aims to identify the molecular and cellular mechanisms required for long-term antiviral CD8 T-cell immunity and efficacy of immunotherapy against chronic viral infection. The results from this study will unveil novel targets that can be harnessed to induce durable control of chronic viral infection in patients.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Stroke affects nearly a million Americans every year and thousands of Veterans. Unfortunately, many individuals do not fully recover from stroke, leaving them with numerous deficits that affect their daily lives. These deficits can include changes in visuospatial and cognitive functioning, which are critical for daily activities such as driving. Many stroke patients, however, return to driving without ever receiving a thorough assessment of visuospatial abilities and/or a formal driving evaluation. In the current study, we are proposing to relate cognitive functioning and stroke lesion sites to specific driving skills using a driving simulator. Our main goals are to identify cognitive deficits (behavioral markers) and brain regions (biological markers) that are consistently related to different aspects of driving. We will also investigate the usefulness of driver hazard warnings in driving after stroke. Findings from this project will help identify the most important aspects of cognition and driving to target in future efforts to rehabilitate brain injured individuals who wish to return to driving.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Innate immune signaling pathways including the RIG-I-like receptor (RLR), cGAS-STING and NLRP3 inflammasome pathways play crucial roles in the host response to pathogenic microbes. These pathways are potent inducers of inflammation when triggered and must be tightly regulated to avoid overexuberant inflammation and tissue damage. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms by which the selective autophagy receptor TAX1BP1 regulates innate immune signaling and immune homeostasis.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to understand a significant public health concern, specifically prematurity and its disproportional impacts on Black and lower income families, and the role social determinates of health, namely work, may play in maintaining or disrupting the downstream consequences of prematurity through the infant’s first year of life. One aim is to determine how work factors (including paid leave, work hours, and schedule flexibility) are related to parents’ involvement in the NICU and their mental health; the second aim is to establish how these factors are related to infants’ short (NICU discharge) and longer-term (12 month) neurodevelopmental outcomes in a diverse sample of 250 NICU families. Findings from this study will hopefully elucidate understudied work-family barriers to parental involvement for diverse families in the NICU and identify family and state/federal policy-level intervention targets to support parent NICU engagement and mitigate the long-term neurodevelopmental consequences of prematurity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative We discovered that the host has evolved physiological defenses that promote the asymptomatic carriage of pathogens through a phenomenon we call “metabolic bribery”. This involves physiological responses in the host that operate to provide metabolic substrates to the pathogen, taming their virulence and preventing their ability to cause disease. We plan to decipher the host metabolic adaptations that occur in asymptomatic carriers that facilitate metabolic bribery, the interplay between the adaptive immune system and the cooperative defenses to promote cooperation between the host and a pathogen, and develop a mechanistic understanding for how cooperative defenses promote the evolution of attenuation of a pathogen and commensalism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The immune system is adept at clearing bacterial infection, however, certain bacteria can pose a difficult challenge that stimulates the immune response to form a structure called a granuloma. This structure is seen in important infections such as tuberculosis, however, granuloma functions have been difficult to study due to a lack of model systems. We have discovered a new granuloma model that allows us to study basic granuloma biology in laboratory mice.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: One in every four Veteran receiving care from the VA is being treated for diabetes, while more than half suffer from diabetic retinopathy. Yet, there is no treatment for non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy; and treatments for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is futile to ~30% of diabetics receiving care. Thus, there is a great need for new therapeutics for this ocular disease. Recently, we discovered a metabolic enzyme (STEAP4) upregulated in the blood of diabetics, which correlates to the severity of diabetic retinopathy. In this study, we will examine the physiological impact of STEAP4 in the onset and progression of diabetic retinopathy. While further identifying a potentially novel therapeutic target for diabetic retinopathy.

PHR: Project Narrative The intracellular bacterial pathogen Legionella pneumophila is an important cause of hospital- and community- acquired pneumonia. We propose to define novel mechanisms underlying how the innate immune system successfully overcomes the ability of Legionella to disarm alveolar macrophage function. Defining these mechanisms will enable the design of new anti-bacterial therapeutics that are effective against Legionella and other intracellular bacterial pathogens.

PHR: Project Narrative Hepatic steatosis drives risk for liver disease (steatohepatitis and cirrhosis), type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular risk. Hepatic steatosis diagnosis rates have increased by 17-fold from 2000 to 2017 in Veterans. Women represent 9% of the Veteran population but will increase to ~15% by 2040. Pre-menopausal women are protected against steatosis but have a much higher risk than men after menopause. Hepatic steatosis is and will continue to be a significant healthcare burden for female VA patients as they enter menopause. Using molecular approaches and mouse models, this proposal will examine mechanistic interactions between liver estrogen signaling, exercise, and mitochondrial quality control mechanisms after the loss of ovarian function due to ovariectomies. The underlying goal is to investigate therapeutic targets and provide mechanistic information for the role of estrogen hormone replacement therapy and exercise in modulating liver metabolism.

PHR: OVERALL PROJECT SUMMARY In this Program Project renewal, we bring together investigators with very different expertise and approaches from structural biology, proteomics, immunology, biophysics and computational biology to understand T cell antigen receptor (TCR) signaling. We will study the distinct features of the T cell-expressed tyrosine kinase enzymes that make these most suitable for TCR signaling, how the biochemical features and assembly of particular molecules are used to amplify signals, how distinct signaling pathways coordinate different cellular responses and how signaling circuitry generated enables the T cell to discriminate and respond to signals generated from self-antigens versus pathogen or tumor antigens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Sex can be a compounding factor in affecting the outcome of a variety of diseases. To date, the mechanisms of sexual differences in radiation sickness have not been fully investigated. In this project, we will gain key insights into sex differences between males and females from the contribution of gonadal hormones and sex chromosomes following exposure to ionizing radiation. Such findings will be invaluable in the case of a nuclear catastrophe, where an exposed population will need to be triaged based on their risk for radiation syndrome severity. This study will also evaluate gonadal sex hormones and IL-33 as potentiators of radiation-induced disease, allowing for the potential identification of novel targets of therapeutic strategy for individuals suffering from radiation-induced disease in the short and long term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes the common STI gonorrhea, for which there are dwindling treatment options and no protective vaccine. N. gonorrhoeae has the striking ability to co-opt human metal-binding proteins, normally meant to restrict bacterial growth, as a source of essential metals. This project seeks to understand the structure and function relationships in four outer membrane transporters produced by N. gonorrhoeae during infection of relevant host cells, to determine the metal environment sensed by N. gonorrhoeae during infection of these cells, and to explore whether inhibitory compounds or monoclonal antibodies block these critical metal acquisition functions, which can point to new therapies against this common infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Increasing antibiotic resistance is a major problem that threatens to end the clinical usefulness of many antibiotics and fundamentally alter our ability to treat bacterial infections. This proposal will extend our studies of enzymes that chemically modify specific RNA molecules to alter antibiotic activity and will also establish a new paradigm for understanding how these modifications impact antibiotic-target interactions. Detailed understanding of mechanisms of resistance and antibiotic-target interactions are necessary prerequisites for the development of new strategies to extend the clinical life of current antibiotics or to create novel designer drugs to combat resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical and mental health can suffer due to insufficient sleep, but even getting enough sleep can be problematic when sleep is qualitatively suboptimal. Suboptimal sleep contributes in the general case to problems that include drowsiness, lethargy, muscle aches, inattention, and poor memory, and in various disease states to problems that include cardiovascular issues, anxiety, depression, and other stress-related dysfunctions. To improve health for a wide variety of patients, including but not limited to patients with obstructive sleep apnea, this project will usher in a new orientation to improving sleep with innovative methods for altering sleep physiology in the home based on easy-to-use wearable technology that changes what happens in the brain during sleep.

PHR: Project Narrative Coxsackievirus is a major human pathogen that initiates infection in the mammalian gastrointestinal tract, home to a community of resident bacteria. These bacteria can enhance Coxsackievirus replication and pathogenesis; however, the mechanism remains unclear. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the mechanism of bacterial-mediated enhancement of Coxsackievirus infectivity and stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-1 initiates infection by fusing with cell membranes through a process mediated by the viral envelope glycoprotein. Several host factors incorporate into virions and inhibit their fusion with new target cells through a poorly understood mechanism. We will use a panel of cutting-edge imaging techniques to delineate the mechanism by which these host proteins disfavor HIV-1 fusion and to inform new antiviral strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Several human illnesses such as chronic viral infection, cancer, autoimmunity, and neurodegenerative diseases are due to aberrant activation of innate immune responses and are associated with production of proinflammatory cytokines. We have identified a novel repressor complex composed of Capicua-Ataxin1 or 1L, which prevents aberrant expression of antiviral genes in the absence of virus infection; and, upon viral infection, this complex is rapidly degraded to turn on antiviral responses. Our proposed study will investigate the Capicua-Ataxin1 mediated regulation of innate immune responses in human cells and knock out mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic treatment for tuberculosis (TB) is long and arduous and new therapies are urgently needed, especially for drug-resistant TB and HIV-coinfected persons. Host-directed therapies (HDT) that work in conjunction with antibiotic treatment are attractive for improving immunity to TB and anti-TB treatment. We aim to use novel multivalent synthetic nanoparticle antibodies (SNAbs) to specifically target immune cells that suppress immunity and explore their potential as targets for HDT for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (MSM) in the United States shoulder a disproportionate burden of HIV, trauma exposure (especially interpersonal violence that is often motived by prejudice), and associated PTSD and substance use, which may negatively impact uptake of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), an effective HIV-preventive biomedical intervention. Latent class mediation analysis can identify the extent to which distinct and unique patterns of PTSD symptomology and substance use mediate the effect of prejudice-motivated violence on PrEP uptake in this population, and in conjunction with qualitative findings from local violence-exposed MSM and key community stakeholders can inform a novel trauma-informed mHealth + peer support intervention to support PrEP uptake, contributing to a reduction in HIV transmission and related disparities. Through this K01, Dr. Wiginton will leverage the UCSD training infrastructure to build his professional research independence for improving PrEP uptake among marginalized populations through innovative trauma-informed approaches, positioning him as a leader in the next generation of queer scholars to contribute toward ending the HIV epidemic among racially/ethnically diverse MSM in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is caused by parasites of the genus Plasmodium and over one billion people are at risk of infection every year. Unfortunately, the rapid development of resistance to all current antimalarials highlights the urgent need to develop new drugs with different mode of actions to overcome this pressing problem. This work aims to optimize two novel, inexpensive and effective classes of antimalarials that target multiple life stages of the parasite. In addition, the proposed studies to uncover how these antimalarials work will reveal valuable information to define unknown cellular (on and off) targets in malaria parasite that in turn will aid the development of safer treatments to circumvent drug resistant malaria in the campaign for disease eradication.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In South Africa, migrant men are at elevated risk of acquiring HIV, and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is effective at preventing HIV, but migrant men face barriers to using PrEP, including lack of knowledge and counseling, the opportunity costs of seeking care, and unfamiliarity with health services in a new setting. Pilot data show that migrant men are interested in using PrEP should they be given information and counseling, and if other barriers are addressed, including lost work opportunities as well as the inconveniences and perceived stigma at clinics. This study will 1) elicit preferences for PrEP counseling and service delivery among migrant men through qualitative interviews and a DCE; 2) design a “Healthy Welcome” intervention for migrant men to promote linkage to community pharmacies for PrEP uptake and adherence; and 3) evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, appropriateness, and fidelity of the intervention through a pilot RCT.

PHR: Uromodulin-associated chronic kidney disease (CKD), a significantly underestimated disease in Veterans, causes renal fibrosis and progressive renal failure. There is no mechanism-based treatment. The goal of this project is to develop novel therapeutics, which can restore mitochondrial homeostasis and mitigate mitochondrial damage-mediated inflammation, to treat uromodulin-associated CKD or other forms of CKD induced by organelle stress in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will characterize sex specific differences in intestinal epithelial radiosensitivity. This proposal will also examine the metabolic function as determinant of observed sex specific differences in intestinal radiosensitivity. Small molecule based modulator of this metabolic function will be tested as radiation countermeasure against radiation induced acute gastrointestinal syndrome. Successful completion of this project will lead to the development of this small molecule-based therapy as a new medical countermeasure to treat injuries resulting from a radiation or nuclear accident.

ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Platelets are the smallest cells in the blood and important in inflammation and the formation of blood clots. Recent findings suggest that platelets are important in a variety of human conditions independent of their role in clotting. One of these conditions is traumatic brain injury (TBI), a disorder affecting many Veterans which can result in symptoms that persist throughout the lifetime of an individual, severely affecting quality of life. The role of platelets in the long-term consequences of TBI is not well understood. The overall goal of this project is to broaden our understanding of interactions between platelets and blood vessels in TBI and define the contribution of platelets to the long-term repercussions of TBI. This Career Development Application seeks to provide the foundation for the applicant's transition to an independent VA investigator studying TBI with the long-term goal of identifying new treatment options for Veterans suffering from TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One goal for HIV cure researchers is to design an intervention allowing people living with HIV to discontinue their antiretroviral treatment (ART) and experience viral remission. We identified a monkey model for the related simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) where animals can maintain virus at undetectable levels after stopping ART. In this project, we will define the immunological mechanisms that govern this monkey SIV model of post-ART viral control so that potential targets for therapeutic clinical interventions can be identified and evaluated in humans in the future.

ORG_NAME: SURGICAL INFECTION SOCIETY FOUNDATION FOR EDUCATION AND RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Intra-abdominal infections continue to be associated with a complication rate of more than 20%, even for relatively simple cases, and a mortality rate exceeding 5% in many populations. These outcomes have changed little in the past 30 years. The current proposal is intended to design and apply for funding for a trial using C- reactive protein as a biomarker to individualize antimicrobial therapy for intra-abdominal infections, resulting in more precise therapy and improved outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Low cardiorespiratory fitness and chronotropic incompetence, the inability to increase heart rate adequately during exercise, may be underrecognized and treatable contributors to cardiovascular disease, especially among people with HIV. This project will describe patterns of low CRF, especially chronotropic incompetence, and risk factors for low CRF and CI among people with HIV, characterize longitudinal effects of CI on CRF, identify associations with subclinical cardiovascular disease, and conduct a pilot study of an exercise intervention for chronotropic incompetence among people with HIV. With these foundational studies, a greater understanding of the role cardiorespiratory fitness and chronotropic incompetence in cardiovascular disease may lead to insights on reducing the growing burden of cardiovascular disease among people with HIV.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) are a major public health concern, impacting over half of the US population, and are associated with negative coping responses such as alcohol, cannabis, and other substance misuse. However, positive coping responses can be taught, disrupting negative health trajectories associated with poor mental and physical health. Garnering Resilience in Traumatized youth and families (GRIT) is a program focused on teaching self-regulation skills to adversity impacted youth and their caregivers; the program’s impact on ACE-related responses such as the early initiation of alcohol and cannabis use and other health indicators will be evaluated.

PHR: Project Narrative Hispanics/Latinos are projected to experience the largest increase in dementia prevalence of any ethnic group, with an 832% growth from 379,000 in 2012 to 3.5 million by 2060. Federal, state, local, and tribal public health partnerships have called for a pressing need to allocate resources toward reducing health disparities among minority populations most likely to be affected by dementia, including Hispanics/Latinos. To address the need for health equity in dementia care for the U.S. Hispanic/Latino population, Ceresti Health will develop an approach for deploying its proven Caregiver-Enabled Care Program (CECP) to Spanish-speaking caregivers of patients with dementia.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA-protein interactions are essential to fundamental biological processes in humans and pathogens, and as such represent important drug targets. Structural details of these interactions are easily obtained; however, we do not yet have a predictive understanding of their biological functions. This proposal aims to investigate the structural dynamics of an RNA-protein interaction in human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV-1) in order to build a first of its kind quantitative model of its cellular function, as well as target it for antiviral drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to evaluate the efficacy of Mlambe: an economic and relationship-strengthening intervention for HIV-affected couples with a heavy alcohol drinker to reduce heavy alcohol use and improve HIV treatment outcomes. We will conduct a randomized clinical trial with heterosexual couples in Malawi to evaluate the health impacts of Mlambe on heavy alcohol use, viral suppression, and adherence to antiretroviral therapy, and the relationship impacts of Mlambe on partner support, couple communication, and relationship quality. We will also evaluate the costs of the intervention to assess future scalability.

PHR: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is the first-line treatment for chronic insomnia. However, cognitive impairments may limit progress in CBT-I for older Veterans with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). This study will develop and pilot test Sleep-SMART (Sleep Symptom Management and Rehabilitation Therapy), an adapted CBT-I treatment that incorporates Cognitive Symptom Management and Rehabilitation Therapy (CogSMART) principles with a goal of improving sleep treatment and rehabilitation outcomes for Veterans with co-occurring MCI and insomnia. The innovation of this study centers on enhancing CBT-I by providing supportive cognitive strategies designed to improve treatment adherence, learning, and acceptability. We anticipate that by improving sleep we can concurrently improve daily functioning, increase quality of life, prevent or reduce late-life disability, and mitigate long-term cognitive decline in this Veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ulcerative colitis (UC), a subtype of inflammatory bowel disease, is a chronic form of intestinal inflammation within the colon and rectum of the gastrointestinal tract where those affected exhibit local and systemic inflammation, gut dysbiosis, and extraintestinal manifestations such as changes (pathophysiological, electrophysiological) in cardiac function. During flare-ups UC patients exhibit twice the risk for developing atrial fibrillation (AF), the most common sustained arrhythmia worldwide caused by increased electrophysiological and structural heterogeneity. This project will examine the mechanism behind the increased risk for AF during UC disease progression.

PHR: Approximately half a million Veterans receiving services at the VA have Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). PTSD is strongly associated with cognitive functioning deficits in areas of concentration, attention, memory, learning, verbal abilities, processing speed, and multitasking. The proposed research will determine the extent to which cognitive functioning deficits remain even after evidence-based PTSD treatment. Compensatory Cognitive Training (CCT) is an evidence-based intervention for cognitive problems that is effective in other Veteran populations such as those with a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI), but CCT has not yet been tested in Veterans with PTSD who don’t have a history of TBI. We will conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) of CCT in Veterans who have been treated for PTSD but continue to have cognitive functioning deficits. We will examine feasibility, acceptability, participant characteristics, and effect size estimates in preparation for a fully-powered RCT of CCT for PTSD-related cognitive functioning deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In its most severe form, food allergy can trigger life-threatening anaphylaxis. We recently discovered that susceptibility to oral anaphylaxis is driven by intestinal permeability to food allergens and that this permeability is genetically regulated and potentially treatable by drugs. We aim to discover the specific mechanisms controlling gut permeability in order to (1) identify new drugs to prevent anaphylaxis upon ingestion of allergens and (2) discover diagnostic markers that can identify individuals most at risk of anaphylaxis to food.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Understanding how normal processes in the cell operate incorrectly at the molecular level during disease initiation and progression is vital to develop strategies to control disease. Interdisciplinary research that integrates methodologies across traditional fields is needed to advance the definition of molecular processes. The proposed predoctoral program in Molecular Mechanisms of Disease at the University of Nebraska- Lincoln will use collaborative research projects, student-centered teaching, and diverse career development opportunities to develop a workforce of team-oriented scientists with critical expertise in the interdisciplinary study of disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Our lab studies how human cells help one of their most abundant proteins achieve its correct three-dimensional shape; this protein enables production of all other proteins and is blocked by a drug with pre-clinical efficacy against SARS-CoV-2. We also study how human cells adapt to stress by remodeling their intracellular membrane compartments by a quality control process that staves-off neuronal degeneration with age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Fluid flows over the external surface of cells serve as sources of information during cell-cell communication events, but how cells sense and respond to flow-derived signals is not understood. We propose to use the tractable zebrafish left-right patterning system to determine fundamental mechanisms by which cells generate, sense and interpret fluid flows using advanced genetic and imaging approaches. Since abnormal flows occur in a range of diseases, our work promises new opportunities for improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Our work is aimed at gaining a better understanding of molecular events that drive diabetic neuropathic pain and then using this knowledge to identify new molecular targets for diabetic neuropathic pain treatment. We have found a key stress signaling pathway surrounding mRNA translation that regulates nociceptor excitability that occur in diabetic neuropathy. The combined use of pharmacology, genetics, and next generation sequencing technologies across mouse, rat, and human model systems in our project will give unprecedented insight into mechanisms of diabetic neuropathic pain and will identify novel therapeutic opportunities to treat this highly prevalent and exceedingly difficult to manage disorder.

PHR: Narrative The grand challenge in the life sciences during the 21st century is understanding how all molecules of life interact, working in concert to give rise to the living state, normal and diseased. Molecular biophysics is the interdisciplinary field that will provide this understanding. The Program in Molecular Biophysics trains predoctoral researchers to solve biomedical problems from first principles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER AT EL PASO
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will elucidate the molecular functions of previously unstudied estrogen-regulated divergent transcription and its products. The results of the study will identify novel targets for estrogen-driven diseases and will provide the research community with unique tools for studying estrogen-dependent signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well known that there are many cell-specific functions and behaviors that have been missed by the limitations of having to rely on easily obtainable cells such as blood cells or lymphoblastoid cell lines for epidemiological studies of disease causation, risk factors, and biomarker identification. Advances in iPSC technologies now allow us to consider non-invasive large-scale deep cellular phenotyping efforts on disease-appropriate cell types in human subjects from easily obtained blood cells. Using a rigorous experimental approach benefiting from subjects from extended pedigrees, we propose to test for genotype×environment interaction (GEI) experimentally by examining cellular phenotypic variation before and after a controlled environmental stress challenge. We expect that the proposed project will establish the cellular basis of GEI influencing complex phenotypes of relevance to human health.

PHR: Project Narrative Safe and affordable housing provides a critical foundation for health; however, its relationship with cancer care and outcomes is largely unknown. This study examines whether patients with cancer who receive federal housing assistance are more likely to receive timely, guideline-concordant care for breast, colorectal, prostate, and lung cancers compared to similar patients without housing assistance.

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to build on our supporting evidence by elucidating mechanistic aspects of the liver microenvironment that impact breast cancer liver metastasis. We propose to employ novel technologies, validate findings with unique patient cohort datasets and tissue specimens, and test new strategies to eliminate liver metastasis in our preclinical models. The knowledge we obtain from our proposed work should provide entry points for clinical development of new life-saving breast cancer therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Cancer cachexia, which is particularly prevalent in pancreatic cancer, is a multifactorial syndrome that encompasses metabolic disruptions, hormonal abnormalities, and inflammation leading to negative energy balance and breakdown of muscle and adipose tissue. The breakdown of muscle tissue is particularly devastating because is negatively impacts physical function and quality of life, and also impacts patient’s ability to withstand the dose and frequency of aggressive conventional treatments for the disease and thus impacts survival. In the current work we will investigate the role of Cellular Communication Network Factor 2 (CCN2), also known as connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), which is produced by pancreatic tumors and in skeletal muscles in response to pancreatic cancer, in driving cachexia and muscle dysfunction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because preterm birth and oxygen therapy in premature infants causes incurable vision impairment and myopia. Results from the study will advance our understanding of why vision problems and myopia of prematurity occurs in almost 1 of every 10 infants born in the United States. Our ultimate goal is to develop preventive and therapeutic strategies to preserve vision in premature infants.

ORG_NAME: WHITE RIVER JUNCTION VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: More than 8,000 Veterans undergo abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair each year. Nearly 70% are treated with endovascular abdominal aortic aneurysm repair (EVAR), where a stent covered in fabric is used to reinforce the weakened aorta. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) directives mandate surveillance imaging after EVAR life-long, typically provided via a once-yearly contrast-enhanced CT scan. In this proposal, we use a mixed-methods design to (1) qualitatively assess Veteran, family, and health care team members’ attitudes and beliefs surrounding surveillance imaging after EVAR and (2) quantitatively examine observational data sources to best characterize surveillance imaging risks, benefits, and outcomes after EVAR. This evidence will be shared with Veterans and key stakeholders to better inform use of surveillance imaging after EVAR.

PHR: Diabetes is a common health condition among older Veterans. It is important for patients and their healthcare providers to understand the benefits and risks of diabetes medications. A particular area of uncertainty is when patients require additional treatment after an initial medication, metformin, is ineffective. This study advances diabetes care by studying the effects of generic and newer diabetes medications when added to metformin. We will use data from a large nationwide sample of Veterans 65 years and older and apply methods to carefully control for factors that may bias the results. The study will then compare three commonly used diabetes medications that may be added to the treatment regimen, and evaluate risks of mortality, diabetes complications, healthcare utilization, and cost effectiveness. This will ultimately help healthcare providers and patients make informed treatment decisions that align with patients’ unique circumstances and goals of care.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Our overall goal is to understand the molecular mechanisms how the cell cycle and differentiation progression are linked and can be synergistically manipulated to regulate terminal cell differentiation of adipocytes and thus fat mass. Understanding how to regulate adipocyte differentiation has many immediate applications for treating the current worldwide epidemic of obesity. The results of this proposed work will likely have applicability to brown fat, skeletal muscle, pancreatic beta, and other terminal cell differentiation processes important for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the proposed project is to conduct rigorous longitudinal clinical validation of MarkVCID-selected biomarkers in a diverse cohort free of dementia, and to investigate the associations of these biomarkers with SVD neuropathologic indices, working synergistically with other consortium sites and contributing scientific expertise, experimental infrastructure, and scientific guidance. Rigorously validated, high-quality SVD biomarkers will have broad clinical implications including refined participant selection and enhanced monitoring of the treatment response in clinical drug and prevention trials, as well as long term implications in the advancement of diagnosis, prevention and treatment of SVD related cognitive decline and dementia in aging.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety and mood disorders are the most prevalent psychiatric conditions, with deficits in cognitive control and emotional reactivity representing proposed mechanisms of disorder onset. Sleep is critical for the optimal neurobehavioral functioning of these transdiagnostic mechanisms, and sleep disturbances, specifically in the deepest stage of sleep (i.e., slow-wave sleep), are implicated in anxiety and mood disorders. The present study will experimentally enhance sleep slow-wave activity via acoustic stimulation and assess neurobehavioral improvements in cognitive control and emotional reactivity in young adults experiencing anxiety and depression symptoms to understand the role of slow-wave sleep in emotion regulation and inform targeted sleep-based preventative treatments for anxiety and mood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although physical activity is an important component of pediatric asthma management, urban minority children with asthma face many barriers to participation in sports and other forms of physical activity. The current study may have a profound impact on public health because it aims to rigorously evaluate the effectiveness of a novel school-based intervention that addresses key barriers to physical activity in urban minority children with asthma. Should the intervention prove successful in reducing symptoms and improving health of urban children with asthma, it has the potential to serve as a model for improved asthma care in urban communities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Research indicates that perceived stigma within medical encounters is prevalent and problematic for lung cancer patients’ well-being and quality of cancer care. Promoting empathic communication appears to be a potentially effective intervention target to help reduce patients’ perceptions of stigma within clinical encounters; however, no formal trainings exist that focus on teaching empathic communication to oncology care providers (OCPs). Building upon favorable findings from a prior R21 (R21CA202793) and the importance of developing interventions to address lung cancer stigma, our goal is to conduct a national trial of empathic communication skills (ECS) training to facilitate improvements in the medical and psychosocial care of patients through de-stigmatizing interactions with OCPs for patients diagnosed with lung cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: USC TCORS OVERALL Th USC TCORS will conduct research that will identify how adolescents and young adults are impacted by novel oral nicotine products, e-cigarettes, and other tobacco products. We will also identify if certain characteristics of nicotine products, like the flavor, and the marketing strategies have an especially strong impact on young people. This research will inform future FDA policies addressing these nicotine products by identifying the likely impact that new regulations may have on preventing nicotine use in young people.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Epilepsy contributes a significant proportion of the world’s burden of disease and is associated with widespread discrimination and stigma which together with other drivers of the treatment gap prevent most PWE from reaching medical care. A complete understanding of its characterization, comorbidities and risk factors is inevitable for developing targeted preventive strategies and other interventions. Community engagement programs addressing epilepsy related stigma especially among the vulnerable adolescents can favorably impact quality of life, reduce disability, and create a fundamental shift in the perception of and behavior related to epilepsy.

PHR: Proposal Narrative Breathing rapidly switches between different patterns in response to the interoceptive signals from the body, and its dysfunction results in serious pathological conditions. The proposed studies here will reveal the neural circuits underlying two discrete and critical breathing patterns in response to different stimuli. This work will lead to not only better understanding of the functional neural circuits for interoception, but also the identification of the endogenous neural pathways underlying these two critical breathing responses, thereby providing new opportunities for the development of novel therapeutics for breathing abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will use intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG) to characterize the effects of sevoflurane anesthesia on intra-operative phase-amplitude coupling and effective connectivity, and it will determine whether this modulation can identify seizure foci and predict seizure outcomes, during resective surgery for pediatric drug-resistant focal epilepsy. Creating normative atlases of these iEEG-derived metrics will provide critical reference by illuminating the human brain’s endogenous neurophysiology landscape under varying concentrations of sevoflurane. Clinically, establishing inducible tools for intra-operative localization of epileptic brain regions is expected to reduce diagnostic burden, optimize treatment cost effectiveness, avoid the complications associated with extra-operative mapping, facilitate more accurate resection margins, and ultimately lead to better seizure outcomes.

PHR: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) has a poor prognosis, with about 50,000 new cases and 45,000 deaths every year. Whereas new therapeutics have increased the overall survival rate of cancer patients in general, these improvements are rarely seen in PDAC, emphasizing the need for new therapeutic targets. Because endoplasmic reticulum-to-mitochondria transfer of calcium is required for cancer cell survival, we propose to use animal and cell-culture models to identify the role of this process in the development and metastasis in pancreatic cancer, anticipating that this may lead to treatments that significantly improve patient outcomes for this highly lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cervical cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer in American Indian/Alaska Native  (AI/AN) women, who are nearly twice as likely to develop cervical cancer compared to non-  Hispanic white (NHW) women and four times as likely to die from it. While implementation  strategies and relevant evidence-based interventions (EBIs) exist to increase screening, few  have been tested in AI/AN populations. Furthermore, few health care settings have adopted  these EBIs, and their evaluation is limited. AI/ANs cite a number of barriers to cancer screening  including cultural reluctance to access Western medicine for non-acute health problems;  transportation difficulties; lack of childcare; and negative perception of health providers.  Enabling factors, however, include access to female health professionals (including Indigenous  health workers), and locally devised health plans that aim to improve access, health provider  knowledge, recall systems, targeted culturally relevant health promotion, and population  registers. Similarly, low HPV vaccination rates among Native communities call for locally and  culturally relevant information and education efforts. Recent studies suggest that low-cost,  targeted, multipronged approach[es] may be effective in Native communities to increase both  vaccination and screening rates, and emphasize the importance of indigenous leadership in  both cancer prevention planning and promotion within the community. This is consistent with  recommendations by the US Community Preventive Service Task Force (USCPSTF) for  multicomponent (individual demand, provider delivery, access) and multilevel (i.e., patient,  provider, health system) EBIs.  To address this gap, we propose to use Implementation Science to assess the implementation  and effectiveness of the existing cervical cancer screening strategies and EBIs in a community  health center serving AI/AN patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative  Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) signaling has been shown to regulate numerous processes throughout the body, both during development and adult life, and aberrant PDGF signaling has been causally associated with defects in craniofacial development, cancer, vascular disorders and fibrotic diseases. Defects in craniofacial development comprise one of the most prevalent birth defects in humans, with an estimated incidence in the United States of 1/940 live births for cleft lip and 1/1,574 live births for cleft palate. The studies proposed here will provide valuable insight into the mechanisms underlying craniofacial development by characterizing dimerization, activation, trafficking and signal molecule binding dynamics for PDGFRa/b heterodimers, which may contribute to the development of new therapeutic directions for the treatment of human craniofacial birth defects.

PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol tolerance is a key factor leading to increased consumption and subsequent alcohol abuse and alcoholism. Our goal is to understand, at the molecular level, the adaptations that occur in response to alcohol exposure that underlie tolerance and its compounding effects on disorders of addiction. In this project we will explore a key regulated process triggered during rapid ethanol exposure resulting in persistent changes in neuronal intrinsic plasticity and its impact on voluntary alcohol consumption. !

PHR: We aim to improve the medical care and well being of the millions of Veterans who have hearing loss. We hope to demonstrate that providing simple, low cost hearing assistance during Emergency Department visits can help patients to understand what they must do to take care of themselves after they leave the ED. Better understanding could result in improved health outcomes and lower healthcare costs for older Veterans with hearing loss and could translate beyond VA to the many more millions of Americans who are also affected.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While smoking cessation reduces risk of lung cancer, former smokers remain at higher risk of disease compared to never smokers. To help control lung cancer in a population that has already taken a major step to decrease risk, this project seeks to identify genetic, epigenetic and biochemical predictors of lung cancer risk. Findings from this study may provide information that may be used for targeted strategies in lung cancer prevention and screening.

PHR: The nation’s opioid crisis has led to a series of policies within the VA designed to reduce the risk of opioid overdose and misuse. While these policies address an important public health problem, it is not known whether Veterans with serious illness may be experiencing unintended consequences of these well-intentioned policies and guidelines. Veterans with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) have very limited life expectancy and high rates of uncontrolled pain. They are at increased risk of opioid-related adverse events, but have fewer non-opioid analgesic alternatives and may face barriers to non-pharmacologic therapies. This novel project will examine how the VA’s opioid policies have affected the treatment of Veterans with ESRD over the past decade, with a focus on important outcomes including pain management approaches, uncontrolled pain, and adverse events. This project will yield important insights into the healthcare experiences of 35,000 Veterans with ESRD, with the overall goal of improving the quality of pain management for this high-risk population.

PHR: Surgery can precipitate the development of both chronic pain and long-term opioid use. There is a need for strategies to augment perioperative pharmacotherapeutic management of pain with non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent long-term sequelae. Psychological interventions such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can effectively reduce distress and improve functioning among patients with chronic pain. While CBT has been used extensively in patients with established chronic pain, it has not been used as a preventive intervention targeting the transition from acute to chronic postsurgical pain. The Perioperative Pain Self- management (PePS) program has the potential to reduce the incidence of chronic post-surgical pain and long- term opioid use among Veterans. This study will: 1) Examine the efficacy of PePS compared to standard care on 6-month pain, mood and functioning outcomes as well as time to post-surgical opioid and other analgesic use cessation, and 2) Elucidate the context for subsequent implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative Autophagy is an intracellular recycling process where crescent-shaped membranes expand around cellular material and seal to form a double-membrane vesicle known as the autophagosome. While we recently identified the components that seal these membranes to allow for efficient recycling, how the components are targeted to the membrane is unknown, and we seek to elucidate this process. Understanding this mechanism is important for human health, as autophagy regulates the cellular response to stress and is dysregulated in many human diseases, including neurodegeneration, cancer, heart disease, liver disease, and aging.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative: Overuse of diagnostic testing in hospitalized adults is an important contributor to unsustainably high healthcare costs and also has harmful effects on individual patients. Methods to identify hospitals with high levels of diagnostic intensity, potentially associated with diagnostic overuse, are lacking. I propose to (1) perform a systematic review of published studies evaluating hospital-level diagnostic overuse, (2) use a hospital-level diagnostic intensity index, with hospital claims data from the Medicare program, to identify hospitals with high levels of diagnostic intensity, and (3) evaluate the relationship between diagnostic intensity and quality of care, specifically missed diagnoses.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Developing and refining methods to measure hospital-level diagnostic intensity, identify outlier hospitals, and characterize the relationship between diagnostic intensity and missed diagnoses

PHR: NARRATIVE A smoker's nicotine metabolism efficiency can influence their lung cancer risk. This is driven by variation in the activity of the enzyme CYP2A6. In this grant we will develop a CYP2A6 genetic score to predict CYP2A6 activity in ever smokers and then determine the association of the score with lung cancer risk.

PHR: NARRATIVE Although smoking is a recognized risk factor for lung cancer, 14% of Americans continue to smoke. About 11-24 % of smokers will develop lung tumors over the lifetime, with a greater cancer incidence in African American and Native Hawaiian cigarette smokers as compared with European Americans, Japanese Americans, and Latinos. Our studies will conduct comprehensive exposome analyses to help provide insight into the origins of this variability in sensitivity to smoking-mediated lung cancer and help identify individuals at risk who should be candidates for special smoking cessation intervention or chemopreventive therapy.

PHR: Relevance of the proposed research project to public health The application addresses PA-19-056 goal as a Research Project Grant on new ways of treating stem cell and wound healing defects in diabetic corneal disease. We will focus on normalizing human diabetic corneal epithelial stem cells, which are the source of corneal surface lining, through the action of a new diabetic corneal marker Wnt5a that accelerates wound healing, as well as through gene therapy blocking Wnt5a inhibition with innovative non-toxic and biodegradable nano polymer conjugate. If successful, the proposal may have a high impact for future treatment of frequent wound healing-related corneal problems in diabetic patients.

PHR: NARRATIVE Former smokers remain at high risk for lung cancer even 25 years after quitting yet little is known about the biochemical mechanisms leading to lung cancer in former smokers. This project investigates the hypothesis that exposure to ubiquitous environmental carcinogens can be very damaging to former smokers because of particles and other changes in their lungs and that chronic inflammation in former smokers is also involved in their high cancer susceptibility. Specific chemical biomarkers will be used to test these theories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the prevalence of obesity in the United States, understanding how neuroendocrine signals mediate the impact of food experiences on consumption is an important step in the development of approaches for treating diseases of maladaptive ingestive behavior. To this end, we propose to investigate the role of brainstem glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) in underlying the suppressed consumption of a recently eaten food. Furthermore, we aim to characterize the role of two brainstem inputs to understand how the effects of GLP-1 signaling can be modulated to promote overconsumption.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This program brings together highly respected scientists with expertise ranging from epidemiology and biostatistics to molecular aspects of tobacco control to determine why lung cancer risk from cigarette smoking is significantly different among five diverse ethnic/racial groups. The multidisciplinary team in this program follows this important lead to determine new approaches toward prevention of lung cancer, the leading cancer killer in the U.S.

PHR: NARRATIVE Senescence cells accumulate with age and are thought to contribute to age-related diseases. Here, we propose to comprehensively map senescent cells in high resolution in the human heart and lung. We will use multi-modal, high-content, and high-throughput approaches in whole tissues, organ slices, and isolated cells in order to characterize and map the senescent cell population, identify the relevant endogenous triggers for senescent cell formation, and delineate the specific senescent cell properties that modulate the response to senolytic therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a painful inherited blood disorder with significant early mortality that affects millions of people worldwide. Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation remains the only curative therapy; however, little is known about how the HSC bone marrow niche health could be impacting transplantation recovery and success, and how damage to the bone marrow niche by SCD pathophysiology contributes to post-transplant complications. This work will be an important first step to understanding how transcriptional dysfunction in SCD MSCs influences HSC support, which could ultimately have implications for improved success of SCD curative therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phthalates are among the most ubiquitous endocrine disrupting chemicals and the widespread exposure poses a risk to pregnant women, a group more sensitive to insults from environmental agents than the general population; however, evidence is limited and inconsistent regarding phthalate metabolites’ effect on maternal gestational weight gain (GWG) and fetal growth trajectories. The primary goal of this research proposal is to use innovative, theory-driven methods to explore associations and highlight the interpretability of phthalate metabolites’ effect on maternal GWG and fetal growth patterns among a diverse group of healthy pregnant women across the United States. The knowledge expected from the proposed study can provide opportunities to design interventions to reduce exposure levels, implement policies to regulate phthalate concentrations in products and, educate and target women at greatest risk of exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than half of the estimated tuberculosis (TB) disease cases in children worldwide have not been reported to the health system, and 96% of pediatric TB deaths are in children not started on treatment. The proposed project seeks to address the key barriers in diagnosing pulmonary TB in children through discovery of a host proteomic biosignature in urine. The findings will be relevant to the public health efforts to reduce the burden of TB in children and will support the development of a non-invasive, non-sputum based assay for childhood TB disease at the point-of-care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black pregnant people are disproportionately impacted by trauma in their lifetime, which has been associated with significantly increased risk for maternal morbidity and mortality. The proposed study aims to understand the physiologic mechanisms by which trauma may contribute to disparities in labor complications through epigenetic changes. Knowledge gained from this study will advance science in the fields of trauma, epigenetics, and pregnancy with the objective of identifying modifiable risk factors for labor complications that could be tested for clinical treatments and prevention approaches to reduce racial disparities in pregnancy- related morbidity/mortality.

PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of this proposal is to evaluate the impact of DNA methylation inhibition of tumor cells, CAR T cells, and combined towards more effective treatments against diffuse midline glioma. Our secondary goal is to understand the treatment naïve microenvironment in DMG and how this environment changes in response to DNA methylation inhibition and CAR T cell administration. Our studies may pave the way for more effective treatments against DMG, a universally fatal disease with limited treatment options.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our Cystic Fibrosis (CF) Center at Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center (CCHMC) already has an excellent electronic medical record system (EPIC) and a site-specific IRB approved genotype database available for clinical and research use. We intend to leverage these capabilities to develop Personalized Cystic Fibrosis Therapy and Research Center (PCFC) for individual patients to determine his/her susceptibility to a particular form of CF mutation, and take steps to mitigate the early onset of the disease.

PHR: Narrative Analytes such as cell-free DNA (cfDNA) and circulating tumor cells (CTC) exist in very low proportion in liquid biopsy specimens, and therefore analyses of these samples are potentially heavily influenced by pre-analytical factors associated with acquisition and processing. We propose to expand our foundation-funded pilot study to evaluate effects of sample processing protocols on cfDNA and CTC analysis to further investigate effect of the patient-specific context. Results will inform the design of liquid biopsy-incorporated clinical trials by identifying optimal timing of blood collection to minimize effects of pre-analytical variables, and will be used to facilitate implementation of liquid biopsy testing in a clinical setting.

PHR: Narrative Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States. The Biobehavioral Cancer Prevention and Control Training Program (BCPT) prepares pre-doctoral and post-doctoral trainees for careers that will address the challenge of cancer prevention and control. The BCPT is a joint effort of departments in the Schools of Public Health, Medicine, Pharmacy, and Nursing at the University of Washington, the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, and affiliated institutions including the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance.

PHR: Project Narrative The development of drug resistance limits the long term success of genotype directed therapies, including EGFR inhibitors in EGFR mutant lung cancer. By identifying and evaluating EGFR inhibitor based combination therapies in vitro and in vivo coupled with clinical trials of such combinations with these analyses of plasma derived DNA from on treatment lung cancer patients, the studies in this proposal aim to improve the outcome of EGFR mutant and other oncogenic subsets of lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diagnostic errors are a significant public health concern and the leading cause of harm due to medical care in the U.S.; yet research to date has principally focused on the clinician as the center of both the problems and the solutions. The Patient-Partnered Diagnostic Center of Excellence will shift this paradigm by convening diverse scientists and patients around research questions developed and prioritized by patients yielding patient- centered diagnostic safety solutions and reductions in diagnostic safety events. By providing clear evidence by measuring the problem (Safety I) and devising solutions to build diagnostic team resilience (Safety II), our Center has high potential to improve diagnostic safety for all patients in the U.S.
PI_NAMEs: GIARDINA, TRABER L;MILLER, KRISTEN ELIZABETH (contact);SMITH, KELLY MICHELLE

PROJECT_TITLE: The Patient-Partnered Diagnostic Center of Excellence

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative: The current COVID-19 pandemic is occurring in the midst of a public health crisis of opioid use disorder and overdose during pregnancy, and little is known about how these changes affect healthcare service use and outcomes. Thus, the aims of this study are to 1) examine how state policies related to maternal opioid use during pregnancy have changed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and 2) examine the effects of COVID-19-related changes in state policies regarding maternal opioid use on patterns of healthcare service use, maternal and child outcomes, and healthcare costs. By thoroughly examining the policy responses to the COVID-19 pandemic and linking these data to detailed claims data describing healthcare service use of women who use opioids during pregnancy and their newborns, we will be able to provide critical data to providers, insurers, health systems, and policymakers as they design treatment processes and policies to provide adequate pregnancy and substance use care to this vulnerable population to mitigate these two public health crises.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: COVID-19, health systems and vulnerable populations: Policies affecting maternal opioid use during pregnancy

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unsafe e-prescription transactions, in which the prescribed medication ingredient, dosage form, or strength is not the medication dispensed, are a significant and largely unrecognized source of harm to patients. We will implement and evaluate a just-in-time feedback intervention, SAVE-Rx, that automatically identifies these dangerous medication safety events and actively communicates them to healthcare organizations for resolution. The overall objective of this proposal is to determine the effectiveness of the just-in-time feedback intervention on preventing patient harm using a large national sample of e-prescription transactions in the US.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing medication errors due to unsafe electronic prescription transactions with just-in-time feedback

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreas cancer kills essentially every patient it afflicts and, with a rising incidence and unabated mortality, it is now the third leading cause of cancer-related deaths in this country. We have developed genetically engineered animal models of pancreas cancer that have exposed unique points of vulnerability for the development of new treatments. We propose a systematic program of investigation to target distinct components of the stromal reaction in pancreas cancer as the basis for new treatment strategies against this highly resistant disease.

PHR: Metabolism plays a fundamental role in cancer growth, diagnosis, and treatment. I propose to develop improved mass spectrometry and isotope tracer technologies for quantitation of cancer metabolism, and to apply the technology to reveal tumor metabolic activity. The resulting understanding of metabolite levels and fluxes in cancer will open new therapeutic and diagnostic opportunities.

PHR: Project Narrative Ciliopathy disorders are unified by their overlapping clinical features and underlying cilia-related biological mechanisms, combined affecting ~1/500 individuals. This project will identify how disease variants result in abnormal global ciliary protein content and if/how these variants contribute to aberrant trafficking. These experiments will lay the groundwork for determining the mechanisms of individual ciliopathies, and also a more comprehensive understanding of cilium biology.
