ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative These early stage clinical trials take advantage of a niche prostate cancer patient cohort who have failed local “curative” therapies to address a significant unmet clinical need in a sizable recurrent cancer patient population who would otherwise soon face androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) through medical or surgical castration. Not only expensive, ADT also causes many serious and unpleasant side effects including sexual dysfunction/impotence, osteoporosis and bone fractures, mode swings, hot flashes, fatigue, loss of lean body mass, gynecomastia and anemia. In spite of multiple next-gen androgen and its receptor targeted drugs (e.g., abiraterone acetate, enzalutamide), DNA-repair drugs (PARP inhibitors) and microtubule targeting taxane drugs indicated for managing more advanced stage diseases, there is currently no FDA-approved modality before ADT to intercept or delay disease progression in the clinic practice. The trials will provide the first of its kind knowledge of safety and preliminary efficacy of an AGN herbal supplement against prostate cancer at therapeutic dosages, with mechanisms of action distinct from the currently approved drugs and more favorable safety profiles. The novel dose-exposure pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenetics information from these trials will be applicable to other patient populations to evaluate prevention and therapy of other cancers as well as other diseases since AGN supplements have been sold for memory health and pain killing for nearly 2 decades.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), also known as primary liver cancer, disproportionately affects minorities and the burden of this deadly disease has increased significantly. The proposed study will determine if genetic differences in African, European or Native American ancestry are responsible for the significant racial differences in liver cancer risk and survival, either directly or indirectly by interacting with other risk factors or social factors. Understanding which genetic features increase liver cancer risk or worsen survival could potentially improve our ability to (1) identify those people who are at highest risk and (2) develop screening and treatment strategies that are based on a person’s individualized risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The proposed study intervention represents the first PrEP mHealth tool that synergistically addresses intimate partner violence and alcohol-related barriers to HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with novel peer navigation and telemedicine components that are designed to increase PrEP initiation and adherence among women in community supervision programs (CSPs) in New York City. This study addresses a key priority of the National HIV strategy to reduce HIV disparities and increase (PrEP) uptake among cis-gendered women. Advancing an effective PrEP intervention for women in CSPs, who are disproportionately Black and Latinx, holds promise for reducing HIV disparities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Systematic comparison of gene regulatory networks across species is essential for better understanding of the evolution of normal and disease traits. This project will develop and apply novel computational tools for single cell omic datasets from multiple species to enable identification and characterization of cell types and their underlying gene regulatory networks. This project will also generate and analyze a novel multi-species multi- omic single cell dataset for kidney that will provide fundamental insights into normal kidney function and diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors have, thus far, been ineffective in the treatment of gliomas, largely due to the immunologically “cold” microenvironment and a low number of neoantigens. Our group recently discovered that IDH1/2 mutations, which are common in gliomas, induce homologous recombination defects and confer sensitivity to DNA damage response inhibitors. The goal of this project is to uncover strategies to exploit IDH1/2-induced DNA repair defects with DNA damage response inhibitors to induce synthetic lethality and generate an immunologically favorable tumor microenvironment thereby improving the response to immune checkpoint inhibition.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because advancement in our understanding of the mechanisms by which the brain encodes and maintains working memory representations in the normal brain is necessary to illuminate the mechanisms that could go awry in the pathological brain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: (aka Project Narrative) Septic survivors exhibit long-term immunologic dysfunction associated with higher rates of disability, depression, subsequent infections, and all-cause mortalities; however, our understanding of the regulation of these responses and their impact on disease is lacking. This proposal will integrate mechanistic in vitro studies with human data and quality of life outcomes measures to provide an indepth assessment of the systemic epigenetic events that occur during sepsis and how their regulation of the post-septic immunosuppressive response effects the immunologic and functional outcomes of patients. The proposal has the potential to provide fundamental insight into disease regulation and novel therapeutics for the treatment of post-sepsis immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Marginal zone B cells are key players in defending against bacteria and viruses that enter the circulation; generating a reservoir of antibodies against common pathogens, and regulating tolerance to our own proteins and lipids. A quantitative understanding of their homeostasis will provide unparalleled insights into determinants that shape their pool size and clonal repertoire, across our lifespan and during immune responses. Leveraging or manipulating these determinants to modulate antibody-mediated protection – for example, to boost the efficacy of vaccines or potency of immune-regulative treatments – will have direct relevance to human health, guiding the development of therapeutics against systemic infections, immunodeficiencies, and autoimmunity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal heterogeneity and clonal selection contribute to drug resistance and disease recurrence in children with relapsed T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) who have a dismal survival rate of < 25%. By single-cell approaches, we discovered the intra-leukemia heterogeneity associated with T-cell development and drug sensitivity. This project will identify clonal therapy by combining drugs that target major clones and rare ones contributing to disease relapse to improve the outcomes for children with T-ALL.

PHR: Project Narrative Analyses using four decades of U.S. SEER data support that three cancers have been increasing dramatically in younger adults over the past decade: 318,781 adults aged 25–49 years were diagnosed with colorectal (n=114,220), thyroid (n=146,977), and kidney (n=57,584) cancer with annual percent increases at 2.44%, 4.81%, and 3.83% per year, respectively, during 2006–2015. To support more effective early prevention, we propose to develop a comprehensive mathematical framework to identify causes behind the rising incidence in these three key early-onset cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Building on our previous validation studies conducted in highly relevant animal models, the successful completion of the proposed studies will provide at least one novel, highly effective and safe mechanism-based formulation of small molecules for attenuating painful cutaneous blistering/inflammation caused by exposure to chemical warfare arsenical vesicants and, perhaps, other similar agents. These studies are crucial for moving the newly developed formulation to clinic. The outcome of the proposed research is likely to have a significant impact on human health protection in the event of accidental or intentional mass population exposure to vesicant chemicals used in warfare.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The goal of this project is to develop a therapeutic for treating endometriosis. Endometriosis is a high priority research area of NICHD. NIH has also stated as a goal in the 2021-2025 Strategic Plan that “at least one, novel, non-hormonal pharmacologic treatment for endometriosis [will be] identified and moved to clinical trials.” This is an aspirational goal because current management protocols for endometriosis—including hormones and surgery—do not address the root cause of the disease, fail to reverse disease progression, leave a chance of recurrence, and often present patients with undesirable side effects. We have identified a lead candidate that specifically targets a downstream pathway component known to contribute to endometriosis pathogenesis and endometrial migration and invasion. In this Phase IIB application, we will further develop this lead candidate for IND submission to the FDA for allowance to begin clinical trials.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE − PROJECT 1  Despite the promise of immune checkpoint inhibition in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), only a minority of patients ultimately benefit. Continuing Project 1 has already identified tumor metabolism and hypoxia as potential drivers of anti-PD-1 resistance in this disease and now seek to examine the interaction between tumor hypoxia and metabolism, combinatorial immunotherapy, and response. The goal of this project will be to identify the next generation of metabolically driven immunotherapy combination for clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eating habits that are uncontrollable and persist without respect to negative consequences are compulsive and can be observed in both obesity and eating disorders. Motivated behavior is controlled by brain circuits that are sensitive to how hungry we are, but how hunger changes the responsivity of these circuits to negative consequences associated with eating is unknown. This project will test the hypothesis that hunger modulates the communication of negative consequences to motivational brain regions, and will improve our understanding of how these mechanisms can contribute to compulsive eating.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastric cancer disparities remain a public health concern in American Indian populations, especially in the Navajo Nation, one of the largest tribes in the United States. Despite awareness of these disparities, little is known about risk factors for gastric cancer in the American Indian population, particularly Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection. This project seeks to assess the burden of H. pylori infection in the Navajo Nation and identify strategies to reduce that burden.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE − PROJECT 2  Treatment of human papillomavirus (HPV) positive squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx (OPC) is highly toxic; however, the use of Trans-Oral Robotic Surgery (TORS) could provide improvements in toxicity if patients with high risk neck disease (HRND) could be identified prior to surgery, and treated with other modalities. This project: 1) subjects clinical samples from over 400 patients with HPV positive OPC treated with TORS in two separate cohorts, including ECOG 3311, to comprehensive genomic, transcriptomic and radiomic analysis to examine a preliminary signature for predicting HRND, coupled with 2) in vivo analysis of mutations already identified as associated with HRND and immune infiltrate and 3) quality of life, toxicity and biospecimen analysis of a prospective trial combining TORS, RT and immunotherapy in this disease. The overarching goal of this Project is to truly apply precision oncology to HPV+ OPC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE − PROJECT 3  Although great strides have been made with immunotherapy for head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), only a minority of patients respond to anti-PD1 monotherapy. Thus, there is an imperative need to find better treatment options for these patients. LAG3 limits effector T cell function and exhibits synergy with anti-PD1 in mouse models of cancer, and thus is a logical therapeutic target to increase anti-tumor immunity in combination with anti-PD1. There are now 10+ LAG3-targeting therapeutic clinical trials in the US, and yet we still know very little about how LAG3 blockade, alone or in combination with anti-PD1, impacts the immune response to cancer, and whether biomarkers exist which could predict responsiveness.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) on Opioids and Overdose at Rhode Island Hospital, in the first four years of Phase 1, has successfully created a vibrant interdisciplinary Center of research excellence consisting of 4 Cores and a critical mass of investigators dedicated to addressing the opioid and overdose crisis. The COBRE has also mentored junior faculty Project Leaders into independently funded researchers. The proposed Phase 2 application will further improve the research infrastructure and continue to develop and strengthen the critical mass of investigators focused on an area of clinical research that is of urgent public health importance.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Chu, Edward OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE The Montefiore Einstein Cancer Center (MECC) seeks to reduce the burden of cancer through its basic, clinical, and population-based research and the translation of preclinical and epidemiological studies into clinical initiatives for the prevention, detection, and treatment of cancer. This is accomplished through MECC’s four established research programs and eight shared resources. MECC seeks to understand the basis for, and ameliorate, cancer disparities that affect the 1.5M, largely minority, under-represented population of the Bronx, the Center’s main catchment area. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dystonia is a movement disorder in which muscles twist and contort, forcing patients into painful and disabling postures and abnormal positions. The brain changes that lead to dystonia are largely unknown, but may result from failure of inhibitory mechanisms to keep muscle activity in check. We will perform brain MRI scans to identify the structural changes associated with dystonia, which is an essential step to developing more and better treatments for this disabling movement disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – CAREER ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM (CEP)  The Hillman Cancer Center HN SPORE Career Enhancement Program (CEP) is designed to foster the growth of a new, diverse generation of diverse scientists dedicated to head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) research leading to improvements in the prevention, detection, and therapy of this deadly disease. To accomplish this, we have established collaborations with Johns Hopkins, Howard University, Emory University and Meharry Medical College to increase the representation of underrepresented minorities in the HN SPORE, in addition to several internal initiatives to increase the diversity of the CEP to the benefit of the entire HNSCC research community.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scale-up of HIV preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a key strategy of the U.S. initiative to end the HIV epidemic, but healthcare providers lack tools to support PrEP discussions and prescribing for the patients most likely to benefit. This research will evaluate whether integrating automated tools into electronic health records to help providers efficiently and equitably identify potential candidates for PrEP, discuss PrEP, and prescribe PrEP can improve PrEP initiation and persistence in safety-net community health centers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blinding diseases result from the loss of retinal neurons, thus, strategies to replace lost retinal cells are needed to restore vision to patients. Retinal stem cells responsible for repair in regenerative species, such as fish, appear to retain regenerative potential in humans but remain dormant under normal conditions. We have shown that the immune system regulates retinal stem cell regenerative potential, and propose to determine the impact of disease-relevant aspects of retinal cell death on immune cell reactivity and how this regulates the nature of the regenerative process, providing insights which will support the development of regenerative therapies.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Biology and Development of the Eye Study Section[BDE]

PHR: Project Narrative Metastatic disease is the primary cause of cancer morbidity and mortality, accounting for more than 90% of cancer-related deaths, yet the molecular mechanisms underlying neoplastic cell metastasis remains poorly understood. The proposed research, herein, will integrate single cell RNA sequencing, novel methods of cyclic immunofluorescence, and cell-based mechanistic studies to identify how discrete subtypes of neoplastic cells, defined by co-expression of immune and tumor characteristics, disseminate in patients with colorectal cancer. Identification and validation of these mechanisms will contribute to our understanding of tumor progression and the development of metastatic disease, with the potential to uncover therapeutic targets aimed to prevent or reduce neoplastic cell dissemination.

PHR: Use of e-cigarettes has dramatically increased among adolescents; however, few prevention programs focusing on prevention and escalation of e-cigarettes have been developed, tested, or widely disseminated throughout the U.S. We have developed a novel Be Vape-Free school-based curriculum aimed at changing high school students’ attitudes towards, misperceptions about, intentions to use and actual use of e-cigarettes, which will be evaluated for changes in adolescents’ knowledge, attitudes, intentions and actual use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor diet quality is an important risk factor for increased asthma prevalence and poor asthma control. To address the question whether adults with asthma can benefit from following a healthy diet, this project will study a behavioral intervention promoting the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) among racially/ethnically and socioeconomically diverse patients with uncontrolled asthma. This study has high potential to advance asthma care by improving our understanding of the role of diet quality in asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The research proposes to use dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) to improve the sensitivity in magic angle spinning NMR experiments that will lead to molecular structures with higher precision. In particular, we propose to apply high frequency DNP to familial amyloid systems whose structure we will determine and to high-resolution multidimensional 17O experiments. We will develop instrumentation for the experiments, and new time domain methods for more rapid data acquisition and we believe that the research will have a profound impact on structural biology, medical imaging and solution NMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Our team has an established history of invention, development, optimization, and validation of a ready-to-launch lab-developed test (LDT), the ENVISAGE assay. This epigenetic biomarker assay predicts future progression risk in patients with Barrett’s esophagus, with 71% sensitivity and 90% specificity. This strong performance for a prognostic assay surpasses any clinical assay currently available. Successful refinement and validation of our proposed 2nd-generation assay will greatly enhance the current repertoire of clinical tools for more precise, efficient, and accurate patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project addresses the problem of weight loss maintenance, one of the most major and critical barriers to the treatment of obesity and comorbid conditions. It is the first to apply control systems engineering, in the form of a system identification experiment, to model how behavioral and psychosocial influences combine to influence weight loss maintenance, and to evaluate the effect of four intervention strategies on the behavioral and psychosocial system. This project will enable a just-in-time adaptive intervention capable of predicting when an individual is entering a period of elevated risk for weight regain, and delivering a tailored intervention targeting the cause of regain to prevent it from occurring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will determine the role of Piezo1 expressed on OCs in the context of dysregulated bone remodeling in P. gingivalis-associated periodontitis. Therefore, this study would cause the paradigm shift in research of mechasnosensor and periodontitis. Outcomes from this project will elucidate the effect of Pg on Piezo1- mediated mechanical sensing of OC in periodontitis and develop a novel therapeutic approach to suppress pathogenic bone loss while inducing bone regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder cancer is strongly linked to environmental chemical exposures including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), but the mechanisms underlying these links remain unclear, and not all exposed individuals develop bladder cancer. PAHs like benzo[a]pyrene (BaP) are found in automobile exhaust and tobacco smoke, and differential metabolism of these chemicals by host-associated microbes could be a contributing factor to bladder cancer pathogenesis; therefore, the aim of this proposal is to define gut and urine microbial metabolism of BaP and determine how this metabolism affects bladder cells. This work impacts public health by establishing a novel chemical-microbe-host framework for evaluating bladder health within the broader context of bladder cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Rotator cuff tears are a common injury in the growing middle-to-late aged population and can cause severe pain, activity limitations and participation restrictions. The proposed research will utilize a large, unique, and previously collected cohort to help establish clinical guidelines for the use of exercise therapy as the initial treatment for rotator cuff tears using quantitative characteristics of their shoulder function. Results will guide the development of individualized treatment plans to improve outcomes while reducing time and expense of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To increase physical activity and associated chronic diseases among mothers living in low- resourced communities, innovative research to identify a multilevel intervention that is easily implemented at the community level and appropriate for mothers with little time is urgently needed. This project will use qualitative and quantitative methods in a cluster randomized control trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the Free Time for Wellness(FT4W) program, which includes free childcare at free fitness classes and peer support activities. The trial will evaluate: (1) the ability of FT4W to increase physical activity within 12 weeks as confirmed by accelerometers; (2) the potential mechanisms by which the FT4W program facilitates physical activity (e.g., environmental resources, social cohesion); and (3) potential differences in the magnitude of effect across intersecting social stratification parameters including race/ethnicity, socioeconomic position, and migration status.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Swallowing impairments (dysphagia) frequently occur after stroke and have devastating consequences on overall health and quality of life. Long-term deficits in swallow function also increase risk of morbidity (e.g. depression) and mortality (i.e. aspiration pneumonia), as such, rehabilitation of swallow function to improve safety and efficiency of swallowing is essential in this population. This study aims to: 1) Provide preliminary data to evaluate the effect of a novel lingual endurance exercise on swallow function in individuals with post-stroke dysphagia; and 2) Collect preliminary data regarding changes in white matter tract diffusion and cortical thickness and from MRI data to better understand effects of lingual exercise training on neuroplasticity.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the current project is to measure the prevalence of cancer misinformation on social media and understand the mechanisms that underlies its spread. Specifically, it aims to (1) characterize the prevalence of cancer misinformation on social media, namely Twitter and Facebook, (2) investigate how people make judgements of source credibility with regards to disreputable cancer sources, and (3) understand the cognitive mechanisms behind updating belief in cancer misinformation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will create a unique new resource to advance research into cures for blinding diseases by studying a genetic line of rhesus monkeys with a retinal disease mirroring human Bardet-Biedl syndrome, a form of retinitis pigmentosa that is currently untreatable. We will characterize the nature and time course of the disease in these unique animals and use them to test a new type of gene therapy for its ability to preserve and restore vision. Such treatments have the potential to provide sight-saving therapy to human patient with this and many other causes of blindness.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As currently the most effective and durable treatment for morbid obesity, bariatric surgery has become increasingly common in the US, but its impact on the risk of colorectal cancer remains unclear. Leveraging a longitudinal cohort of bariatric surgery patients and applying multi-omics approaches and fecal microbiota transplant experiments, the proposed study will provide novel knowledge regarding gut microbiota-related mechanisms that impact colorectal cancer risk after bariatric surgery. The gained knowledge may be translated into novel therapies targeting gut microbiota, microbial molecules, and/or immunosurveillance to reduce risk of colorectal cancer among individuals with morbid obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Senderos a la Ciencia/Pathways to Science project is specifically designed to enhance workforce diversity in the health research sciences space. By offering role model talks featuring Hispanic health research professionals at a Hispanic-serving church, and by providing near-peer mentoring to Hispanic high school students interested in pursuing health science research careers, this initiative will: 1. Build awareness and value among Hispanic parents and youth in targeted under-resourced  Hispanic communities of careers in health research. 2. Engender an interest to pursue health research careers among youth in these same communities. 3. Trigger pursuing a college path in health research among high school students in these same communities. Besides initially serving Hispanics in the greater New London, Connecticut community, this project will have the potential to reach much broader Hispanic audiences. Role model talks will be featured on the project website, which will be promoted via Hispanic Access Foundation’s bilingual social media accounts. Altogether, we foresee 1,000 unique visitors to these web pages during the project period. In addition, during the dissemination phase of this project, Hispanic Access Foundation will reach out to our network of pastors representing 150,000 Hispanic-serving churches. Interested pastors will be invited to attend replication seminars where they may learn about the Senderos/Pathways project and receive guidance for launching similar projects in their own communities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Altered exposure to specific placental hormones may underlie diverse neurological disorders including epilepsy, autism, or cognitive deficits. Placental hormone alterations can occur insidiously due to preeclampsia or infection (conditions seen in 5 to 10% of term pregnancies) or acutely due to preterm delivery (representing more than 10% of all US pregnancies); this loss of placental hormone exposure may place many infants at risk of impaired neurodevelopment. Our investigations in neuroplacentology, focused here on allopregnanolone—a potent neuroactive steroid made by the placenta—are important in determining how placental hormones or related compounds can provide novel treatments to ameliorate developmental brain damage due to placental dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite recent innovations in diagnostic testing, nearly three million people every year develop active tuberculosis (TB) but are not adequately diagnosed – in part reflecting the paucity of evidence on how to implement patient-centered case-finding strategies. Self-testing is an innovative approach that has been successfully used to enhance the diagnosis of infectious diseases such as HIV, but self-testing has not been widely used for TB to date. In this project, I will conduct a combined implementation/effectiveness evaluation of oral swabs for molecular testing as used for self-testing in six occupational centers in South Africa (as informed by formative qualitative evidence) while gaining the training I need to become a leader in the field of patient- centered TB care. 1

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision medicine holds great hope for children with cancer, but matching kids with available open clinical trials remains a challenge. The Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) team at University of Chicago has developed GEARBOx (Genomic Eligibility Algorithm at Relapse for Better Outcomes), a tool to assist clinicians in quickly and efficiently finding a clinical trial for a patient with relapsed or refractory acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). Based on the success of the platform for AML, the PCDC now endeavors to expand GEARBOx to include several more tumor types and to develop better and faster ways to automatically collect and incorporate data into the clinical trial matching algorithm.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Why we age continues to be a critically unanswered question in biology. The original hallmarks of aging were described nearly a decade ago (López-Otín et al., 2013), but how they intersect and whether interactions among them cause pathological aging remains unknown. Together, these studies will provide the field with a novel set of customizable tools to track the hallmarks and test the hypothesis that many hallmarks intersect at the informational level, making them co-reversible when information in the nucleus is reset to a youthful state.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this study is to develop new statistical methods, algorithms and open-source software for building large-scale embedding models of brain networks using fMRI of 1206 subjects available from the publicly available Human Connectome Project database. The proposed models and algorithms will be used to establish the base- line map for the genetic inﬂuences on brain networks at the voxel level. Considering recent surge of interests in dynamic brain network phenotypes in relation to cognition, behavior and genetics, such detailed heritability maps will be highly useful as a baseline for future studies.

PHR: The primary mission of the coordinating center of the Pre-medical Cancer Immunotherapy Network for Canine Trials (PRECINCT) is to provide infrastructure and oversight to a highly collaborative and interactive network of researchers and clinician scientists working to investigate immunotherapeutic strategies in dogs with cancer, identify correlates of immunological and therapeutic responses and determine the value of dogs with spontaneous cancers in informing human clinical trial design. Leveraging the renowned expertise of the University of Pennsylvania in human and canine immunotherapy trials, PRECINCT's coordinating center will provide expert services in project management and research technology, data management and sharing, and biostatistical and bioinformatics support to U01 awardees and network members. This work will advance discovery, promote collaborative research and accelerate the translation of safe and effective immunotherapies into the human cancer clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Arthroscopic-assisted tibial plateau fixation (AATPF) vs. Open reduction internal fixation (ORIF): A multicenter randomized controlled trial Project Narrative The current standard treatment for tibial plateau fracture fixation, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF), has limitations, including surgical site infections, pain, stiffness, and a prolonged period of non-weight bearing restrictions.1-6 The ultimate goal of this project is to conduct a multicenter randomized controlled trial to test the hypothesis that arthroscopic-assisted tibial plateau fixation (AATPF) provides superior patient-reported outcomes, clinical outcomes, and radiographic outcomes compared to the traditional ORIF method.

PHR: NARRATIVE: GLNARCH OVERALL  This Great Lakes Native American Research Centers for Health (GLNARCH) application will pursue exciting opportunities to improve education, training, and research within the Indian Health Service Bemidji Region with increased focus on including Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCU). The Student Career Enhancement Project (SCEP) proposes important activities to expose AI/AN students to remote learning. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most promising strategies to reduce readmissions in heart failure (HF) is through the timely receipt of home health care (HHC) nurse visits and outpatient medical follow-up after discharge, yet our prior observational comparative effectiveness study found that only 12% of Medicare beneficiaries receive these evidence-based practices. Using a Hybrid Type 1 design, this study will test the effectiveness of the I- TRANSFER-HF intervention (early and intensive HHC nurse visits and early outpatient medical follow-up) in a stepped wedge cluster RCT and determine the context surrounding its implementation among a diverse sample of hospitals and HHC agencies. As the first pragmatic trial of HHC in HF, the results have the potential to inform clinical guidelines in home health and improve transitions of care and post-discharge outcomes for HF patients at a national level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research will enable the development of tools for the characterization of protein carbohydrate structures at a sensitivity, throughput, and level of detail not previously possible. The implementation of these tools will enable researchers to better understand the attributes and biomedical significance of glycans in the development and progression of a wide array of diseases. Examples of future benefits for public health include the identification of disease and cancer biomarkers for medical diagnostics and the monitoring of recombinant protein therapeutics, which will lead to better targeted drugs that are more bioactive with fewer side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: We lack understanding of how structural and functional changes in the micturition reflex are linked to bladder pain syndrome/interstitial cystitis and how stress exacerbates symptoms, thus impeding effective therapies. We hypothesize that increases in urinary frequency and pelvic pain from stress- and injury-induced changes in central and peripheral micturition circuits reflect neuropeptidergic PACAP/PAC1 receptor-mediated signaling and neuroplasticity to engender a pro-excitatory state. We will assess how maladaptive intersections between the PACAP/PAC1R pathways may be contributory to stress-induced urinary bladder dysfunction and pelvic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE – STTR PHASE II Cardiac arrest kills hundreds of thousands of Americans each year, but survival is improved with bystander cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). CPR is required by law to be taught in most U.S. high schools, but instructional methods are outdated, non-standardized, and ineffective. Building on the success of our Phase I prototype, we propose finalizing for commercial production a novel, interactive CPR video game experience that combines the drama of a live-action cardiac arrest film with a "CPR Spring" device, to improve learning of CPR skills that should translate into improved survival from cardiac arrest.

PHR: Project Narrative The DNA methyltransferase DNMT3A, applies methyl groups to DNA and has been found to be necessary for development of the human brain, regulation of body size, control of blood cell differentiation and for leukemia development. A particular form of the enzyme, DNMT3A2, is overexpressed in human cancers and may contribute to the widespread methylation changes found in every cancer. We will test whether this overexpression can initiate cancer, use cryo-EM to determine how it works on chromatin and determine how cells read methylation signals in DNA.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical cancer patients treated with standard of care (SoC) chemoradiation therapy (CRT) commonly experience disease recurrence, and current clinical testing and genomic research data cannot predict which patients will fail therapy or would benefit from personalized treatment. Based on our recent publications integrating genomic and imaging data to improve CRT risk stratification, we intend to stratify patients into groups with distinct mechanisms of resistance and validate precise treatment targets using large multi-omics (transcriptomic, radiomic, proteomic, and metabolomic) and longitudinal data. In this proposal, we will develop new radiogenomic and deep learning approaches to identify novel biomarkers from these high-dimensional and complex data and will experimentally validate these targets in vitro and in patient samples.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The goal of the Boston University Contraceptive Development Research Center is to develop a new woman-controlled on-demand contraception method based on the use of a vaginal film that releases an antisperm monoclonal antibody that prevents sperm from fertilizing the egg. There is an urgent need for more contraception choices as nearly half of all current pregnancies are unplanned. Unplanned pregnancies disproportionately affect young women and contribute to maternal and child mortality and intergenerational cycles of poverty and poor health.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative This study will identify molecular pathways that represent potential targets for interventions to protect AYA survivors against the adverse biological effects of social isolation, socioeconomic disadvantage, and other psychological and social determinants of health in the highly stressful context of cancer. Its intent is to identify functional genomic pathways through which social and psychological factors influence gene regulation and alter health outcomes in AYAs; and, to define the role of such effects in structuring health disparities in post-treatment survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: 8. NARRATIVE Chronic pain affects millions of Americans, yet less than half of patients respond to current treatments, leading to opioid relance and the opioid crisis. AfaSci has discovered a non-opioid, single molecule, dual modulator of the T-type calcium channel, a neuronal pain signaling pathway, and soluble epoxide hydrolase, an enzyme involved in inflammation. This dual modulator can provide complementary analgesia and anti-inflammation, leading to better pain relief with fewer side effects. We now propose advancing our IND AFA-281, to first-in- human clinical studies for the treatment of chronic neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the NGLY1 gene are associated with a rare congenital disorder leading to global developmental delay and neurological inflammation. Studies proposed here will reveal important understand of mitochondrial biology and immunology in the brain, which should benefit not only the NGLY1 disease but also other more complex neurodegenerative diseases that are affecting millions of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Early detection of neurocognitive disorders is highly beneficial for patients and families, yet cognitive impairment and dementia are frequently under-recognized. The UCSF Brain Health Assessment is a promising paradigm to rapidly detect cognitive impairment and provide turnkey guidance for follow-up. The proposed research will evaluate the effectiveness of the paradigm for improving brain health care via a large pragmatic trial, address challenges to implementation, and pioneer precision medicine approaches to reference group adjustments.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to develop a novel platelet-rich plasma derived biologic named BIO-PLY™ for the treatment of biofilm-related periprosthetic joint infections. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Overall Chronic conditions such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes among Alaska Native and American Indian (ANAI) people are high or on the rise and rates of tobacco use and dependence far exceed national averages. In this project, we will build the capacity of an ANAI run healthcare organization to conduct research which examines the implementation of interventions to improve ANAI health outcomes. Interventions will identify ANAIs with diabetes or pre-diabetes in dental clinics and refer to primary care, match tobacco cessation medications based on the variability in metabolism of nicotine, and encourage use of advanced care planning.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This multi-PI collaborative proposal directly addresses the specifications delineated by the FOA RFA-EY-004: Ocular Surface Innervation from Cell Types to Circuit Functions, where collectively, the aims will characterize the sensory afferents that innervate the ocular surface on all three levels requested by the FOA, morphologic, molecular, and functional, with rigor and precision. The project will implement cutting -edge genetic mouse models, advanced microscopy, single cell genomic, and machine learning ap proaches, and leverage the expertise of a preexisting, strong interdisciplinary team with a robust productivity record. Data generated from this proposal will provide an extensive, detailed resource to inform the physiology and pathophysiology of the corneal nerve afferents and inform the development of new treatments for diseases, such as dry eye disease, neurotrophic keratitis, and neuropathic ocular pain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tyrosine kinase driven Non-small-cell lung cancers (NSCLC) develop resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Waiting for resistance, reverse engineering its molecular origins, and then responding to that resistance with new drugs is a slow, costly, and ultimately losing battle. This grant will propel the model driven forward engineering design of “dual-switch selection drives” in NSCLC that re-program tumor cells to work with existing therapies to combat drug resistance—regardless of molecular origin.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HPV vaccination among adolescents is suboptimal, and parental delays and refusals are common. Addressing the unique vaccine hesitancy concerns and information needs of underserved families is critical to increase vaccination. This study will engage multiple stakeholders to develop and pilot a tailored intervention to address HPV vaccine hesitancy among Black families to increase vaccine confidence, vaccination, and ultimately help reduce HPV-related cancer disparities.

PHR: Project Narrative Owing to the significant clinical and societal burden of pediatric PNES and the limited remission rates of current adult treatment approaches, new strategies are needed for addressing pediatric PNES that utilize novel treatment targets. This study will evaluate a treatment for a common and serious pediatric health condition for which there are no established therapies and assess important targets mediating that effect.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Ribonucleotides are being constantly incorporated into the genome by eukaryotic DNA polymerases. This project will investigate the processing of these genomic ribonucleotides by topoisomerase 1 (Top1) and the possible ramifications of this Top1 activity for transcription by introducing a novel mechanism for DNA supercoil relaxation by Top1. Our proposal will also provide insight into the mechanism of PARP1 regulation of genomic ribonucleotide excision by Top1, which will help us understand the way human cells respond to the lesions that arise from Top1 cleavage of genomic ribonucleotides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Liver injury due to medication or herbal and dietary supplement use is an important medical, scientific, and public health problem in the US. Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) is the most common reason for non-approval, withdrawal, and clinical monitoring by the FDA. Understanding the dynamics of this medical problem and determining its clinical and genetic determinants will ultimately allow safer medications to be prescribed to patient populations and safer supplement on the market.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Our R25 program seeks to prepare physicians for independent and competitive research by developing researchers who can combine the clinical expertise obtained during residency with a well developed and focused investigative research program. The CHB/BIDMC residency program combines both adult and child neurology within an environment that has great breadth and depth in basic and clinical neuroscience. Mentors chosen for the R25 include leading NIH funded basic cellular and molecular neuroscientists, as well as successful physician scientists actively engaged in clinical and basic neuroscience and experienced in, and eager to train physician scientists.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) Patients with pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs) often have few symptoms before tumors have metastasized, hence most patients are diagnosed with late-stage disease for which there are few effective therapies. The incidence of pNETs increases yearly, but the development of newer and more effective therapies is still limited by our understanding of the biology of pNET tumorigenesis and progression. Modulation of the Notch2 signaling pathway is a promising approach for treating pNETs, and further characterization of the role of the Notch2 pathway in pNETs may deepen our understanding of NETs while facilitating the development of novel therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Muscle stem cell exhaustion is one of the hallmarks of aging and leads to gradual impairment of tissue structure and function. However, the molecular mechanisms that are linked to the aging process and that contribute to stem cell exhausting have not been defined. The main focus of this proposal is to examine how increases in DNA damage (another of the hallmarks of aging) might lead to MuSC exhaustion, and to explore how the molecular mechanisms that normally limit DNA damage could be enhanced to preserved youthful MuSC structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Lysosomal dysfunction initiates a pathogenic cascade that results in relentless neurodegeneration and premature death in neuronopathic lysosomal storage disorders. This RM1 Grant Application investigates the mechanisms and players that drive disease as a result of lysosomal dysfunction. This work holds the promise of identifying novel targets to promote brain health, combat neurodegeneration in neuronopathic lysosomal storage disorders, and halt or delay disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose an innovative adjuvant approach to surgical treatment of contaminated high-energy open fractures using topical photodynamic therapy (PDT) to reduce the bacterial bioburden at the site of a contaminated open fracture. The scientific premise of this project is based on our preliminary research demonstrating that PDT is extremely effective at eradicating mature biofilm on metallic implants, beyond the efficacy of currently utilized adjuvant treatment modalities. In the proposed study we will optimize the formulation, light dose and timing of PDT, determine the efficacy of PDT on two different fracture stabilization strategies and develop and assess the efficacy of repeat PDT administration through a surgically placed extraosseous catheter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Radiation therapy plays an integral role in treating human head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. However, head and neck radiation therapy is associated with significant toxicity in the oral mucosa, termed radiation-induced oral mucositis. The overall goal of this project aims to develop novel therapeutic strategies that will prevent or reduce radiation-induced oral mucositis by transiently enhancing p53-mediated signaling in response to acute DNA damage in normal oral mucosa.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is imperative to understand the underlying sources of the large health disparities among individuals from different racial and ethnic groups living in the United States. Complex relationships between genetics, individual behavior, socioeconomic status and the environment influence health. The goal of the CAST (Center for Admixture Science and Technology) program is to improve the utility of genome science for all populations living in the United States.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research in the first phase of this proposal is to investigate a new methodology to capture and define a novel ultrashort circulating tumor DNA species in the plasma of lung cancer patients. In the second phase, the usage of various other molecules additional to the ultrashort DNA species in biofluids will be explored in hopes to detect multiple cancer types with liquid biopsy. These findings will contribute to improved clinical outcomes for cancer patients by leading to the development of new liquid biopsy approaches for improved detection and treatment monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a progressive lung disease which can lead to respiratory failure and potential death. LAM has been treated with drugs targeting the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway however there are alternative pathways important in the pathogenesis of the disease. Therefore, this proposal will further delineate the role of the HMGA2 pathway in the disease of LAM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Apparent treatment resistant hypertension (aTRH) describes a subset of hypertensive individuals with elevated blood pressure despite use of multiple antihypertensive medications, and is associated with very poor long- term prognosis. Currently, there is no conclusive way to identify hypertension patients who will ultimately develop aTRH, or determine which patients will experience the adverse cardiovascular outcomes associated with hypertension. This project will identify hypertension subpopulations and characteristics associated with aTRH and adverse cardiovascular outcomes, and evaluate prediction of aTRH and adverse cardiovascular outcomes by geographic regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic diabetic wounds such as diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) are one of the major clinical complications in patients with diabetes and incur substantial and rapidly growing clinical and economic burdens in aging societies around the world. During the prior development (Phase I-equivalent), the collaborative team developed and evaluated a proof-of-concept prototype of a strain-programmed bioadhesive patch for accelerated diabetic wound healing. In the proposed project, we will continue optimization and validation of the strain-programmed patch based on pre- clinical and GLP testing in compliance with FDA regulatory guidance toward the FDA IDE approval in advance of a pivotal clinical trial for the ultimate regulatory clearance and commercialization.

PHR: Narrative Adolescent suicide has been linked with sleep disruptions. Adolescent social media use has been tied to both sleep and mental health difficulties. The present research examines how social messaging may serve to structure adolescent diurnal rhythms and impact later suicidal thoughts and behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recruitment and retention of women and underrepresented minorities into academic gastroenterology (GI) has been a major challenge for decades. NIDDK has supported efforts by the American Gastroenterology Association (AGA) from 2012 through 2023 through the R25 mechanism. I have been involved in these efforts for decades at the local (UCSD) and national levels. The latest of these R25 DK118761 AGA - Fostering Opportunities Resulting in Workforce and Research Diversity (FORWARD) provides a structured mentoring program for junior GI faculty. The program has provided structured mentoring to 20 junior academic GI’s and has received an excellent score for the next 5-year cycle renewal. I have been involved in these efforts for decades at the local (UCSD) and national levels. This award will provide dedicated salary support to allow this investigator to reallocate effort to these diversity initiatives both at UCSD and with the AGA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Having “the talk”—discussing racism and buffering children from racist experiences, is a task  shouldered by families of color; seldom do White parents have “the talk” with their children—critical and honest  conversations about race and racism, and the role that they have in remedying the pervasive legacy of racism  and eliminating discrimination and prejudice. This study focuses on the role that families can have in  addressing racism, an important yet under-leveraged point of intervention, and tests the efficacy of a multi module app in promoting productive, color-conscious, and anti-racism conversations between parents and their  children. It is hypothesized that the app-based “Color Brave” intervention we propose will reduce racial bias  and the perpetration of racism, and promote support for restorative societal policies—all of which are important  to address racial inequities in health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will have adequate power and collaborative input to determine the best pharmacological therapy for NOWS, comparing morphine, methadone, and buprenorphine in a head to head trial for the first time. This site, by virtue of its large diverse, rural population, its previous research experience in NOWS, opioid use, pk/pd modeling, and implementation science, and support from the Translational Research Institute and CTSA, is well positioned to become an active member of this collaborative effort. This site will advance NIH's mission to effectively and safely treat NOWS and participate in all aspects of this important comparative effectiveness trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our group seeks to understand why and how some patients, even after being ‘healed’ and discharged from the hospital, continue to suffer poor health and a high rate of long-term death. Our characterization of how the mitochondrion restructures itself as an adaptive mechanism to mitigate the acute insult and ‘learn’ so as to protect the cell against any future environmental threat may provide a biological explanation for the elevated long-term death experienced by our patients. Together our results will provide foundational knowledge to support the development of innovative diagnostic tools and novel biologic therapeutics that compliment contemporary sepsis care to improve survival. In doing so we will address one of the most pressing needs in the care of septic patients.

PHR: Peripheral sensory neurons play important roles in the function and dysfunction of pancreatic insulin-producing β cells. The proposed project aims at elucidating the  molecular basis of sensory neuromodulation of β cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Ria Treatment Platform is an innovative model for personalized alcohol use disorder treatment using telemedicine that includes anti- craving medications that are managed by expert physicians and nurse practitioners with psychosocial treatment delivered by recovery coaches. The RTP technology system collects objective measures of drinking behavior with breathalyzers synced to our smartphone app and integrates group and peer support within a HIPAA-compliant environment. This project will build upon this successful technology by 1) identifying prospective patients by reviewing medical records for evidence of possible liver injury from alcohol and 2) conducting the first randomized clinical trial of the Ria Treatment Platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Immunogenomic variation plays a pervasive role across organ systems and is implicated in myriad conditions, including adverse drug reactions and infectious, oncologic, cardiovascular, and neurologic diseases. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it has the potential to accelerate genomic research on the biology of disease and create a model by which future researchers investigate the impact of immunogenomic variation. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH mission that pertains to reducing the public health burden of a wide variety of disease and adverse drug reactions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)—which affects 3% of children and adolescents—is a severe mental illness that causes people to eat an insufficient volume or variety of food and puts them at risk for medical and psychological compromise. There is currently no evidence-based treatment, but cognitive- behavioral therapy for ARFID (CBT-AR) is a promising new intervention that reduces food avoidance by targeting (1) the maladaptive thoughts that prevent trying new foods, and (2) hyperactivity of brain regions involved in fear processing. In the current study we will conduct two randomized controlled trials to ensure that CBT-AR engages one or both of these critical targets and that it substantially reduces food avoidance by doing so.

PHR: Narrative The PI3K/Akt signaling is one of most important oncogenic events in human cancers, which regulates many aspects of biological functions including cell proliferation, survival, and metabolism important for cancer initiation and progression. The objectives of this study are to dissect the upstream regulatory mechanisms by which growth factors activate and recruit SETDB1 and E3 ligases TRAF6 to elicit Akt methylation and subsequent K63-linked ubiquitination, to understand how Akt ubiquitination triggers Akt membrane recruitment and activation, and to explore these regulatory mechanisms and its targeting in oncogenic processes. Our study represents a highly innovative and paradigm-shift proposal that will not only open up a new avenue for PI3K/Akt signaling regulation, but also offer new concepts and strategies for cancer targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this project is to develop a revolutionary, new generation of implantable neurodevices that will communicate with, learn from, and teach their human hosts to better treat disease. Current implantable devices are blind to human actions, thoughts and behavior, which limits their effectiveness. State of the art computer techniques that can measure behavior and link them to brain activity will empower patients to teach, control and learn from their devices to improve health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The prevalence and incidence of cardiometabolic diseases are increasing worldwide, contributing to high levels of morbidity and mortality. In this study we investigate pleiotropy and construct polygenic risk scores across cardiometabolic disorders, in diverse ancestry populations. This research will lead to a better understanding of the transferability of polygenic risk scores from discovery to target populations of different ethnicities, inform prevention and diagnostic strategies that could contribute to the development of effective public health policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our interdisciplinary team of urogynecologists, clinical psychologists, physical therapists, epidemiologists, and experts in community-health and disparities submit this application, which is an ideal response to NIDDK’s RFA for Stimulation Urologic Interdisciplinary Team Opportunity Research (SUITOR). This proposal will lead to improved treatment of urinary incontinence and lower urinary tract symptoms (common, embarrassing, costly and under-treated disorders) in minority women who face significant barriers to care and have been systematically left behind with respect to evidence-based non-surgical approaches to urinary incontinence. Given barriers to accessing physical therapy and the behavioral and mental health impacts of urinary incontinence, this project will evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a culturally-specific, home- based, online, community health-worker supported, conservative intervention for urinary incontinence. We hypothesize that improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms of women receiving SUPPORT therapy will be non-inferior to those receiving the gold-standard treatment of in-person physical therapy and will lead to improved mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to understand how cells build a molecular “recycling center” called the proteasome. Alterations to the assembly of the proteasome cause or exacerbate many human diseases, including some cancers and many neurodegenerative disorders. Understanding how proteasomes are assembled will help us to design new treatments for these diseases that work by restoring normal protein recycling.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is at the heart of the opioid epidemic and back pain is the most common condition leading to chronic pain. Improving back pain management and reducing disparities are important considerations in reducing the opioid crisis and improving the lives of impacted individuals. The goal of this project to identify effective strategies for providing nonpharmacologic alternatives to opioid pain management for patients with back pain in low income and rural communities using telehealth solutions.

PHR: Body schema, i.e the body’s configurations and positions in 3D space, is critical for self- awareness and for motor control. Yet how the brain generates and updates such representation remain largely unknown. This research will not only solve this fundamental neuroscience mystery, but also provide insights into body schema representation deficits observed in many neurological diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Older people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) have greater walking impairment and faster functional decline than those without PAD. Yet few therapies have been identified that improve disability in people with PAD. This randomized clinical trial will determine whether beetroot juice, which increases nitric oxide in lower extremity arteries and skeletal muscle, significantly improves walking impairment and/or prevents walking decline in older people with PAD, compared to placebo.

PHR: Project Narrative Despite the emergence of new antiepileptic drug options, there is a consistent proportion of epilepsy patients that remain drug-resistant. This proposal takes an innovative approach by studying the role of the gut microbiota and its metabolites on seizure occurrence and neuronal physiology. We will examine a microbial-derived metabolite as a key factor in seizure development, which will provide a basis for investigating its role as a therapeutic target in epilepsy.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will develop novel methods to pinpoint the genetic variant sets associated with the disease. Compared with the existing method, the methods will have a higher power and can be easily customized to various special needs such as preserving data privacy, incorporating functional annotations, and adjusting for varying ancestry loadings for admixed populations. A successful completion of the proposal will lead to both rigorous methodology foundation and useful statistical and computational tools to identify and visualize disease-associated variants.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This K26 Midcareer Investigator Award expands the candidate’s ability to provide excellent mentoring in behavioral diabetes prevention research to diverse early career researchers. Within the context of intensive ongoing research, the award supports comprehensive mentor training and mentee training in health behaviors for diabetes prevention, health equity, maternal health, and implementation science, leveraging unique UC Davis resources and a transdisciplinary team science approach. These activities support the long-term objective of diversifying the research workforce dedicated to diabetes prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The primary goal of the proposed research to investigate the genetic and environmental architecture of cardiometabolic traits across ethnic groups in the All of Us cohort. Both genetics and environment influence disparities in cardiometabolic health span and disease, thus, understanding differences between ethnic groups will be essential to realize precision medicine goals. We will implement software workflows into the All of Us Researcher Workbench to accomplish the research and make them available to the broader community.

PHR: The DPPOS AD/ADRD project will address the overarching question: What are the determinants and the nature of cognitive impairment among persons with pre-diabetes (PreD) and type 2 diabetes (T2D), who are a high-risk group for cognitive impairment and represent a large fraction of the United States (US) population? This U19 proposal addresses the National Alzheimer’s Project Act goal to “prevent, halt, or reverse AD” in the high-risk group of persons with pre-diabetes and type 2 diabetes, who represent over half of the population aged 60 years and older in the US.

PHR: Narrative Increasing evidence supports that neurodegeneration resulting in the onset of Alzheimer’s Disease could be linked to imbalances in the diversity and composition of microbes in the gut. This imbalance, or dysbiosis, has been shown to be linked to neuroinflammation resulting in neurodegeneration and impaired cognition. We propose the first study linking human and preclinical models for gut-brain axis using ultrahigh field 7 Tesla multi- modal magnetic resonance imaging with a mechanistic and interventional study design to enhance our understanding of gut-brain interactions underlying neurodegeneration in AD and pave the way for future disease- modifying interventions for AD via microbiome-gut-brain axis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Despite the allure of cancer precision medicine, at present most patients do not benefit from this approach. Only a minority of patients receive therapy that is guided by the molecular features of their tumor. This research proposal aims to open the scientific bottlenecks that currently limit the utility of cancer precision medicine.

PHR: The proposed project will provide a mentorship to predoctoral and postdoctoral scholars from diverse backgrounds who are conducting research within the mission of NIDDK. The PI will provide theory-driven and evidence-based interventions that target scientific self-efficacy and identity to increase perseverance to achieve a career as a researcher. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viral pandemics (e.g., Spanish flu, H1N1/influenza, and COVID-19) have taken a huge toll on human health and welfare. Organ injury and death from viral infections are increasingly recognized to result from an imbalance in the host immune response as well as tissue damage caused by the virus. The proposed studies will employ preclinical models to test a new therapeutic that that uses a novel mechanism to rebalance the host immune response as well as protect tissue from virus-induced damage. It has the potential to prevent deaths from COVID-19, regardless of evolving viral variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to plan for a multi-center randomized controlled trial (M-RCT) to test the effectiveness of novel gluten detection technologies as an adjunct to telemedicine to manage celiac disease in newly diagnosed adults. If successful, the proposed intervention will improve mucosal recovery, promote a shift in current practice of celiac disease management toward long-term monitoring, and represent a significant step toward reducing the severe physical and psychological consequences of celiac disease.

PHR: Project Narrative As the number of rare disorders grow each year, the need for new treatments, approaches, and understanding continues to expand. This program has a five-year track record of successfully increasing early career clinical researcher’s intent to remain in research. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroblastoma is an aggressive pediatric cancer with a poor prognosis despite an intensive multimodal treatment regimen. This proposal aims to advance an experimental immunotherapeutic nanomedicine toward clinical translation through optimization of physiochemical and biological properties, rigorous preclinical evaluation in animal models of neuroblastoma, and optimization of combination immunoregimens.

PHR: Project Narrative (NIH) We propose the Hallmarks of Aging are mediated and coordinated by the branches of methionine metabolism: the methionine cycle, the transsulfuration pathway and the polyamine/salvage pathway. Nutrient sensing, itself a Hallmark of Aging, strongly impacts methionine metabolism through signaling from the insulin/IGF receptor. We will use novel mutants of the Drosophila insulin receptor to dissect how methionine metabolism integrates the Hallmarks of Aging.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal requests competitive continuation funding for renewal of a postdoctoral Ruth L. Kirschstein National Research Service Award Institutional Research Training Program (T32) at UCLA for 5 years for the funding of 6 postdoctoral positions per year. The focus of the training program is on training researchers in the area of clinical translational intervention science for child mental disorders to prepare them to become independent transdisciplinary investigators. During the 2-year training period, postdoctoral researchers will mentored independent research under the mentorship of a primary and secondary mentor, develop core competencies for clinical research, receive formal didactic and experiential training in a designated area of research, as well as training in ethical issues in research and the responsible conduct of research involving children and families.
PROJECT_TERMS: Child Mental Health;Science;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training the Science of Child Mental Health Treatment

PHR: NARRATIVE While nine hallmarks of the aging process have been described to date, little is known about their interconnectivity and the hierarchies governing these interactions. Our proposal aims to develop and utilize cellular therapy as both a somatic tool to dissect the spatial and temporal hierarchies as well as a potential therapeutic for the treatment of age-related diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor and Group 3 medulloblastoma is the most aggressive form of this disease, which is mostly refractory to immunotherapies. This project will dissect the crosstalks between tumor and tumor microenviorment and the mechansims of immune evasion in Group 3 medulloblsatoma. We will also investigate cellular therapy strategies that will circumvent tumor-mediated immunosuppressive mechanisms and reinvigorate anti-tumor immunity in this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: SOCIETY FOR THE ADV CHICANOS/NATIVE AMER
PHR: Narrative SACNAS, the Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science, is an inclusive, multi-disciplinary and multicultural organization with a 45+ year history of interventions toward enhancing Underrepresented Minority (URM) participation in STEM fields. The National Diversity in STEM Conference (Conference) aims at increasing preparedness of the scientific workforce by delivering a vanguard scientific program, provide a framework for research presentations, enable trans-disciplinary discussions, provide mentoring opportunities, and promote professional development of URMs in biomedically-focused and behaviorally-related STEM fields. The Conference will also encourage panel discussions on how we can best integrate and diversify biomedical research, paying particular attention to be inclusive of those most underserved and underrepresented (e.g. Native Americans).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Underrepresented early career investigators need the opportunity to gain research knowledge coupled with quality mentorship to assist with the proper application of those skills, resulting in innovative and meaningful research. In addition to providing mentorship on research skills, it is also important to understand the circumstances, in which early career investigators have found themselves and work to develop needed soft (non- research) skills. Taken together, my philosophy as a mentor is to provide experiences for early career investigators, especially from underrepresented groups, that will help them develop into well-rounded individuals who contribute to advancing science as well as be demonstrative of reputable citizens in academe.

PHR: NARRATIVE Contemporary research in visual sciences requires access to modern quantitative and analytical technologies, the use of a variety of complex animal models, and state-of-the-art imaging. This Vision Science Core proposal encompasses all of these requirements to augment the already exceptional research capabilities of investigators at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. A fundamental difference in this revised application is the expansion of our quantitative molecular biology core to include access to the “Omics” facilities that are operated by the UW campus. Our plan is to provide Core users with a subsidy to facilitate their use of these facilities, which includes modern high-throughput and multi-plexing sequencing technologies, mass spectroscopy (including lipidomics and metabolomics), and proteomics. Additionally, the core itself has added laser-capture microdissection instrumentation and plans to acquire a SeaHorse XF analyzer to augment these capabilities. The imaging core retains its services for top-tier histopathology, while including access to high resolution confocal and live-cell imaging and conventional electron microscopy. Additionally, this core has added access to a new serial block face scanning electron microscopic facility that is co-directed by Dr. Mrinalini Hoon who is also a co-director of this part of our core application. Lastly, we retain our animal model core to provide world class expertise and access to the variety of complex animal models and ex vivo systems, ranging from rodents to non-human primates, that are essential to translational discovery in vision research. As a new initiative, this core is also the center of a new biobank of human ocular tissue and fluids that is being cataloged, stored, and made available to core users for research projects.

PHR: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE NARRATIVE The goals of the Administrative Core are to provide for the smooth operation of the various cores to ensure that users receive timely and appropriate services from the Vision Research Core, to insure that users with qualifying NEI R01 grants receive priority service, to assist others carrying out vision related research, to assist vision researchers in developing preliminary data to support new applications, to enable user access to equipment in the core, to facilitate user access to other campus entities that support research (e.g. Biotechnology Center), and to adjudicate any potential disputes as to the quality and availability of services.

PHR: CORE 1: OCULAR OMICS AND QUANTITATIVE MOLECULAR BIOLOGY NARRATIVE The goal of Core 1 is to provide the following services to users with qualifying grants and other vision researchers. The quantitative molecular biology services include providing consultation for and access to quantitative PCR, access to plate readers for quantitation of antibodies, cytokines, and other analytes, access to spectrophotometers and a bionalazyer for RNA, DNA and protein samples, a laser microdissection system to obtain material from tissue sections for transcriptomics, metabolomics, or proteomics analysis, allelic characterization of normal and genetically modified mice, nucleic acid probe design, in situ hybridization, quantitative reporter gene analysis. This core will also facilitate use of campus resources such as the Biotechnology Center (NextGen Sequencing, RNAseq, data handling and analysis, proteomics, etc.) and the Flow Cytometry Facility.
