PHR: CORE 2: PATHOLOGY AND IMAGING NARRATIVE The goal of the Pathology and Imaging core is to enable investigators to obtain state-of-the art imaging procedures to meet their research goals. Specifically, the module (1) provides tissue processing services for both light and electron microscopy, (2) provides access to state-of-the art imaging equipment located in institutional core facilities and in our Cores, (3) maintains image acquisition instruments and (4) trains eye and vision researchers on how to use and develop novel imaging technologies for their individual and collaborative research programs. It is also responsible for the collection and maintenance of tissue specimens and cell lines.

PHR: CORE 3: ANIMAL MODELS AND EYE ORGAN CULTURE NARRATIVE The goal of the Animal Models and Eye Organ Culture Core is to facilitate the use of animals and eye organ culture to study visual function and visual diseases by qualifying NEI funded researchers. We also assist non- qualifying investigators in generating preliminary data, in support of proposals seeking NIH funding. This is accomplished by providing expertise in complementary animal models across a range of species from rodents to non-human primates (NHPs) and including spontaneous and experimental models of glaucoma, retinal degeneration, ocular vascular disease ocular pharmacology and toxicology and infectious diseases and includes animal handling and anesthesia and, importantly, provision of alternatives to live animal research including eye organ culture. We provide expertise and equipment necessary for the evaluation of visual system structure and function including ERG, multifocal and pattern ERG, VEP, OCT, retinal imaging, tonometry and outflow facility and outflow pathway determination. As a result of unique expertise and access to model species spanning the translational spectrum, this core has had a broad impact, facilitating interdisciplinary and inter-institutional vision research in support of the NEI’s mission.

PHR: This Career Development Award (CDA)-2 proposal will offer comprehensive training in psychiatric genetics for Dr. Peter Na to advance his research skills to become an independent VA researcher. The proposed research project will investigate environmental (e.g., adverse childhood experiences), and psychosocial (e.g., purpose in life, social support) (EP) factors that moderate the genetic liability for substance use disorders (SUDs) in Veterans using polygenic risk scores derived from large genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Further, the proposed study will advance our understanding of the biopsychosocial etiology of SUDs using cutting-edge genetic research methodologies such as epigenetic, gene enrichment and drug-repositioning analyses. The moderating EP factors identified in the study will elucidate targets for clinical interventions to prevent and treat SUDs in Veterans and ultimately help guide VHA clinical practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Title: Correlative cryoET of the HIV-1 integration targeting in native T-lymphocytes Project Narrative HIV-1 infection remains a global health concern. While the past 30 years have seen a dramatic increase in the life expectancy of individuals living with HIV, however, there is still no reliable treatment to eradicate HIV-1 from its human host and no vaccine to protect the society from new infections. One of the reasons underlying the persistence of HIV-1 is its permanent integration into the host’s genome, where the structure of chromatin plays a pivotal role. Understanding chromatin architecture of HIV-1 integration targeting and the interplay between HIV-1 and host chromatin hold the promise of informing strategies to disrupt latent infections and aid in the development of innovative therapies targeting the viral-host interface.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The project proposes to develop an HIV risk prediction model (ACTION-HIV algorithm) that can detect women with a higher risk of HIV and translate the ACTION-HIV algorithm into a clinical decision support (CDS) platform integrated into an electronic health record (EHR) system to assess its feasibility, acceptability, and usability. This is a major step toward overcoming the gaps in existing HIV risk prediction algorithms and helping providers identify women for HIV testing and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). Our innovative EHR- based CDS tool is relevant to public health as it can have a potentially significant impact on increasing HIV testing, reducing sex disparity in PrEP uptake, and decreasing new HIV infection in Florida.

PHR: NARRATIVE One major goal of human genetics is to understand the functional consequences of the various genetic and chromosomal variation that exists within a population. Telomeres are crucial chromosomal structures that protect chromosome ends from instability and length of the telomere can highly vary between individuals in many organisms, including humans. This proposal uses plants as a tractable model to uncover the molecular function and evolutionary significance of telomere length variation within populations.

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative This mixed-methods sequential exploratory/developmental study, which is guided by the NIMHD research framework adapted for sexual and gender minority health research, is relevant to public health for several reasons. The study will (a) describe how social ecological factors facilitate or impede sexual risk, HIV testing, and PrEP use among Latino/x sexual minority men (SMM) migrants, (b) investigate the role of social integration factors (immigration status, length of time in the U.S., language use, social connections, healthcare access and utilization) in the association between social ecological factors and sexual risk, HIV testing, and PrEP use among Latino/x SMM migrants, and (c) illustrate sexual risk, HIV testing, and PrEP decision-making processes as it relates to PrEP use disparities among Latino/x SMM migrants. This research will further establish the empirical foundation for future research with this exceptionally vulnerable subgroup of Latino/x, SMM, and migrant populations; that is, a longitudinal examination of PrEP uptake and promotion.

PHR: NARRATIVE This study will enhance our understanding of the utilization of multiple evidence-based approaches for HIV risk reduction among rural people who inject drugs (PWID) and afford new insights about how to best meet HIV prevention needs. Our study will fill an important gap in the scientific literature as we will examine how complex patterns of initiation and sustained utilization of multiple risk reduction strategies are associated with network characteristics and change over time. This study will inform the adaptation of an evidence-based intervention for reducing HIV risks among PWID to a rural context.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A substantial proportion of people with HIV experience cognitive impairment, despite effective multi-drug regimens targeting viral replication. This study will use DNA methylation profiling, magnetic resonance imaging, and machine learning methodology to investigate whether HIV infection and resulting cognitive impairment are associated with accelerated biological aging both in the epigenome and in the structure of the brain. This approach will help to clarify the mechanisms underlying cognitive impairment in people with HIV and may lead to better prognosis and clinical care for at-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Effective diagnosis and treatment of substance use disorders in people living with HIV is a critical public health issue as these disorders are disproportionately prevalent in this vulnerable population, enhancing HIV neuropathogenesis and promoting behaviors that spread HIV. The cause of the change in neuropathogenesis is not clear, but we hypothesize that addictive substances enhance HIV neuropathogenesis by increasing dopamine, which drives inflammation in macrophages. In this F30, we will address this hypothesis by defining the mechanisms driving dopamine mediated inflammation in macrophages, which will give the candidate, Ms. Breana Channer, a comprehensive set of technical and professional skills that provide a robust foundation on which to prepare for a career as an independent physician scientist studying the neuroimmunology of HIV.

PHR: Program Narrative Nearly 5000 new HIV infection occur per day, and the epidemic negatively impacting the most vulnerable populations resulting in health inequities, there remains a critical need to train investigators who are prepared to conduct primary and secondary prevention research in HIV. Our proposed Training Program will continue to provide the strongest foundation of knowledge, skills, professional networking and experience to young investigators at the pre- and post-doctoral levels, who can establish and sustain careers as scientific investigators, contributing to advances in HIV prevention, specifically, and health equity, in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NO CHANGES FROM ORIGINALLY AWARDED APPLICATION  PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with hearing loss who use cochlear implants (CIs) show significant deficits and strong unexplained intersubject variability in their perception and production of spoken emotions in speech. This project will investigate the hypothesis that "cue-weighting", or how patients utilize the different acoustic cues to emotion, accounts for significant variance in emotional communication with CIs. The results will focus on children with CIs, but parallel measures in postlingually deaf adults with CIs will be made, ensuring that results of these studies benefit social communication by Cl patients across the lifespan by informing the development of technological innovations and improved clinical protocols.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perinatal depression is a barrier to sustained engagement in HIV care for women living with HIV (WLHIV) during the perinatal period, yet few interventions exist to address both mental health and engagement in HIV care outcomes. Building on our pilot trial, we will test in a randomized controlled trial the Enhanced Friendship Bench intervention, versus usual care, to improve perinatal depression and engagement in HIV care outcomes for WLHIV, as well as infant HIV, health, and developmental outcomes. Completion of the proposed project has strong potential to lead to a culturally appropriate, scalable counseling intervention to improve PND and engagement in HIV care outcomes for WLHIV that is poised for rapid translation into practice.

ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Veteran access to an assessment of day-to-day function is vital to enable aging-in-place, especially for Veterans with dementia who experience progressive functional decline that necessitates caregiver assistance. While early assessment of Veteran day-to-day function is critical to mitigate the functional losses due to dementia, Veterans with dementia face barriers to a functional assessment due to rurality or difficulty traveling to the clinic. Though video telehealth increases access to care, video has not been used to observe daily life tasks, such as tooth-brushing or medication management, particularly for Veterans with dementia. This project will develop and pilot test an assessment of Veteran day-to-day function adapted for VA Video Connect (VVC). Increasing Veteran access to functional assessment allows clinicians to identify Veteran functional deficits and related need for caregiver assistance, thereby minimizing the cascading effects of dementia and disability- related deficits to Veterans, caregivers, and VHA, while fulfilling Veterans’ wish to age-in-place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to understand how cellular lipid biology can control HIV entry. It uses molecular dynamics simulation coupled closely to experimental validation to design nonreplicating HIV mutants that have altered dependence on cellular lipids. A molecular and functional understanding of how HIV proteins interact with these lipids will help design new interventions that could reduce HIV infection.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is a powerful technique used to non-invasively identify metabolites and to examine the three-dimensional structure, dynamics, and interactions of proteins. PHR: Every year ~3000-3500 veterans are diagnosed with chronic kidney disease (CKD). In many of these affected individuals there is progressive kidney fibrosis leading to end stage organ failure and a need for dialysis and transplantation. Currently, more than 10,000 veterans are receiving dialysis in the VA health care system. Glomerular diseases, such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) are a frequent cause of kidney failure. In addition, CKD is a major risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Low nephron number due to congenital renal hypo/dysplasia, premature birth and intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) significantly increase the risk of glomerulosclerosis, CKD and HTN. These conditions disproportionately affect African Americans, a group that is highly represented among veterans. The proposed research is relevant to public health and to the mission of the VA because the information learned from these studies is expected to provide novel mechanistic insights into FSGS that may lead to therapeutic interventions to prevent the disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Narrative: As individuals with HIV live longer due to antiretroviral therapies' success, the prevalence of cognitive and motor deficits in the infected population is increasing. Astrocytes play a key role in maintaining most CNS functions in physiological conditions, but their importance in the pathogenesis of NeuroHIV has not been well characterized and remains controversial. However, our group demonstrated that glial viral reservoirs use gap junctions (GJ) and hemichannels (HC) to spread toxicity into neighboring uninfected cells despite their low numbers and minimal to undetectable viral replication.

PHR: This project will examine how HIV and age influence the immunogenicity of pneumonia vaccines (how well the immune system is stimulated by these vaccines) with the goal of determining whether specialized approaches are needed to vaccinate individuals living with HIV in advancing age who are on anti-retroviral treatment. It will further examine whether chronic inflammation in persons living with HIV is associated with impaired vaccine responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antiretroviral therapies have transformed HIV into a manageable chronic condition but are burdensome and do not cure infection, in part because HIV integrates into the human genome as reactivatable proviruses. In some individuals, however, only proviruses integrated into deeply inactive parts of the genome remain – potentially representing a form of cure. This proposal will study and seek to enhance the ability of the cytotoxic (CD8) T-cell arm of the immune system to eliminate all but the most dormant proviruses and thus provide guidance to therapeutic approaches to curing infection.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunctional T cells and persistent viral reservoirs are leading causes of failure to HIV/SIV cure. A system to reliably study early T cell generation and their infection is lacking. The proposed work will establish an innovative organoid system in the SIV/NHP model to study T cell generation, infection, and reservoir establishment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is a major health problem among person living with HIV. Despite clinical guidelines recommend HIV clinicians address cardiovascular risk among their patients, this recommendation has not been widely adopted. Using implementation research, community engagement, and computer modeling methods, we will identify strategies to improve adoption of hypertension care guidelines among HIV clinicians.

PHR: NARRATIVE There are now two forms of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) available (oral PrEP and long-acting injectable cabotegravir; CAB-LA), requiring TW patients and PrEP service providers (e.g., navigators, nurses, physicians) to work together to choose between these products. The intentional and informed use of digital tools can enhance clinical communication and shared decision-making; yet few digital shared decision-making tools (SDMT) tailored to TW exist, and none are PrEP-focused. The proposed study builds on formative work by further developing and pilot testing our existing prototype of a PrEP-focused bilingual (English/Spanish) digital SDMT called, “WePrEP,” that is tailored to diverse TW and PrEP service providers and supports shared decision- making regarding selecting an appropriate PrEP method and reviewing corresponding adherence strategies.

PHR: Narrative This study explores strategies to promote linkages to HIV care following an HIV self-test (HIVST) for Tanzanian heterosexual men who are shown to test less frequently than women and are less likely seek follow-up care following a self-test. Similar studies have shown that community-based care, including the provision of PrEP and ART, can help mitigate the various barriers that heterosexual men in Sub-Saharan Africa face when seeking HIV care in a traditional facility-based setting. Exploring novel service-delivery settings for HIV care in Tanzania is critically important in the fight against HIV/AIDS in Sub-Saharan Africa, where there are an estimated 28.5 million people living with the disease.

PHR: Project Narrative: This R01 application aims to determine how exposure to HIV Tat and methamphetamine induce the astrocyte- specific inflammasome, NLRP6, and its role in PANoptosis-mediated neuroinflammation in NeuroHIV. Using in vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo approaches, this proposal will identify the novel molecular mechanism(s) involved in HIV Tat and methamphetamine in the context of activation of ZBP1/NLRP6-mediated PANoptosis and neuroinflammation. The goal is to identify novel therapeutic targets to alleviate neuroinflammation associated with NeuroHIV, and the outcome of this study will set the stage for developing novel therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a chronic, debilitating health problem that affects 4.7% of adults in the US and has a total economic cost of $232.2 billion, annually. Despite the existence of effective treatments, many patients do not receive treatment due to barriers such as time, cost, or limited access to qualified therapists. To reduce these barriers, we will develop and test a digital therapeutic (i.e., a mobile app that delivers a health intervention) that utilizes empirically-supported cognitive-behavioral techniques to treat adults with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our results show that the cellular protease ADAM10 is taken up into HIV-1 particles, cleaves viral proteins required to enter a new target cell, and inhibits the propagation of HIV-1. Our application proposes an in-depth investigation of the mechanism by which ADAM10 impairs the spreading of HIV-1, and of how HIV-1 has adapted to minimize its inhibition by ADAM10. The proposed studies are relevant to public health, because they have the potential to identify a novel vulnerability that can be exploited to inactivate HIV-1.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Implementation research is needed to support further roll-out of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) as an umbrella HIV prevention strategy, yet long-acting injectable PrEP (LAI-PrEP) via intramuscular cabotegravir has unique implications for clinical practice that will not easily fit within implementation strategies for oral PrEP. In this study, we aim to identify determinants to LAI-PrEP roll-out, conduct consensus building with stakeholders to plan optimal strategies to support LAI-PrEP implementation, and pilot a cyclical Plan-Do-Study- Act implementation strategy within two outpatient clinics serving priority populations for HIV prevention. This proposal compliments current research supporting implementation of oral PrEP and will set the stage for larger scale implementation efforts to enhance prescription of LAI-PrEP.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This translational and multimodal imaging study uses magnetic resonance (MR) scans to obtain measures of GABA and glutamate in the hippocampus, as well as neuromelanin in the midbrain as an index of dopamine, to examine the inter-relatedness of these transmitter systems in medication-free patients with schizophrenia, compared to controls. This will represent a test in humans of the prominent view in the field derived from clinical and preclinical evidence, proposing that a deficit in GABA function in the hippocampus may lead to hippocampal glutamate excess, which in turn may dysregulate dopamine. If confirmed, this will provide a validated and integrated model of circuit dysfunction that can lead to new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hazardous alcohol use is prevalent among men living with HIV (MLWH) in Uganda and associated with non- adherence to antiretroviral therapy (ART) and detectable viral load, which is especially problematic in serodiscordant partnerships with pregnant partners as it threatens Uganda’s progress towards HIV elimination goals. Therefore, intervening on hazardous alcohol use among MLWH with serodiscordant pregnant partners is critical to both HIV prevention and treatment efforts. We apply the Exploration, Preparation, Implementation, Sustainment (EPIS) framework to guide adaptation of an intervention with strong preliminary efficacy reducing alcohol use and improving ART adherence among MLWH in Uganda for use specifically among MLWH with serodiscordant pregnant partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative: AIDS-associated cryptococcosis continues to ravage communities impacted by high HIV transmission rates, causing 15% of AIDS-associated mortality. Our work investigates the molecular mechanisms by which C. neoformans, among the millions of species of fungi, is able to adapt to the host environment, coping with the stresses it encounters. We have identified pathways required for agility in stress adaptation, and will investigate how they promote stress adaptation, cooperate with other pathways, and how conserved these responses are across diverse clinical isolates from people with AIDS-associated cryptococcosis as well as environmental isolates from the same region.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed project includes several short courses designed to complement and enhance the training of a new generation of the public health workforce in diverse career stages to gain strong understanding and skills in methods to advance the intersection of HIV prevention and gender and health justice. Focused on undergraduate students, MPH students, and community health workers, our project will build on the intellectual capital and infrastructure of the world-class University of California Center for Gender and Health Justice. PHR: Project Narrative People living with HIV infection have increased inflammation and risk of cardiovascular disease and metabolic disease. Abnormalities in the gastrointestinal tract and in the immune system can increase the risk of cardiovascular and metabolic disease. This proposal would enable the PI to advance research on metabolic and cardiovascular health in people with HIV and to train future physician scientists.

PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop and test a perinatal depression intervention using a couple-based approach that involves male partners to provide social support for depression and to prevent transmission of HIV to infants. Our goal is to demonstrate a proof-of-concept for the proposed intervention, which if shown to be feasible and acceptable, may have the potential to reduce depressive symptoms and ultimately, improve adherence to prevention-of-mother-to-child transmission of HIV outcomes for mothers and infants in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to quantify how traditional HIV therapy (ART) and antibodies against HIV (bnAbs) lose efficacy during treatment interruption in people with HIV, for bnAbs, distinguishing between antiviral and potential "vaccine"- like effects. The study will analyze ART levels in plasma, blood cells, and tissues as it relates to viral rebound and changes in reservoirs during ATI, and assess bnAb antiviral activity in human tonsil tissue cells. This research will guide the design of future HIV cure trials, providing essential insights into cure treatment efficacy with broader implications for HIV treatment and prevention.

PHR: Finding a cure for HIV/AIDS is challenging because we lack the tools to identify the cells that contain latent proviruses. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Impact: Noninvasive brain imaging using novel rosette trajectories-based 5D spectroscopic imaging and myelin imaging combined with compressed sensing reconstruction will provide improved knowledge of HIV neuropathogenesis in perinatally HIV-infected young adult survivors. Our approach will reduce the duration required for MR spectroscopic and myelin imaging to a clinically feasible scan time, which will allow the implementation of these novel tools for the assessment of neurofunction in perinatally HIV-infected young adult patients. By characterizing HIV neuropathogenesis to the brain as these youth age, interventions can be developed (such as change of antiretroviral medications) to improve neurologic function, prevent central nervous system deterioration, and improve quality of life. The same technology can be useful in the investigation of neuropathogenesis in other congenital infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. The induction of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) by vaccination is a global health priority as a means to prevent HIV infection, and the membrane proximal external region (MPER) of the HIV-1 envelope protein is a site of particular interest. Vaccine induction of bnAbs will likely require sequential immunization with additional immunogens designed to shepherd affinity maturation of the B cell receptor (BCR) to acquire neutralization breadth and potency. This project seeks to develop soluble and membrane-bound boost immunogens that present the MPER epitope in a more native-like context with the aim of maturing primed BCRs to acquire bnAb features.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Co-infection with Human Immunodeficiency Virus (4) and tuberculosis (TB) causes extensive mortality. Identifying the molecular mechanisms that drive progression to TB disease following HIV co-infection is critical for developing improved treatment strategies. Using our well-established and faithful nonhuman primate model, we propose to test our hypothesis that both TB as well as HIV infection result in the expression of deleterious pathways /production of deleterious metabolites for immunity, and that blocking these pathways can prevent disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This is a study to develop strategies and pilot test adding testing for and providing results for a blood biomarker of prior month alcohol consumption, phosphatidylethanol (PEth), to a standard brief intervention for unhealthy alcohol use. The brief intervention is being rolled out by the Uganda Ministry of Health (MOH) in HIV care, and the research will be conducted via focus group discussions with persons with HIV, HIV clinic staff, a community advisory board, meetings with MOH members, and field testing and pilot testing the protocols. We will determine the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of adding PEth results to alcohol brief interventions, and decide if a large scale trial is warranted.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By capitalizing on recent new insights into brain neurovascular coupling, the goal of this project is to establish and validate a transformative neuroimaging approach that quantifies non-invasively physiological metrics fundamental to brain function, such as oxygen availability, pH and carbon dioxide accumulation in tissue. The project represents a novel direction of research for Dr. Mangia, who will conduct pioneering studies using the proposed novel neuroimaging approach to explore an innovative conceptual framework linking loss of brain function to abnormal accumulations of metabolic waste products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Delivery of broadly neutralizing antibodies by viral vectors has the potential to a) mediate long-term protection against HIV acquisition and b) strongly and durably suppress HIV replication in infected individuals; both after a single vector administration. However, naturally preexisting antibodies to such viral vectors in the human population can compromise the applicability of this approach. In this project we propose a set of easy-to-apply approaches to overcome this critical issue and advance the use of the antibody/vector approach against HIV for human use.

PHR: Project Narrative Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and cocaine use disorders (CUDs) are persistent public health concerns within the United States and worldwide. Cocaine use can facilitate the pathophysiology of HIV and preclinical studies suggest that HIV may promote addiction-related behaviors, highlighting the unique biobehavioral interaction underlying the comorbidity of HIV and CUDs. This proposal will employ a cutting-edge combination of preclinical rodent modeling of HIV and CUDs along with quantitative cellular imaging and circuit-specific, closed-loop optogenetics to reveal corticolimbic circuit and neuroimmune contributions to HIV-induced dysregulation of reward-seeking behavior, which will further our understanding of the neurobehavioral underpinnings of comorbid HIV and CUDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Periodontal infection (periodontitis) causes loss of the alveolar bone anchoring the teeth and is common in people infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Antiretroviral therapy (ART) suppresses HIV replication, ameliorating HIV-disease severity; however, ART-induced immune recovery, is associated with an inflammatory reaction (immune reconstitution bone loss (IRBL)) that causes severe skeletal deterioration. Whether IRBL also degrades alveolar bone in the jaws, promoting tooth loss is unknown, and our studies will hence examine the effects of IRBL on the alveolar bone and the intersection of IRBL with periodontitis in people infected with HIV initiating ART, and in animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Finding a cure for HIV-1 is challenging since the virus can remain hidden and inactive (latent) inside CD4+ T- cells for years, meanwhile the immune system does not recognize that these cells as infected. Among HIV-1 research, several approaches have been used in combination with existing cART, yet People Living With HIV (PLWH) need to currently maintain life-long daily administration of combination antiretroviral drug therapy (cART) that suppress plasma viremia to undetectable levels, which does not eliminate the viral reservoir. Thus, a niche for new therapies is warranted to achieve an HIV-1 cure.

ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The Million Veteran Program (MVP) is the largest and most diverse biobank in the world, containing genetic and electronic health record (EHR) data for more than 650,000 Veterans. As a result, the MVP presents a unique opportunity to perform statistical genetic analyses that advance our understanding of biological mechanisms for serious mental illness (SMI) related traits. Nevertheless, a growing body of literature has demonstrated that genomic research is not equitable, in part due to sample size differences and heterogeneity in EHR data quality, obscuring our ability to identify new treatments for SMIs. This proposal mitigates disparities in genomic research by quantifying data quality heterogeneity and aggregating multiple related traits in the EHR to perform meta-analyses that boost power in detecting genetic risk factors for SMI related traits. Since Veterans with SMIs have increased mortality risks, this study is aimed at improving detection and identifying novel genetic targets for improving healthcare outcomes for Veterans from all backgrounds.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACT STATEMENT The co-occurrence of HIV infection and obesity has substantial implications for maternal and child health. Given the role of HIV stigma in HIV viral suppression and postpartum weight retention among women living with HIV, an integrated intervention approach is ideal for addressing these dual outcomes among a critical population, postpartum women. This study seeks to refine and test an integrated HIV treatment and postpartum weight retention intervention for postpartum women living with HIV.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The HIV/AIDS epidemic continues to be one of the world’s most serious public health challenges. Restrictions in population movements and suspensions in health services due to the COVID-19 pandemic caused widespread disruption to HIV service utilization in many HIV endemic settings, including South Africa. Using harmonized data from multiple national surveillance systems across South Africa, we will employ an agent- based modeling approach to establish applied methods for estimating disruptions in progress towards ending HIV/AIDS and identifying social and psychological factors that hypothetical interventions can target to alleviate individual-level risk factors for poor HIV prevention and care outcomes in the context of a disruptive event.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A majority of mental health care needs in Africa continue to go unmet despite existence of evidence-based interventions such as problem-solving therapy that can circumvent resource-related challenges to the provision of care— a reality that is particularly harmful for people with comorbid HIV and depression who are more likely to experience delays in diagnosis, treatment initiation, and viral suppression compared to their mentally well counterparts. The proposed study will draw from patient and provider preferences regarding the distinct features of mental health care implementation to formulate and pilot test a stepped problem-solving therapy implementation approach comprised of one lower- and higher-resource implementation strategy. Ultimately, I aim to engage in the training and research necessary to understand the feasibility of using adaptive mental health care implementation approaches in KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa, thereby supporting equitable physical and mental health outcomes for people with HIV in resource-constrained settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hemodialysis (HD) is the primary mode of survival for half a million Americans with failed kidneys (i.e. stage 5 chronic kidney disease (CKD) or end-stage renal disease (ESRD); millions more globally die each year because they lack access to dialysis. Arteriovenous fistulas (AVFs), or surgical connections of veins to arteries in the arm, are considered the gold standard for HD treatment, but 39% of the AVFs created in the United States fail to ever be used for dialysis and 50% are abandoned within 12 months because the vein that connects to the artery maladapts, greatly contributing to 1- and 5-year HD mortality rates of 21% and 60%, respectively. To address this, VenoStent has developed the SelfWrap Bioabsorbable Perivascular Wrap, a wrap that helps the vein adapt favorably to its new high pressure, high flow AVF environment, thereby improving the quality and length of life of CKD patients and potentially millions of others undergoing similar vascular surgeries.

PHR: Abnormally phosphoryated Tau protein (pTau) is implicated as causative in Alzheimer's Disease and certain other cognitive disorders, and is also commonly observed in persons with cognitive changes in opioid use disorder (OUD) and in HIV/HAND. Both gain-of-function (AAV/Cre techniques) and loss-of-function (Tau knockout mice crossed to HAND models; Tau aggregation reduced pharmacologically) studies test the hypothesis that pTau production and aggregation cause/escalate cognitive dysfunction in OUD, in HIV/HAND, and to opiate-induced exacerbation of HAND. Neuron activity, pathology, biochemistry are measured in mice that are studied behaviorally so that direct correlations can be made; miniscopes are used to measure activity of individual hippocampal neurons over 12 weeks of behavioral testing.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative With antiretroviral treatment (ART), children living with perinatal HIV achieve viral suppression, but inflammation persists, and may lead to early onset cardiovascular, metabolic and neurocognitive disorders. The goal of this study is to determine the durability of inflammation in persons with perinatal HIV after prolonged ART, its pathogenesis and the clinical consequences of sustained inflammation in a 10 year follow up study of the Pediatric Immune Activation cohort. Understanding long-term outcomes for the 2.7 million children living with HIV globally is of important public health relevance in order to develop early screening biomarkers and preventative interventions so they can thrive as adults.

ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative My current research is focused on understanding molecular mechanisms and pathophysiology that may be at the basis of stress-induced mood disorders, including depression, anxiety, and other neuropsychiatric disorders, and their influence on cognitive dysfunction and neurodegenerative disorders. These studies are investigating the role of psychological stress and toxin exposures in influencing novel neuro-inflammatory mechanisms driving immune-brain interactions to test causal hypotheses regarding neurovascular damage and the active recruitment of peripheral immune signals related to neuropathology and mood-related brain structures which control depression-like behavior, cognitive functioning, and neurodegeneration. The outcomes aim to further characterize and develop targeted therapeutics for conditions that severely impact the veteran population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic inflammation that persists in people with HIV is thought to impact the brain and elicit depressive behaviors, including motivational deficits like anhedonia that promote poor disease outcomes and are difficult to treat. The pathophysiologic mechanisms of HIV-associated CNS and behavioral dysfunction are not fully understood, but may involve peripheral blood monocytes and the cellular metabolic mechanisms that enable their activation and migration to the brain. The proposed research will examine monocyte glycolysis and migration as pathways to HIV-associated inflammation, reward circuit dysfunction, and symptoms of anhedonia while exploring immunomodulators that may therapeutically target monocyte mechanisms in HIV.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. Solnick's K23 research addresses critical gaps in HIV prevention and care by developing, implementing, and testing the Telephone Initiated PrEP Post-Emergency Department Discharge (TIPPED) protocol, a comprehensive and pragmatic approach for initiating PrEP in STI-diagnosed patients who visit Emergency Departments. Using implementation science methodology, stakeholder engagement, interrupted time series analysis, and a nested pilot RCT, this study will evaluate the implementation of a novel TIPPED protocol as well as a persuasive health communication intervention (PHCI) and ultimately improve PrEP initiation rates for patients at risk of HIV. This research will not only deliver important implementation science and clinical findings but also lay the foundation for larger-scale implementation and study across multiple emergency departments.

PHR: NARRATIVE In South Africa (SA), as many as 45.5% of transgender women (TW) may be living with HIV, and an estimated 1/3 are not in care; estimates of prevention behaviors, such as HIV testing, and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) use are also low (20.5% and 11%, respectively) and prevalence of syphilis, which drastically increases HIV risk and viral load, is ~9%. This study uses the Mensch Model to fill 3 critical information domains necessary to develop a dual HIV/syphilis (via INSTI Multiplex) self-testing and linkage-to-care intervention for SA TW, including needs/preferences on: self-test access/uptake, logistical support to use/interpret tests, and linkage to and uptake of PrEP and/or HIV/syphilis treatment. In 3 stages, we will: 1) conduct in-depth interviews (IDIs) with SA TW (N=15), and healthcare workers who care for SA TW (HCW; N=15) to understand preferences on the domains (Stage 1); send web-based surveys to SA TW's mobile phones (N=80), to identify the most popular strategies address each domain, and converge qualitative and quantitative data to draft the intervention using the 4 COM-B Intervention Function Matrix (Stage 2); and 3) convene an intervention development workgroup consisting of at least n=5 members from each our CAB, TW, and HCW groups (total of at least N=15 workgroup group participants) to further develop/refine the intervention to be pilot tested in a future R34 (Stage 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Up to half of people with HIV (PWH) develop HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND), even on effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). Little is known about the pathologic mechanism behind this group of disorders, including what exact role the virus plays in its their development. Using tissues from the unique Last Gift cohort, we will examine the epigenetic context of the integrated provirus guiding HIV expression in microglia, which are the primary reservoir for HIV in the brain. We will also examine the inflammatory cells in the brains in PWH on effective ART using cutting edge single cell sequencing techniques

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA damage, caused by environmental agents and the body’s normal processes, plays a critical role in the development of many major human diseases; in the U.S. alone, this potentially impacts one in two adults (~125 million people). While the comet assay is one of the most widely used and versatile methods for detecting cellular DNA damage, it is a time-consuming and labor intensive method. This proposal aims to develop a novel device for automating the comet assay, facilitating the simple and rapid measurement of DNA damage; advancing our knowledge of the role of DNA damage in health and disease, and hence promoting mitigation strategies and therapeutic interventions.

ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: For over a decade, Dr. Stella Dracheva's research has focused on deciphering the molecular underpinnings of brain disorders prevalent among U.S. military Veterans. Her work encompasses psychiatric and neurological disorders such as major depressive disorder, suicide, schizophrenia, opioid addiction, as well as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and spinal cord injury. Current treatments for these conditions are limited and often ineffective for many patients, underlining the urgent need for a deeper biological understanding to facilitate novel therapeutic development. Dr. Dracheva's track record of federal funding and impactful publications in high-ranking journals demonstrate her substantial contributions to these research areas. The RCS Award will enhance Dr. Dracheva's VA research, fostering new investigations, collaborations, and mentorship opportunities.

PHR: The rate of suicide among Veterans increased by 57% from 2001 to 2019; however, prospective prediction of suicidal behaviors remains a major challenge. Moreover, whereas heritability estimates for suicidal thoughts and behaviors range from 30-55%, the genetic basis of suicide remains largely unknown. Dr. Kimbrel’s program of research aims to address these gaps and to promote a precision medicine-based approach to suicide prevention in Veterans by: (1) Identifying the genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors that underlie risk for suicide and other closely-related conditions in Veterans; (2) Developing improved risk algorithms that utilize state-of-the-art machine learning techniques and novel data sources to identify Veterans at risk for suicide; and (3) Creating practical clinical tools that enhance clinicians’ ability to identify and intervene with Veterans at risk for attempting suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop an in vivo approach to therapeutic T-cell transformation that exploits our ability to synthesize virus-like particles (VLPs) from purified mRNA and viral capsid protein and to functionalize these particles with targeting antibodies against proteins that are uniquely expressed in T cells. The mRNA that is delivered in this way encodes either a T-cell receptor (TCR) or a chimeric-antigen receptor (CAR) that is specific to the particular cancer or viral infection from which a patient is suffering. The goal of this in vivo transformation and its accompanying transient expression of TCR and CAR genes is to supplant current ex vivo immunotherapies with ones that avoid both the extraction/infusion of T cells and the disruption of T-cell chromosomes by permanent integration of new genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In fishing communities in eastern Africa and similar environments alcohol and HIV are intertwined epidemics creating challenges to optimizing HIV treatment as prevention and ending the HIV epidemic. We propose to test an intervention and its components to reduce heavy alcohol use and improve ART adherence and HIV treatment outcomes with promising preliminary efficacy in this setting. We will also explore barriers and facilitators of integrating the intervention into routine clinical care to inform future widespread implementation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black women with BW face sociostructural inequities including structural racism, HIV stigma, and medical mistrust in addition to the syndemic effects of substance use, intimate partner violence and adverse mental health, which act as barriers to health seeing behaviors that contribute to poor HIV outcomes. Additionally, BW have been historically under enrolled in HIV clinical research that does not contend with these historical circumstances. As a first-generation, Black female predoctoral student, this explanatory sequential mixed methods R36 dissertation proposal is the first to attempt to quantify and contextualize the impacts of sociostructural inequities and syndemics on BW’s participation in HIV research to inform multilevel intervention efforts to conduct equitable and diverse research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that transgender women face high levels of trauma (e.g., events that result in harmful effects), clarifying the mechanisms by which traumatic events and the mental health sequelae impact HIV prevention and HIV care engagement is needed. This proposed study will explore trauma, mental health, and trans women’s engagement in HIV prevention and HIV care, implement an evidence-based trauma intervention, and explore implementation outcomes. Findings from this study will inform a larger scale study that will implement the trauma-informed intervention across multiple clinics to improve HIV prevention and HIV care for transgender women. .

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of our postdoctoral training program (Traineeships in AIDS Prevention Studies, or TAPS) are to train the next generation of HIV prevention scientists who will be skilled in diverse research methods, and to increase the number of ethnic/racial minority researchers; and thus we seek to build the skills of postdoctoral fellows to engage in research that combines biomedical, behavioral, social and structural interventions to have the biggest impact on the HIV epidemic and to train more ethnic/racial minority scientists. TAPS balances social/behavioral and biomedical/clinical sides of prevention and is housed in UCSF’s Center for AIDS Prevention Studies (CAPS) within the Division of Prevention Science, with close relationships to other institutions working in HIV prevention. Since the start of TAPS, we have trained 132 fellows who have become leaders in the field and this five-year renewal will permit training of 2-3 new fellows per year, for a total of 6 in the program.
PROJECT_TERMS: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome;Prevention;Traineeship
PROJECT_TITLE: Traineeships in AIDS Prevention Studies

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost all human cancers have alterations in metabolic pathways associated with aging and cancer signaling, but undergraduates rarely receive cross-training in cancer, aging, and metabolism research. The proposed Cancer Aging and Metabolism research experience Program (CAMP) will address the need for a well-trained workforce by providing a unique 10-week hands-on learning experience for 20 undergraduates each summer. This first iteration of CAMP will also pilot the integration of school-year academic and research activities with California State University, Dominguez Hills in an effort to bolster the pipeline for undergraduates to thrive as future cancer researchers.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Veterans are disproportionately susceptible to age-related skeletal muscle wasting known as sarcopenia. Identifying cost-effective interventions to treat sarcopenia is a major public health challenge for Veterans. We propose to develop and test a biomaterials-based sustained delivery of a small molecule drug, in conjunction with rehabilitative exercise, for treating sarcopenia in an aged mouse model. The critical preliminary data generated from this study will establish the feasibility of this approach, ultimately paving the way for further drug development and therapeutic testing towards clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although air-purifying respirators protect against occupational exposure to harmful particulate matter, in- cluding wildfire smoke or COVID-19, industry-standard filtering facepiece air-purifying respirators can cause con- tact dermatitis, discomfort, and bruising after prolonged wear, obstruction of visual communication, significant environmental waste, and insufficient or unknown filtration capabilities. The proposed design uses electrostatic filtration to overcome many of the barriers of traditional respirators while providing a high degree of protection. The perimetral gap filter removes particles even though the mask does not come in contact with the skin of the wearer’s face.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Comfortable Face Mask for Long-Term Wear
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: The more than one million firefighters in the United States provide critical emergency medical services in communities they serve and are on the front lines of healthcare delivery, including in the post-pandemic world. As a result of exposure to occupational stressors, a high proportion of firefighters experience considerable stress-related burden including psychological distress (i.e., anxiety and depression). To address this need, this project will test the efficacy of an app-based meditation intervention to improve well-being among career firefighters.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Psychological Distress in Fire Fighters with an Asynchronous App-based Meditation Intervention
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotic resistance among gram-negative bacterial pathogens is becoming increasingly frequent. This is particularly true in patients who suffer from chronic infections or are immunocompromised, such as in those with cystic fibrosis. One pathogen that causes significant morbidity and mortality is Pseudomonas aeruginosa. We have developed antisense molecules that effectively kill this pathogen, including in drug-resistant isolates. We will further characterize our lead antisense molecules and nominate an ultimate lead for IND submission.

PHR: The project aims to validate new genetic models for studying the mechanisms underlying painful neuroma which occurs after nerve injury and seriously impacts Veterans’ quality of life, engagement with rehabilitation, and use of prosthetics. The causes of painful neuroma are not known, which hinder development of treatments and preventions. The proposed work will take a basic science approach to enable new types of experiments to answer some of the fundamental questions which will directly influence the design of translational strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the many exciting advances in gene editing technologies since the advent of CRISPR-Cas9, the field has been hampered by an inability to catalyze programmable and predictable insertion of large DNA payloads without generating double-strand breaks. The recent discovery and development of CRISPR-associated transposons offers an exciting new strategy to insert large genetic cargos (>10kb) with high integration efficiencies and virtually no off-target events. This proposal aims to systematically optimize CRISPR- associated transposons in human cells to achieve therapeutically relevant editing efficiencies, and to apply them for the universal correction of CFTR gene mutations that cause cystic fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will build a foundational pathogenic understanding of Sjögren’ss disease (SjD), a common systemic autoimmune disease characterized by oral and ocular dryness and marked morbidity, with no available disease-modifying treatments. This proposal leverages cutting-edge spatial genomic and protein profiling technology to define a new pathologically relevant cell type, the mesenchymal stromal cell, while simultaneously determining clinically relevant differences between salivary gland tissue of seronegative and seropositive SjD subjects. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIDCR’s mission that pertains to improving oral and dental health through research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies address the important areas of breast cancer that is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in women throughout the world, and the regulatory T cell-induced tumor immunosuppressive microenvironment that is a major barrier for successful anti-tumor immunotherapy. The proposed research has relevance to public health, because it seeks to dissect novel suppressive mechanisms and then to develop strategies that control immune suppression mediated by regulatory T cells in human breast cancer. Thus, the findings are ultimately expected to improve treatment of human breast cancer and other cancers as well.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While traditional radical prostatectomy is the most popular treatment for clinically significant prostate cancer, significant risks are commonplace: urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, penile shortening, penile curvature/ deformation (Peyronie's disease), and inguinal hernia. In contrast, pelvic fascia-sparing radical prostatectomy, by preserving fascial support structures, penile arterial supply, and nerves, can reduce urinary incontinence by 80% and may improve patient survival. To overcome both the limitations of small, retrospective studies with limited cancer control follow-up outcomes and the typical barriers of low accrual and high costs of prospective trials, we propose a multi-center, randomized controlled trial with a novel, two-stage, informed consent process and a web portal for self-entry of patient-reported outcomes, which will strengthen the quality of evidence for this new surgical technique.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic, with associated unprecedented ARDS/VILI mortality rates, dramatically highlights the absence of FDA-approved ARDS/VILI pharmacotherapies. Aqualung Therapeutics has identified a novel ARDS/VILI target, eNAMPT, and have developed a highly effective monoclonal antibody, ALT-100 mAb, to directly addresses the serious unmet therapeutic need for novel ARDS/VILI therapies. Both ALT-100 mAb safety and efficacy will be assessed in the proposed R-44 PUERTA trial, a randomized Phase IIA clinical trial, as well as the development of an individualized therapeutic approach to reduce ARDS mortality.

PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer cells rely on the RNA binding protein, HuR, to regulate a pro-survival response to low nutrient conditions in the tumor microenvironment. In this proposal, we show that antioxidant defense (via the IDH1 enzyme) and mitochondrial function are the principal effector arms of this adaptive program. Insights gained from this work should expose therapeutic opportunities to target deadly pancreatic cancer cells, and spare normal tissue.

PHR: The proposal aims to determine if non-invasive vagus nerve stimulation(nVNS) will alter: 1) the peripheral inflammatory biomarker profile, 2) the neural correlates of change in pain stimuli and 3) PTSD symptom severity and 4) life quality and function in Veterans with PTSD. The planned inflammatory biomarker and neuroimaging results can 1) promote knowledge of inflammatory and neurobiological mechanisms that contribute to pain in PTSD, and 2) advance our ability to provide targeted neuromodulation based interventions that support improved life quality and function for Veterans. These goals are consistent with the VA’s mission to sponsor research examining variables related to pathogenesis, diagnosis, and(ultimately) treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Influenza A-induced Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (IAV-induced ARDS) is associated with 45% mortality and current treatment is supportive. Glutamine metabolism plays a key role in immune function and viral replication but is understudied in IAV-induced ARDS. This project will target the glutamine pathway to identify key sites of metabolic regulation in alveolar macrophage effector function and viral replication, which will serve as the basis for my transition to become an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite evidence that early treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations improves outcomes, prior efforts to identify exacerbations prior to presentation to care have demonstrated mixed results. Because patients are instructed to increase their use of short-acting beta agonist (SABA) inhalers in response to worsening symptoms, electronic inhaler monitors that detect these increases may be used to identify exacerbations earlier in their course, expedite outpatient management, and decrease the risk for hospitalization. In this study, we will examine whether SABA inhaler use is associated with respiratory symptoms and exacerbations, examine possible risk factors for poor self-management, and conduct a qualitative study to explore participants’ thought processes surrounding their self-management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is a heterogeneous group of progressive diseases of blood-forming hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells. Mechanisms of progression are poorly understood, and treatment options are limited. Our proposed highly collaborative and synergistic studies will produce a vibrant understanding of the path from molecular mutations to functional consequences in MDS and create a library of resources that can be shared with the greater MDS scientific community to enable further progress toward improved treatment strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this MIRA research program we will investigate how chemical properties of drug compounds affect drug absorption through skin that has been treated with microneedles, and we will study this in the laboratory, in animals, and in patients of different ages. PHR: Project Narrative ACLY is a key metabolic and epigenetic mediator whose dysregulation has been implicated in diseases such as cancer. The full-length protein is preferentially expressed in tumors over another major splice isoform, but ACLY isoforms have not been closely studied. The goal of my project is to understand the structural, molecular, and biological impacts of ACLY alternative splicing, which will provide insight into the tumor-supporting roles of ACLY and potentially lead to new therapeutic strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) can provide metabolic information noninvasively for assessment of tumor type and treatment response in any body part. This research project will develop and evaluate automated tools to make MRS measurements easier and more robust for both research and clinical uses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well-documented that where you reside in America shapes when you die, and this has been shown to be particularly true among low-income Americans where longevity varies substantially in different places of the country. This proposal studies Medicaid enrollees that migrate to understand whether “place-based inequalities” are driven by the causal impact of places on access to evidence-based behavioral healthcare treatment, and to identify the characteristics of places associated with improved access, health, and health equity.

PHR: Project Narrative The FDA has issued a call for research that provides ”Evaluations of the impact and possible unintended consequences of tobacco regulatory actions among specific populations, as appropriate, addressing how such actions may increase or decrease tobacco-related health disparities.” Our proposed study will examine the impact of the anticipated flavor ban policy using a health equity lens. We will provide the FDA CTP with evidence of the impact of the ban on the intended (i.e., smoking reduction and increased cessation) and unintended (e.g., increased smoking rates) behavioral consequences on African-American/Black and Hispanic/Latino young adults.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among current T32 training programs for cancer prevention, control, and survivorship, few focus on health equity among rural populations and none focus on cancer in the rural, Appalachian population. Addressing Rural cancer Inequities through Scientific Excellence (ARISE) is a postdoctoral training program at the University of Kentucky that will be a collaboration among the Center for Health Equity Transformation (CHET), the NCI-designated Markey Cancer Center (MCC), Center for Clinical and Translational Science (CCTS), UK Center for Appalachian Research in Environmental Sciences (UK-CARES), six colleges and 10 departments to provide interdisciplinary training in behavioral cancer research focused on rural disparities. The training program will have three tracks, environment, risk behavior, and health care delivery and will provide didactic, research experience and mentoring.

PROJECT_TITLE: Addressing Rural cancer Inequities through Scientific Excellence (ARISE)

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oropharyngeal head and neck cancers have escalated to epidemic levels in the United States, and survivors are suffering from life-long, devastating swallowing disorders with limited therapeutic options. This clinical trial investigates a novel swallowing treatment that trains initiation of swallowing during the expiratory phase of respiration to improve swallowing safety and efficiency. Consistent with the National Cancer Institute's research mission, this study may discover a new therapy option, that could be combined with traditional therapies, to improve swallowing recovery for survivors of oropharyngeal head and neck cancer.

PHR: Establishing the optimal anesthetic approach for inguinal hernia repair could improve post-surgical outcomes for adults aged 65 years and older. This project will culminate in a well-designed pilot study of local anesthesia versus general anesthesia for inguinal hernia repair in older adults. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: How a gene is expressed differentially depending on the context such as cell type and environment is a fundamental question in biomedicine with substantial implications in human diseases. However, the mechanism is poorly understood because of the shortcomings of the current technology, which involves mainly fixed, thus non-physiological, cells and tissues. Our proposed research will develop versatile intravital technology for interrogating transcriptional dynamics in living mammals, combining intravital multiphoton microscopy and molecular/genomic engineering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Spatiotemporal and mechanical processes are prevalent and critical for the cell, but remain poorly understood. The PI’s laboratory will use mathematical modeling to synthesize experimental data and elucidate the roles of spatiotemporal and mechanical processes, as well as their coupling with biochemical pathways, in cellular functions. Focusing on mitosis and bacterial motility, this research will create fundamental knowledge about the underlying cellular mechanisms, which will promote future innovations in cancer therapy and bacterial control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pain is the hallmark of sickle cell disease (SCD), and is the leading cause of hospitalizations, emergency room visits, missed school, and is associated with an increased death rate. We found that patients with SCD and pain had low levels of the amino acid arginine in their blood, and we also demonstrated that arginine supplementation during acute pain events signi?cantly reduced the amount of narcotics needed to treat sickle cell pain in children and dramatically improved pain scores at discharge compared to placebo. We propose to investigate the bene?ts and safety of arginine for the treatment of patients with SCD and pain in a phase 3 randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial where neither the patient nor the clinical team know which therapy the patient is receiving, since Arginine is a promising new therapy that could change the way we treat acute pain in SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Three of the most pressing scientific challenges in vaccine-preventable disease research are (1) estimating time-varying disease transmissibility (i.e., the effective reproduction number, REff); (2) real-time monitoring and measurement of transmissibility-relevant behaviors (e.g., vaccine hesitancy, mobility, etc.); and (3) epidemic forecasting as a function of said behaviors. To address these challenges across relevant vaccine-preventable diseases, we propose the development of (1) a meta-analytical tool to generate ensemble estimates for REff; (2) a surveillance system for monitoring vaccine hesitancy and an inference system for improved measurements of human mobility; and (3) a generalizable agent-based model that integrates behavioral parameters informed by the aforementioned surveillance and inference systems to produce more accurate disease forecasts. By addressing these challenges through a combination of digital data streams and machine learning, we hope to enable data-driven decision-making for clinicians and public health policymakers alike.

PROJECT_TITLE: Digital data streams and machine learning for real-time modeling of vaccine-preventable infectious diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Narrative Indian Health Council, Inc. (IHC) with San Diego State University (SDSU) and University of California San Diego (UCSD), intends to build upon their already existing long-term research partnership with the following proposed projects/studies in the NARCH X application: Student Development Program and the Administrative Core. These projects will further expand and refine strategies to recruit students from local academic institutions into biomedical and behavioral sciences as well as, continue to provide strong mentorship and guidance for the students in and outside of the region and by providing administrative and fiscal oversight, coordinating communication and dissemination of information to foster the academic and community partnerships, supporting the CA-NARCH SDP in establishing a trained cohort of AI/AN scientists dedicated to impacting the health disparities of AI/AN populations, and by guidance in and conducting relevant evaluation to ensure the success of the core and CA-NARCH SDP.

PHR: Program Narrative The CA NARCH XI Administrative Core will help fulfill the major aims and goals of all Center components by pursuing the following specific aims: 1) To provide leadership and management, including administrative and fiscal oversight of the CA-NARCH student development project; 2) To coordinate communication and dissemination of information between the local tribes, tribal leaders, and the student development program team; 3) To support the cultural interface and augment research ethical training in the SDP with biannual workshops led by the Tirbal IRB chair and members; 4) To seek out and disperse information on funding opportunities through NARCH and other sources for continued development of training and mentoring programs and/or research projects; 5) To evaluate progress of the CA-NARCH in achieving its objectives and milestones. The specific aims will support the efforts of the CA-NARCH mission of conducting highly relevant, American Indian/Alaskan Native (AI/AN) community-based research and establishing a trained cohort of AI/AN scientists dedicated to impacting the health disparities of AI/AN populations.

PHR: Overall Program Narrative Brain tumors are the most common pediatric solid malignancies, and the leading cause of cancer-related death in children. This program will continue to advance understanding of the mechanisms driving diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma and multiple subtypes of medulloblastoma. The Program also investigates therapeutic vulnerabilities for these childhood brain tumors that inflict significant morbidity and mortality.

PHR: Project 1 Narrative Diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas (DIPG) are incurable brainstem tumors arising almost exclusively in children. This project will determine how disrupted glial development contributes to DIPG tumorigenesis, why particular mutations are selectively associated with brainstem or midline gliomas, and what molecular features modulate tumor response to inhibitors of pathways mutated in DIPG.

PHR: Project Narrative Circadian misalignment and synaptic dysfunction are common to several neurodevelopment, neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative syndromes, but the mechanisms that directly link the circadian system to synaptic function are poorly understood. We have recently discovered a novel role for the phosphorylation of BMAL1 – a component of the core circadian clock mechanism – in regulating a circadian rhythm of synaptic vesicles, a key computational unit for information transfer. The proposed research will determine how BMAL1 regulates circadian presynaptic plasticity through biochemical interactions and/or biophysical organization of synaptic proteins and will identify what pre-synaptic signals modulate it, with the goal of uncovering targets the can modulate synaptic vesicle dynamics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal cord injury leads to long-lasting impairment, and currently, there is no cure for paralysis. Although electrical spinal cord stimulation has shown promising results in recovering lost movements, the mechanisms of action are not properly understood. This project uses novel, non-invasive techniques to determine how different structures in the central nervous system respond to spinal cord stimulation and training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  RNA is fundamental for all life, and is involved in complex interactions that impact human health and disease; however integrative analyses are often performed at the genomic level rather than the transcriptome level. We propose two complementary approaches to uncover new biological insights about RNA sequence and structure, and their impact on efficiency of translation from RNA transcript into protein, and how this process is regulated. We also propose to create a user-friendly, web-accessible infrastructure for the investigation and visualization of RNA sequence, structure, and interactions, by integrating publicly-available data, along with the data that we generate through our proposed work, which will allow us and other researchers to make new discoveries about RNA function, with implications for the critically important development of RNA-based vaccines and interpreting disease-associated synonymous variants within transcripts.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 27 million people worldwide are estimated to suffer chronic somatic pain as a result of systematic torture, which is likely undetected by evaluators due to confounding psychiatric illness and a lack of diagnostic tools. This gap in the detection of pain results in exclusive psychological treatment rather than multimodal therapies, substantially limiting rehabilitation, placing vulnerable individuals at higher risk of drug abuse, and increasing healthcare expenditures. The objectives of this study are to improve the diagnosis of pain in torture survivors (SA 1), to qualitatively characterize acceptability of somatic pain treatment (SA 2), and to assess the feasibility of recruiting and retaining subjects in a subsequent clinical trial (SA 3).

PHR: Project Narrative: Training and Education Program Diverse investigators play an integral role in identifying novel research questions, perspectives, and solutions to complex biomedical challenges. Yet, diversifying the biomedical research workforce remains a major challenge in the US, despite the fact that underrepresented minorities make up the most rapidly growing segment of the US population Thus, in a unique partnership between the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and Hampton University, we propose to provide hybrid training and education to increase the research capacity, engagement, and success of the HU scientific workforce, with particular emphasis on genetics and genomics and cancer disparities research.

PHR: Project Narrative This U01 grant application is submitted in response to RFA EY-21-002 “Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD) Integrative Biology Initiative”, with the goal of determining if patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) can be used to discover the underlying pathophysiology of AMD. Our studies will focus on two single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with the highest odds ratio for developing advanced AMD- Age-Related Maculopathy Susceptibility 2/High Temperature Requirement A1 (ARMS2/HTRA1) and Complement Factor H (CFH) . Our hypothesis is that each genetic risk SNP has a unique molecular signature, determined from changes in the proteome and metabolome. Results from our studies will provide novel insight into the specific biological pathways and how they are affected by these high-risk SNPs.

PHR: Project Narrative Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children. Of the four subgroups, Group3 is the most aggressive and patients invariably experience recurrence with metastases and die of their disease. A better undertstanding of the genes and molecular mechanims that drive Group 3 tumorigenesis may lead to the identification of novel targets for therapeutic intervention to improve survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious diseases continue to be a major threat to the health and safety of people around the world, and technologies that can rapidly produce vaccines with long shelf-life, such as that promised by peptide-based vaccines, would significantly improve society’s ability to meet global needs in the face of a novel pathogen. Our ability to rapidly develop peptide-based vaccines is dependent on the identification of epitopes, or pathogen fragments, that will sufficiently train the immune system to recognize a novel pathogen as foreign. The proposed work is aimed at developing computational tools that account for the genetic variability between pathogen strains and across individuals to efficiently identify epitopes for the development of peptide-based vaccines.

PHR: Narrative Clonal selection and inherent cancer cell plasticity—as well as the ability of cancer cells to undergo adaptation and reprogramming to drug resistant states, following treatment are currently challenging the concept of individual proteins as effective therapeutic targets for an entire tumor mass—especially if identified from bulk tissue analyses. To address these challenges, we have identified a more universal class of mutation- agnostic, non-oncogene dependencies implemented by Tumor Checkpoint (TC) modules, comprising small sets of Master Regulator (MR) proteins working in concert to implement and maintain tumor cell state by canalizing the effect of mutations and signals in their upstream pathways. Our proposal will thus focus on the elucidation and pharmacological targeting of MRs and TC-modules at the single cell level, within molecularly distinct, yet co-existing tumor subpopulations, leading to design of successful combination therapy approaches and discovery of mechanisms of drug resistance and cell adaptation.
