IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The impact of global climate change, including the increased frequency of weather extremes such as flooding, on the incidence of malaria and other vector-borne diseases is an issue of substantial public health importance. Thus, there is an urgent need not only to elucidate the changes in the ecological, biological, and social factors that impact malaria transmission in the post-flood environment, but also to develop effective mitigation and control strategies. Therefore, the scientific aim of this proposal is to evaluate the effectiveness of a targeted, time-limited malaria chemoprevention intervention with and without larval source management (LSM) to reduce excess malaria burden in a perennial, high-transmission setting following severe flooding.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognition is relevant to the origins and outcome of different types of psychopathology, but the specifics of this relationship are not well understood. The NIMH’s RDoC framework encourages examination of transdiagnostic traits, as well as genetics and brain systems, to advance knowledge. We aim to use this approach, along with newly available samples in the field and computational strategies we developed, to validate and demarcate the genetic and neural underpinnings of cognitive systems in relation to ADHD and child psychosocial outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative. The secretion of saliva is vital for health and this is most commonly appreciated in disorders such as Sjogren's syndrome where salivary flow is markedly decreased. Following nerve stimulation, the secretion of saliva occurs through the finely tuned choreography of changes in intracellular Ca2+ and activation of ion channels and transporters in specific subcellular domains in salivary gland cells. We postulate these processes are disrupted early in disease and using mouse models of Sjogren’s syndrome, coupled with pathway analysis and functional assays, we will define the events which result in a decrease in secretion and the progression of disease, with an ultimate goal of identifying novel molecular pathways targetable for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this proposal is to conduct a placebo-controlled randomized trial comparing the effects of hemp-derived CBD with and without THC, relative to placebo, on reducing cannabis use and CUD symptoms in adult treatment seeking cannabis concentrate users with CUD. This question has enormous public health importance because the field lacks an effective CUD medication, particularly for high potency concentrate users. In addition, hemp-derived CBD products with and without low levels of THC are already widely available to consumers; thus, a positive finding would have an immediate public health impact.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The human genome encodes tens of thousands of circular RNAs (circRNAs), of which the translation is essential for regulating important biological functions, such as cell proliferation, differentiation, and migration. Current technologies cannot distinguish circRNAs from linear RNAs efficiently, such that the mechanism and molecular components regulating circRNA translation remain unclear. The proposed research will utilize my newly developed technology, which can identify the RNA sequences that initiate circRNA translation specifically, to (i) characterize the sequence and protein components regulating circRNA translation, (ii) elucidate the association between genetic variation, circRNA translation and disease, and (iii) build a gene expression platform with tunable expression level and tissue specificity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic bladder cancer is a devastating disease with a 5-year survival rate of only 5.4%. While the initial steps of the metastatic cascade are rather well defined, identification of targets to block this process continues to be a major clinical challenge. Discovering the regulatory mechanisms by which the metastatic microenvironment support tumor cell colonization and survival will enable design of new strategies not only targeting the primary tumors, but also eradicating metastatic foci – a potential new breakthrough.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research has significant public health relevance related to the adolescent opioid epidemic because it will identify modifiable factors associated with the development of opioid misuse among adolescents who receive an opioid prescription for pain management following surgery. This research will examine sleep deficiency as a novel risk factor associated with problematic opioid use behaviors and explore underlying mechanisms related to pain and psychological risk factors. The application’s contribution would be significant because it is expected to enable the identification of adolescents at risk for problematic opioid use following surgery and inform novel behavioral therapeutic targets for the prevention of opioid misuse.

PHR: Project Narrative CAR-T cells have demonstrated value in the treatment of hematological malignancies, though their efficacy in solid tumors is lacking. This proposal will establish an outbred, immunocompetent canine model of CAR-T therapy for solid tumors to identify molecular predictors of CAR-T cell homing and persistence in tumors. This model will be used for to evaluate novel CAR-T therapy approaches prior to human trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Successful uptake of research in authentic school and community settings requires the application of well- established, team-based, systematic approaches to translational science that combines research findings, stakeholder engagement, both quantitative and qualitative analyses, and iterative improvements. These approaches have great potential to close the research to practice gap by creating sustainable processes built for the contexts in which they will be used. With this LDRC, we expand upon previous successes to include studies beyond foundational science and with more diverse populations of students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project leverages the unprecedented opportunity to utilize existing data in the All of Us Researcher Workbench, our prior linkage of environmental factors into the dataset, and novel analytic methods to investigate how the social context and physical environment jointly contributes to disparities in CVD risk, and to further evaluate the impact of individual-level factors (e.g., established genes, individual demographics) on the modification and/or mitigation of these impacts. It addresses the need for integrated, and comprehensive investigation of the multiple layers of environmental influence with individual-level factors, especially in studies powered to investigate racial/ethnic disparities in CVD. It builds upon work being conducted by the University of Chicago team using All of Us data and provides an excellent training opportunity for a Disparities Fellow.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The AHRQ-sponsored conference series on “Developing a research agenda for wellness within the LHS framework” has an overarching goal of creating a foundation for development of the next generation of healthcare worker (HCW) wellness scholars and equipping them with tools to carry out a structured research agenda on HCW reactions to challenging work environments. These conferences will convene a multidisciplinary group of stakeholders studying HCW wellness and work culture. Our objectives are to identify promising strategies to study HCW wellness and develop competencies required for this rigorous area of scholarship.

PHR: Project Narrative  This project is aimed toward the development of a production platform for natural 6-deoxysugars. These deoxysugars can be used to make derivatives of natural products with new or improved therapeutic properties, for example, more potent anticancer agents and antibiotics that are effective against antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health in that it aims to achieve greater understanding of, and creation of more effective, cognitive interventions for typically developing adolescents as well as youth diagnosed with Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). This research is aligned with the NIMH mission of transforming the understanding and treatment of mental illnesses in that it seeks to develop and test an accessible and low-cost intervention to improve cognitive function and mental health in diverse populations using an innovative telemedicine approach. The proposed research cuts across the bounds of numerous NIH agencies, with our framework contributing to the missions of the NIMH, NICHD, NIA, NCI, NEI, NIAAA, NINCD, NIDA, and NINDS, in that all of these agencies work with populations who can gain direct benefits from successful approaches to remediate cognitive deficits and improve mental health, and the NIH’s greater mission to seek knowledge that will result in enhanced health and a reduced burden of disabilities, and ultimately, transform mental health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it makes new discoveries about diseases and conditions associated with speech-language disorders; and identifies shared genetic risk factors underlying speech-language outcomes and a host of other clinical outcomes. Findings from this study will establish necessary groundwork for improving precision medicine for individuals with speech-language disorders by identifying novel clinical and genetic risk factors; generating testable hypotheses about disease mechanisms; and early intervention efforts for comorbid conditions. This project is therefore relevant to the NIH’s mission to gain insights into the nature and behavior of living systems and to apply this knowledge to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Head and neck cancer has the sixth highest incidence among cancers worldwide, and recurrence rates approach 50% in patients diagnosed with locally advanced disease. In this proposal, we will utilize cutting-edge mouse models of oral cavity cancer to study mechanisms of tumor progression and resistance to standard therapies. We will also use these models to identify and test new therapeutic approaches. Therefore, the proposed research is particularly relevant to the National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Resesarch’s mission to improve oral health by enhancing the understanding and treatment of head and neck cancer.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coordinated activity among different regions of the neocortex is essential for normal sensory perception, cognition, and motor control. My research will focus on the mechanisms by which the visual thalamus mediates functional communication between visual cortical areas through the transthalamic corticocortical circuit. This project will provide insight into core mechanisms of functional communication between visual cortical areas, interactions that are impaired by both diseases affecting visual perception (e.g. schizophrenia) and brain injuries affecting visually guided behavior (e.g. visuo-spatial neglect following trauma).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Exposure to complex environmental agents, such as ultrafine particulate matter derived from combustion sources and engineered nanomaterials, is not well understood. The toxic potential of inhaled particles is dependent on their size and chemical composition, and current solutions for personal exposure monitoring are expensive. This proposed effort addresses the need for a better individual exposure assessment, specifically, quantification of the health impact of ultrafine particles, and will facilitate optimal selection and implementation of air pollution control strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a common and devastating disease of women that causes dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and other sequelae. The investigators in our proposed Center have helped to identify a central feature of endometriosis pathophysiology and discovered a molecular mechanism underpinning it: progesterone resistance due to SIRT1 activity. In this application, we propose to use features of progesterone resistance to develop improved diagnostic imaging techniques and deepen our pathophysiological understanding to improve approaches to therapy.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: The retina detects, computes, and transmits visual information to brain through intricate synaptic networks among five major neuronal types: photoreceptors, horizontal cells, bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and retinal ganglion cells. Amacrine cell is the most diverse but least understood retinal neuron. This study will use a multidisciplinary approach to investigate the role of a wide-field amacrine cells called TH2-AC in contrast and motion detection during daytime. Success of the study will bring better understanding on information processing in retina and will benefit current and future therapeutic attempts in treating human blinding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases of the small vessels of the brain contribute to the development of vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID). Because vascular diseases can be prevented and treated, there is an incredible potential for the development of interventions to stop or treat the disease; however, more research is needed to develop robust biomarkers that can be used in clinical trials of VCID. This study seeks to perform a comprehensive longitudinal validation of candidate biomarkers for diseases of the small vessels of the brain in a diverse sample of South Texas, particularly in Hispanic and African Americans as they face an increased risk of VCID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The number of people in the world suffering from neurological disorders is increasing rapidly, and many of these diseases have no good treatments much less cures. To address this unmet need to find better treatments for these disorders, this program aims to train laboratory-based scientists working on disease relevant projects to advance their discoveries to clinical trials and eventually as treatments for these patients. The comprehensive program combines traditional and experiential learning opportunities.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Translating Neuroscience to Therapies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this proposal is to identify an immune modulation strategy to increase safety and efficacy of an adeno-associated virus (AAV)-mediated gene therapy approach for the treatment of Friedreich’s ataxia, a devastating genetic disorder affecting the heart and the nervous system in children and young adults. First, we will develop and optimize a safe and effective immune modulation approach to prevent immune responses to the viral capsid and to allow for safe and effective repeated administration of AAV. Second, we will identify a strategy to reduce anti-AAV antibody titer in animals with pre-existing immunity to AAV and allow for safe and effective therapeutic AAV dosing in pre-exposed animals. Since experiments will focus on safety and levels of transgene expression, we will use wild type mice and non-human primates (NHPs). The successful completion of this proposal will lead to important breakthroughs for Friedreich’s ataxia as well as for the application of gene therapy in many other inherited neuromuscular diseases.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a leading cause of disability and lost productivity. I have found that both the number and the activity of newborn neurons in an area of the brain called the hippocampus are necessary for the effects of antidepressants. The goal of these studies is to understand the role of these newborn neurons in MDD to enable the development of new and more effective antidepressants.

ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a major public health crisis in the United States, with >50,000 overdose deaths in 2017 alone. The candidate lead compound of this drug development application is based on the neurotensin system, which represents a promising target for the treatment of addiction; however, its therapeutic utility has not been fully realized due to the lack of brain-penetrant, systemically available compounds with non-limiting side effects. The research purposed here will further develop a potential, brain-penetrant treatment for OUD through to testing the drug in healthy volunteers, with the ultimate goal of testing the drug’s efficacy in phase 2 studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to the lack of efficacious alternative treatment options, chronic pain is often treated with opioids despite the risk of addiction and side effects. With the advent of gene therapy, it is now possible to specifically target pain pathways at the molecular level. The goal of this study is to further develop and evaluate the efficacy and safety of a non-addictive, alternative analgesic that can epigenetically repress expression of NaV1.7, a sodium channel that is important for sensing pain.

PHR: Lung cancer patients that get treated with radiotherapy and immunotherapy are at a risk of developing pulmonary side-effects from treatment. Our project proposes to use quantitative imaging to reduce toxicity for patients treated with aggressive radiotherapy and immunotherapy regimens in clinical trials. The developed novel imaging modality can improve quality of life for lung cancer patients and enable investigation of more- aggressive treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application is for the “Trauma Resuscitation with Group O Whole Blood Or Products” (TROOP) trial, an 1,100-patient, 12-center, pragmatic, multicenter, phase III randomized clinical trial to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of whole blood, compared with component blood therapy, in trauma patients predicted to require large volume blood transfusions. Hemorrhage remains the most common cause of preventable death after injury, and whole blood has several potential advantages over component therapy (the current standard of care). The TROOP trial is exceedingly well positioned to improve mortality from trauma, and reduce the number of preventable deaths resulting from hemorrhagic shock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: Public Health Relevance More than 80,000 patients are diagnosed with bladder cancer each year in the USA alone, and 78% of them face recurrence, which is believed to be because surgical instrumentation limitations currently require tumors to be removed piecemeal. We propose a new endoscopic robotic system that will give surgeons two tiny, dexterous surgical instruments in the bladder, enabling removal of the whole tumor, in one piece. Accomplishing this will enable surgeons to immediately initiate aggressive chemotherapy and/or bladder removal for patients whose disease has progressed into the muscle, while sparing patients with localized disease from the morbidity of aggressive treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is one of the leading causes of death and disability worldwide because the disease is highly heterogeneous with complex mechanisms of pathogenesis and the role of the peripheral immune response on the brain remains unexplored. This project will establish an innovative perfused blood / blood-brain barrier three dimensional interface model that will allow us to examine the relationship between blood components (plasma, immune cells) and the blood-brain barrier in healthy conditions and following TBI. This model may facilitate discovery or analysis of potential biomarkers for TBI and evaluate the efficacy of potential therapeutics that target the systemic inflammatory-driven brain pathophysiology in this disease.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Oral, Dental and Craniofacial Sciences Study Section[ODCS]

PHR: Narrative  Partial nephrectomy is becoming an increasingly important treatment for kidney cancer because more than 60% of kidney cancer cases are diagnosed in early, localized stages; however, accurate visualization of renal tumor and its boundary remains a long-standing technique challenge and there is a strong unmet for fluorescent imaging agents that can enhance precision of partial nephrectomy. The goal of ClearNano Inc. is to commercialize a safe, renal-tubule-secretable, tumor targeting NIR fluorescent agent, named “ClearICG” for intraoperative, hyper-fluorescence imaging of kidney cancer. The success will significantly improve oncological and renal functional outcomes while overall medical expense is significantly reduced (~20%).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell to cell variability in signaling networks is universal and its functional importance is now recognized across a range of different biological contexts. Therefore, predictive modeling of population variability will be of a broader interest to the cell and molecular biology community. In this proposal, we will develop a novel mechanistic and predictive computational tool to model population variability and use it to study two centrally important mammalian signaling pathways; mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway and the mechanotransduction pathway.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Nigeria has the 4th highest global burden of HIV and an uncontrolled epidemic. Youth aged 15-24 have high rates of HIV incidence, while retention in care and viral suppression are both poor. The HIV epidemic in Nigeria's youth is highest in men who have sex with men (MSM) and transgender women (TW). Effective, scalable, youth-specific interventions with enhanced prevention, improved case-finding, and increased ART access and adherence support for youth living with HIV, including YMSM and YTW are critical to turn around lagging indicators across the HIV prevention and care continuum. However, to-date, no interventions have shown efficacy or undergone rigorous effectiveness and implementation research in Nigeria's complex sociocultural milieu.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will provide an in-depth analysis of our previously-developed metabolic syndrome (MetS) severity z-score across a wide array of racial/ethnic and sexual/gender subgroups. We will first evaluate for unique features of metabolic syndrome across different populations, producing unique scoring if needed or continuing with already-derived scores if not needed. We will then assess both for 1) how social determinants of health (SDOH) are related to MetS severity for each group, and 2) how MetS severity is related to longitudinal risk for CVD—providing tools for a more personalized approach to measuring cardiometabolic risk across the entire U.S. population, as well as a validated tool for other All of Us researchers to use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The main objective of this award is to recruit, retain, and mentor trainees from backgrounds underrepresented in medicine into research career pathways that will ultimately help support our nation's biomedical and behavioral workforce goal of increasing and diversifying the pipeline of diabetes researchers. This opportunity will provide research training under the mentorship of a recognized and dedicated researcher with a well- established track record of NIH funding. This mentoring relationship holds the potential to favorably impact career trajectories of underrepresented students and fellows and help close America's gap in training a diverse biomedical and behavioral diabetes research workforce to improve clinical and public health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Beta cell dysfunction and death are significant pathologies underlying the development of Type 2 diabetes. The PI will train and mentor students from diverse backgrounds in projects focused on understanding how SARS- CoV-2 infection affects beta cell survival, metabolism, and function. This research and mentoring experience will prepare trainees to be the next generation of investigators by engaging in experiments to understand the molecular basis of a pressing public health issue that may afflict a significant number of patients who have recovered from COVID19.

PHR: Although screening colonoscopy can reduce colorectal cancer (CRC) incidence and mortality, there is considerable variability in individual risk of CRC. Better CRC risk estimates could improve CRC prevention through personalized approaches to the timing, modality (colonoscopy or non-invasive options) and frequency of screening and follow up. To achieve this goal, we need risk prediction models that incorporate individual clinical factors and screening history (if available) with genetic information for each Veteran. This CDA proposal seeks to build an accurate database of Veterans who developed CRC and advanced precancerous lesions, link this database to the Million Veteran Program to expand genetic discovery across diverse populations, and create an equitable tool for personalized assessments of CRC risk. More precise CRC risk stratification will improve CRC prevention by better targeting colonoscopy resources to the individuals at increased risk for CRC, while reducing the costs and harms of invasive screening and follow up in those at low risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Standard care for obesity produces minimal weight loss and weight regain is common. An innovative behavioral treatment, acceptance-based therapy (ABT), focuses on self-regulation skills and increasing mindfulness and tolerance of negative or uncomfortable emotions and is highly effective for weight loss in adults. Our study team has developed and tested an ABT weight loss intervention for adolescent girls and the objective of this proposal is to randomize adolescent girls with OW/OB to an ABT versus an Enhanced Care (EC) intervention to test the efficacy of an ABT intervention on physiological, behavioral, and psychological factors related to cardiometabolic health.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Staphylococcus aureus infections occur commonly in Veterans, both in outpatients as well as hospitalized patients. The VA healthcare system is one of the largest healthcare systems in the US, with over 5 million people served per year. Among Veterans, S. aureus is the most common cause of skin and soft tissue infections, and these infections are becoming harder to treat due to high level antimicrobial resistance. Our studies will provide insight on mechanisms used by methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) to colonize the skin and transition to systemic infection. Understanding colonization mechanisms could improve treatment options for skin and soft tissue infections.

PHR: Project Narrative In 2023, multiple attribute-specific and intersecting stigmas are critical determinants of poor mental and sexual health of communities at risk for and living with HIV; however, most HIV-related health interventions continue to focus on individual risk behavior. The disconnect between recognizing stigma as a social determinant of health and barrier to HIV interventions and intervention efforts has often been cited as arising from limited capacity of domestic and international investigators to appropriately measure complex stigma processes and develop methodologically sound effectiveness and implementation studies of interventions grounded in theory and lived experience that aim to reduce or mitigate stigma and its harms. In response, we are proposing to develop the Johns Hopkins-Emory-developmental AIDS Research Center (JH-E-dARC) to build capacity for the measurement of stigma and development of interventions focused on responding to stigma as a threat to both mental health and suboptimal individual and population-level HIV outcomes in the US and around the world.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: This work aims to improve the health and functional independence of Veterans with severe motor disabilities caused by neurologic injuries or diseases, such as spinal cord injury (SCI) or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Veterans account for approximately 18% of the 296,000 people affected by SCI nationally. Approximately 17,900 SCI cases occur annually in the U.S, causing tetraplegia in more than half. High tetraplegia profoundly inhibits independence in the most basic of tasks, including personal care. More than 27,000 Veterans with SCI are provided with care through the VAA; however, full recovery is achieved in less than 1% of all cases. This project directly benefits Veterans by addressing the reliability of intracortical brain–machine interfaces (BMIs) (an important RR&D priority area) by improving neuroinflammatory response and developing translational strategies for minimizing risks associated with post-implantation infection, device failure and systemic administration of antibiotics (i.e., toxicity, systemic side effects and emergence of resistant bacteria).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This intervention development research project will strengthen evidence-based strategies to improve mental health and HIV medication adherence for MSM in South Africa. The population focus represents one of the highest priority populations for HIV intervention in sub-Saharan Africa and one that also experiences high risk for mental health problems. The intervention addresses crucial gaps in HIV science and is designed to enhance scalability and implementation in complex service delivery settings in LMIC settings.

PHR: This proposal addresses a significant health problem globally and in the US Veteran community, which is the bone disease induced by diabetes (DM). The American Diabetes Association declared this disease a nationwide epidemic. Within the general population, 1 year after suffering a hip fracture, 25% of patients will die, 30% will suffer a permanent disability, and 40% will be unable to walk independently. Diabetic patients exhibit >30% in- crease in bone fracture risk compared to non-diabetics. Thus, morbidity and mortality due to bone fractures is significantly augmented in DM. Successful completion of the proposed studies will reveal novel genes, pathways, and cells to be therapeutically targeted downstream of the PTH1R signaling pathway to restore skeletal health in the frame of DM.

PHR: American Veterans are disproportionately affected by kidney-damaging agents during deployment operations, and failing health and medical countermeasures add long-term health effects eventually causing acute renal injury. Our studies showed that the kidney has a way of damaging and protecting itself by the interplay of two enzymes, one of which, DNase I, is responsible for the injury, while another, EndoG, provides protection of kidney cells by inactivating DNase I. Here, we propose testing out recently discovered DNase I and EndoG inhibitors to protect against these disturbances in the kidney. This study will likely result in new therapies providing short-term protection of the kidney immediately after injury, and may eventually allow saving human lives, improve the health of Veterans, and decrease the number of disabilities in the Veteran population.

PHR: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) has caused great suffering for Veterans from loss of productivity and quality of life. It has also placed a significant and increasing financial burden on VHA in disability payments. Considering that PTSD is resistant to treatment, identifying susceptibility factors for PTSD that can be altered to increase resilience, has great potential to both decrease PTSD-associated VA costs as well as decrease loss- of-productivity and increase quality of life for many Veterans. There are sex-differences in susceptibility factors for PTSD. With the increase in female Veterans, it is important to investigate these differences so that strategies to build resilience in each sex can be developed. This grant builds upon findings from an animal model, developed by the PI, to investigate sex-differences in susceptibility factors. We will also investigate resilience building treatments in both sexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Lewy Body Dementia (LBD), a neurological disorder, is potentiated by the aggregation of a neuronal protein, α-Synuclein (αS). We have identified a ligand to rescue LBD phenotypes by reducing αS aggregation. We propose to test and optimize the pharmaceutical and efficacy of our ligand to rescue LBD phenotypes in in vivo models.

PHR: Project Narrative Childhood ADHD is one of the most common neurodevelopmental disorders with prevalence of 5-10% across the world, and is characterized by pervasive deficits in cognitive control and motivation. This project seeks to uncover on the latent state dynamics in the cognitive control and reward systems in ADHD and particularly their evolution from resting to cognitively demanding task states. The proposed research will enhance our understanding of ADHD’s brain mechanisms using novel cognitive, neuroscience and computational models and will contribute foundational knowledge that eventually facilitate more effective and precise interventions of the disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Lyme disease (LD), caused by multiple species of the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato, and Relapsing Fever (RF), caused by B. miyamotoi and B. hermsii are the most common tick- borne diseases in the United States. Though acute illness is commonly treated by antibiotics, prolonged disease manifestations costs the U.S. health care system close to $4.8 billion a year. We are developing a pre-exposure prophylaxis to prevent LD and RF in individuals who are at particularly high risk of infection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OF THE FUNDED PARENT AWARD Acetaminophen (APAP) exposures are ubiquitous use during pregnancy and early life during lung development. Alarmingly, clinical data support the hypothesis that the developing lung may be adversely affected by APAP exposure due to the developmental ontogeny of pulmonary CYP2E1 expression. These pre-clinical studies will be the first to interrogate the mechanisms underlying the unique susceptibility of the developing lung to APAP exposure and help determine its safety profile in this understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Artificial hibernation has the promise to impact broad medical domains, including enhancing survival rates during critical health events such as stroke and heart attacks, inhibiting the proliferation of cancer cells, extending the viability of organs for transplantation, promoting longevity, and facilitating long-distance space travel. This application will pioneer an innovative approach for inducing artificial hibernation through ultrasound neuromodulation, with the ultimate aspiration of applying this technology to medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There are more than 700,000 annual acute ischemic stroke (AIS) events in the US which result in nearly 150,000 deaths, making AIS the fifth leading cause of death and the leading cause of neurological disability. Although thrombectomy is the standard of care for those diagnosed with a treatable large vessel occlusion in the anterior circulation, improvements in thrombolysis are needed given that most AIS events are not amenable to thrombectomy. UNandUP (short for “Unmet Needs and Underserved Populations”) has invented a safe and effective nanoparticle-based magnetic thrombolysis platform which can be applied to nearly all AIS victims.

PHR: Project Narrative Low medication adherence when initiating antiretroviral treatment (ART) is a key barrier to HIV virologic suppression, resulting in avoidable cases of drug resistance, death, and viral transmission. Routinized pill-taking can lead to successful long-term ART adherence, and short-term behavioral economics-based supports are a novel way to overcome the limited success of existing routinization interventions. This study proposes to test this combined approach for promoting long-term ART adherence using a Stage III Sequential, Multiple Assignment, Randomized Trial (SMART) design in one of the largest HIV clinics in Uganda to identify the most cost-effective adaptive intervention that if found effective is generalizable to other settings and other chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Based on our extensive preliminary data we now believe we have determined the degradation event that may underlie nuclear pore injury loss that occurs early in the pathogenesis of ALS/FTD. Our preliminary experiments suggest that this novel disease pathway can be pharmacologically manipulated. Thus, candidate ASO therapy could be useful for C9orf72 ALS/FTD patients and therapeutic targeting of nucleoporin and nuclear pore complex degradation and CHMP7 has potential to extend far beyond C9orf72 mediated disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Extreme heat is the leading cause of weather-related deaths in the United States (more than hurricanes and tornadoes combined), and the heat island effect intensifies these health risks, often in low-resource urban areas. Through the Heat Viz project, we can connect human health, environmental justice, and STEM education to prepare students to better address the public health risks of urban heat islands.

PHR: Cellular immunotherapies are revolutionizing cancer treatment but suffer from serious limitations. Drawing inspiration from a surprising discovery we made working on fruit flies, we propose to revolutionize and democratize an emerging cellular immunotherapy called CAR-M. We further propose to generalize the approach to remove any unwanted cell or substance from the body – from cancer to drug resistant microbes to amyloid plaques.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will conduct a cluster-randomized trial to establish the efficacy of an App-based video intervention to integrate U=U (Undetectable equals Untransmittable) messaging into HIV counseling in South Africa. Although treatment-as-prevention is the primary rationale for “test-and-treat” policies, the prevention benefits of antiretroviral therapy have not featured prominently in HIV counseling and public health messaging. The intervention provides accurate, up-to-date information on the science of U=U – including its limitations – alongside the U=U narratives of PLHIV, their partners, and health care workers.

PHR: Project Narrative HIV disproportionately impacts young Black women in the Southern US. A future HIV vaccine could decrease disparities, but successful rollout will require communication that is strategic and tailored. We will use Community Engagement Studios to engage young Black women in developing communication strategies and content for increase uptake of a future HIV vaccine, within the larger family of HIV prevention tools. We will then test these communication strategies in three separate randomized trials to see what types of strategies have the great impact on HIV vaccine and prevention intention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV requires lifelong antiviral treatment because it persists within a population of silently infected cells termed the HIV reservoir. If treatment is permanently stopped, HIV reemerges and escapes from the immune system leading to AIDS. In this proposal, we will test a strategy to limit formation of the HIV reservoir by targeting proliferation of silently infected cells during the first month of infection.

PHR: In previous years the total cost of care for Veterans with psychoses has consumed 16% of the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) Veterans Equitable Resource Allocation (VERA) funds. The current investigation is intended to reveal the importance of brain waves – or oscillations - to abnormal visual perceptual experiences and symptoms of psychosis such as hallucinations and illusions. The value of the work is that oscillatory abnormalities can serve as targets for brain interventions that reduce perceptual dysfunction and psychotic symptomatology. Through state-of-the-art analysis of brain electrical activity in people with schizophrenia, this study will test whether the speed of a dominant brain oscillation (i.e., the alpha rhythm) accounts for difficulties in adapting to visual input and accurately seeing objects in one’s environment. The work includes a manipulation of the rhythm to determine if perception can be improved. Alpha manipulation will be personalized and inform neuromodulatory treatment focused on the speed of a Veteran’s alpha rhythm.

PHR: NARRATIVE Many non-brain disorders accompanied by acute or chronic systemic inflammation result in common behavioral symptoms like extreme fatigue and diminished motivation. The neuro-immune mechanisms and specific brain circuits mediating these convergent symptoms remain unidentified. Here, we will employ high-resolution brain-wide scans along with advanced neuroscience techniques, investigating five mouse models of systemic inflammation, aiming to pinpoint central circuits connecting inflammation to these behavioral symptoms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Testicular germ cell tumor (TGCT) is the most common cancer in men aged 15-45. We have identified genetic changes that predispose to TGCT, and this proposal seeks to identify the mechanisms of these genetic changes by defining their impact on developing human fetal germ cells and gonad. We will use both cell models and study of individuals with atypical gonads to better understand the influence of TGCT-predisposing genes, with the goal that results from this study will provide rationale for future precision cancer prevention and treatment strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies address the important issue of immune suppression and dysfunction of tumor-reactive T cells mediated by human regulatory T cells that is a major barrier for successful anti-tumor immunity and immunotherapy. The proposed research has relevance to public health, because it seeks to dissect a novel suppressive mechanism and then to develop critical strategies that control immune suppression mediated by human regulatory T cells. Thus, the findings are ultimately expected to be applicable to improve the treatments against human cancer and immune-related diseases as well.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorder is a multidimensional neurological disease increasing in prevalence across the United States despite increased awareness and substantial leaps in treatment approaches. Unfortunately, these treatments commonly fail due to strongly encoded drug-associations, often resulting in relapse. The experiments in this Proposal aim to identify previously unknown functional and molecular plasticity involved in drug-seeking behaviors needed to develop targeted pharmacotherapies to reduce and hopefully eliminate relapse episodes and overdoses.

PHR: Project Narrative: Administrative Core The Administrative Core provides oversight and coordination for all components of the Melanoma and Skin Cancer Program (MSCP) SPORE. The Administrative Core provides centralized administrative and fiscal functions that optimize and assure the efficiency of the proposed translational research to improve the understanding and therapy of melanoma and other skin cancers. It assures linkage of the MSCP SPORE with the Regional Melanoma Consortium, the Network Lead Academic Participating Sites and other NCI National Clinical Trials Network efforts of the institution, and the other Melanoma and Skin Cancer SPOREs.

PHR: Project Narrative Suicide claims more than forty thousand lives in the United States each year, making it a leading cause of death, the 2nd leading cause of death for adolescents, and a devastating public health concern. The goal of this project is to test the associations between interoceptive processes and the occurrence of STBs during adolescence, using innovative, rigorous methods such as ecological momentary assessment, hospital-based data collection, and advanced statistical modeling. Results can provide an enhanced understanding of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in adolescents, which can provide crucial insight to improve understanding of suicide in adolescence, as well as novel targets for clinical intervention and suicide prevention.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The PI discovered that the humoral immune response is controlled through novel and specific epigenetic mechanisms linked to histone modifying enzymes, which cause malignant transformation when perturbed through somatic mutations that are present in a majority of patients with B-cell lymphomas. In this proposal he will determine the signals that control histone modifying complexes during the normal immune response and how somatic mutations of histone modifying enzymes reprograms B-cells to undergo malignant transformation by disrupting these signals. Based on functional studies he will identify and test the efficacy of epigenetic- targeted drugs that counteract the effect of these mutations on the epigenome and sensitize lymphomas to other targeted agents and immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mandibular fractures resulting from trauma can cause limited mobility, pain, and diminished quality of life, and these unstable fractures heal through the mobilization and differentiation of progenitor cells. This proposal will study the molecular mechanisms of healing in unstable mandibular fractures. The proposed studies will lead to a better understanding of how this healing occurs and may identify new therapeutic targets to improve patient outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Rural individuals face a disproportionate burden of negative mental health outcomes. Emerging technology in psychiatry uses machine learning and human neuroimaging data to inform clinical decisions such as treatment choices. This study investigates how this machine learning technology itself may drive mental health disparities by performing more poorly in rural populations and means of reducing disparities by creating models that perform equitably within underrepresented populations.

PHR: Given the strong relationship between social adversity (e.g., homelessness, food insecurity) and health, policy makers suggest routine screening and referral (S&R) for unmet social and economic needs in the clinical setting. This call has catalyzed a small but promising evidence base indicating that unmet need S&R can lead to patients’ connection to resources, unmet need reduction, and potential improvements in health. However, this evidence base focuses on unmet needs in urban settings. This means we lack the knowledge needed to adapt unmet need S&R to the unique needs of rural VA facilities and the rural Veterans they serve. We propose to examine unmet needs among rural Veterans, how they manifest, and the infrastructure available to identify and address these needs. With this knowledge and in collaboration with the individuals in the setting where the intervention will ultimately be implemented, the study will develop the specifications for the adapted unmet need S&R intervention for rural Veterans. Future study will implement and evaluate the intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black Americans have higher death rates and worse outcomes than White Americans following open heart surgery. These racial disparities are not well understood; however, disruptions in sleep, circadian rhythms, and blood sugar in the intensive care unit may explain a significant portion of this disparity. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to understand the role of novel connections between an individual’s sleep, circadian rhythm, and blood sugar pattern in the intensive care unit environment following open heart surgery.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposed multi-center research is to compare and contrast the nature of cancer genetic counseling encounters and patient-centered outcomes between Black and White patients in the naturalistic clinical setting. We will conduct an observational study with a convergent mixed methods research design, analyzing video-recorded cancer genetic counseling encounters both qualitatively and quantitatively and linking those data to pre-encounter survey data (to identify provider factors associated with the nature of cancer genetic counseling encounters), post-encounter survey data (to assess the role of cancer genetic counseling encounters in predicting self-reported patient-centered outcomes), and data from medical chart reviews (to assess the role of cancer genetic counseling encounters in predicting genetic test uptake). Findings from this proposed study enables researchers to identify specific aspects of cancer genetic counseling encounters (i.e., patient-counselor communication and clinical recommendations) that are modifiable and are directly associated with patient-centered outcomes.

PHR: The incidence and mortality of uterine cancer are rising dramatically in the U.S., especially among black. We will develop three natural history models of uterine to estimate the harms, benefits and cost-effectiveness of screening, prevention and treatment options for uterine cancer. We will likewise use these models to address areas of public health relevance including racial disparities, the growing obesity epidemic in the U.S., and changing rates of hysterectomy for benign gynecologic disease, all of which will have profound effects on the incidence and mortality of uterine cancer in the coming decades.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory hypersensitivity is a common problem for individuals with Fragile X Syndrome, a leading cause of autism and inherited intellectual disability, but the mechanism that mediates this process is not fully understood. The proposed research will investigate of a previously unstudied neurotransmitter receptor to cortical network dysfunction. Results are expected to provide crucial knowledge of the etiology of dysregulated cortical development in Fragile X Syndrome and potential new therapeutic targets using translationally relevant biomarkers of brain function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1 Melanoma is an aggressive skin cancer for which immunotherapy has been successful in an increased fraction of patients—but there remains a critical need to improve upon this, and to understand why many patients are still non-responsive. LAG3 limits effector T cell function and LAG3 blockade exhibits synergy with anti-PD1 in mouse models of cancer, and thus is a logical therapeutic target to increase anti-tumor immunity in combination with anti-PD1. There are now >10 LAG3-targeting therapeutic clinical trials in the US, and yet we still know very little about how LAG3 blockade, alone or in combination with anti-PD1, impacts the immune response to cancer, and whether biomarkers exist which could predict responsiveness.

PHR: Cirrhosis is a major and rising clinical problem in VA due to the high prevalence of risk factors for cirrhosis such viral hepatitis B and C, alcoholic liver disease, obesity, diabetes and fatty liver disease, which has reached epidemic proportions. There are 73,331 patients with cirrhosis currently in VA care, who have high mortality, morbidity, hospitalization and resource utilization rates. Veterans with cirrhosis frequently require surgery, which carries very high risks, especially in those patients with more advanced cirrhosis and liver dysfunction. The proposed C-SuRC will address a major gap in cirrhosis care by providing accurate preoperative risk assessment for Veterans with cirrhosis. C-SuRC estimates will apply directly to Veterans, since C-SuRC will be developed using data from a representative Veteran population. We will develop web-based and app-based tools to execute C-SuRC, which will be used by clinicians for the preoperative assessment of VA patients with cirrhosis who require surgery.

PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL With an estimated 22,000 new cases and 14,000 deaths each year, cancer of the ovary, fallopian tube or peritoneum (termed “ovarian cancer” in this application) remains the most lethal of the gynecological malignancies. The Mayo Clinic SPORE in Ovarian Cancer provides support for translational research projects that are intended to have a rapid impact for ovarian cancer patients. Specifically, we will develop and test four novel therapeutic approaches designed to i) stimulate the immune system (Project 1), ii) introduce a Next Generation TOP1 inhibitor for ovarian cancer (Project 2), iii) repurpose the FDA-approved kinase inhibitor ceritinib as an ovarian cancer therapeutic (Project 3) and iv) provide a new form of adoptive immune cell therapy (Project 4).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Depression in adolescence is growing public health concern, with symptoms beginning as early as pre- adolescence, and conferring heightened risk for long-term deleterious psychological and cognitive outcomes. The purpose of this K08 proposal is to prepare this applicant for a career in translational pediatric research, by investigating the effects of insufficient sleep and depression on longitudinal sleep-dependent hippocampal memory trajectories across the adolescent transition in typical and depressed youth. The knowledge gained from this proposal will address a critical gap in our fundamental knowledge of the individual trajectories of and longitudinal associations between insufficient sleep, depression, and sleep-dependent hippocampal memory across the adolescent transition, and help to identify key timepoints for sleep-based interventions for mental health and cognition across this neurocognitive sensitive period.

PHR: Project 3: Project Narrative This project evaluates a novel combination immunotherapy approach applicable to a broad range of accessible skin cancers. Specifically, we will target both a potent chemotherapeutic agent to induce immunogenic cell death and an innate immune stimulant specifically to the 3D space of the tumor microenvironment of cutaneous squamous cell carcinomas. These studies represent the first tumor immunotherapy clinical trials utilizing localized spatially and kinetically controlled delivery of a synergistically acting combination therapy.

PHR: Aberrant transcription of protein-encoding genes by RNA polymerase II is a cause of many human diseases, especially cancer. Pol II(G), a metazoan-specific form of Pol II, plays an essential role in embryonic development, while in quiescent differentiated cells, Pol II(G) is dispensable for viability but critical for maintenance of tissue-specialized functions. This proposal will reveal new insights into biological and mechanistic aspects of Pol II(G), and will further assess how modulation of its function impacts transcription in breast and hepatocellular carcinomas, thereby suggesting potential therapeutic avenues.

PHR: In African American (AA) men prostate cancer is characterized by higher aggressiveness, early onset, more extensive metastases, and increased mortality rates compared to those in Caucasian men. Conventional therapies produce a high rate of cure for patients with localized prostate cancer, but there is no effective treatment for intervention in metastatic prostate cancer. Currently-used prognostic indicators (Digital rectal exam, PSA measurement and Gleason score) do not predict metastases risk accurately. These facts underline the urgent, yet unmet, need for identification and characterization of new targets that can help distinguish between aggressive and metastatic prostate cancer from an indolent disease. Our goal is to address this vital knowledge gap by characterizing the role of Prostate Derived Ets Transcription Factor (PDEF) in PCa aggressiveness, thereby reducing the prostate cancer-related health disparity between African American (AA) and Caucasian men. We propose a novel and unique causative link between PDEF and metastases. Our proposal also details mechanistic experiments that may help to patient stratification and use PDEF expression as a means to stratify patients to demethylating agents. Our studies will pave the way for routine clinical use of PDEF as an independent predictor of metastases risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project estimates the causal impact of a child health investment on recipients’ long-run life outcomes, as well as on the health and cognitive development of recipients’ children, exploiting experimental variation to overcome the key methodological challenge of confounding. The research builds on the existing Kenya Life Panel Survey (KLPS) longitudinal dataset, which contains detailed information on individual health, education, social attitudes, and labor market outcomes over an exceptionally long timeframe (1998-2021), and will extend this panel dataset through 2026 for 6,500 adults and over 5,000 of their children. The project will estimate the extent to which the child health intervention (deworming) can improve long-run living standards and help break the intergenerational transmission of poverty, and will also assess the effects of two low-cost parent-child interventions (reading promotion and sleep promotion) on child learning and development.

PHR: ! PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaping—the inhalation of vaporized substances from electronic devices–has increased in adolescents and young adults (AYAs), including vaping of flavors only, nicotine, and cannabis products. This study will provide new essential information about whether low-risk AYAs begin nicotine and cannabis use via vaping, and whether vaping may lead to adverse consequences, including cigarette and cannabis smoking. This study will provide public health officials with data regarding the potential adverse public health impact of AYA vaping and clear targets for intervention to reduce AYA vaping and the health consequences that may follow.

PHR: NARRATIVE—ANIMAL MODELS CORE (CORE D) The Animal Models Core (Core D) will facilitate the translation of novel therapies into the clinic by providing SPORE investigators with ovarian cancer patient-derived xenograft (PDX) models in immunocompromised mice, a syngeneic model in immunocompetent mice, and ex vivo 3D cultures of PDX tumors. PDX tumors were collected at surgery from women with ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer made available through this Core for current and future use in research projects designed to improve the treatment of ovarian cancer. The Animal Models Core collaborates directly with Core B for tumor acquisition and with Core C for genomic and clinical data correlation.

PHR: Project Narrative The Cellular Senescence Network (SenNet) Consortium Organization and Data Coordination Center (CODCC) will engage the rapidly growing community of single-cell genomics mapping consortia including the Human BioMolecular Atlas Program Consortium (HuBMAP), the Human Cell Atlas (HCA) and the Human Tumor Atlas Network (HTAN). In particular, SenNet focuses on discovery, induction, and mapping of specific physiology at the cellular and molecular level, under a variety of normal, experimental and disease conditions. Investigators among the Consortium Organization and Data Coordination Center (CODCC), Tissue Management Centers (TMCs), and Technology Development (TTDs), as well as the broader community of Cellular Senescence (CS) scientists and innovators, will work together to common purpose to achieve a multiyear strategy of human impact.

PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 Treatment options are limited for women whose ovarian cancer has become resistant to platinum drugs and PARP inhibitors. Clinical studies have shown that prolonged schedules of DNA topoisomerase I (TOP1) inhibitors can be effective in some platinum-resistant ovarian cancers. Our preclinical studies have also shown that PARP inhibitors can enhance the antitumor effects of TOP1 inhibitors in vitro and in ovarian cancer patient derived xenograft (PDX) models despite resistance to the antitumor effects of PARP inhibitor alone. These observations, which reflect the fact that PARP inhibition and PARP inhibitor-induced tumor cell killing are related but separable processes, provide the opportunity to use PARP inhibitors as chemosensitizing agents in ovarian cancers that are PARP inhibitor resistant. Accordingly, this project will study the action of a promising 3rd generation ultra- long acting TOP1 inhibitor, PLX038, in combination with the PARP inhibitor rucaparib in preclinical models and in a phase II clinical trial in platinum- and PARP inhibitor-resistant high grade serous ovarian cancer.

PHR: A Rapid HIV RNA Detection without Sample Preparation CrossLife Technologies Inc. Narrative We propose to develop a rapid, sensitive, specific, simple, and cost-effective diagnostic – “TARApen” – by integrating innovations in biomolecular recognition (TARA) and microfluidic design that address the key limitations of current home-test kits. The resulting TARApen test will automate all steps of molecular analysis and amplification for detection of HIV RNAs in blood finger-stick without sample preparation.

PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 3 Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitors have recently been FDA approved as maintenance therapy to extend progression-free survival in ovarian cancer. Here we study the effect of combining PARP inhibitors with an FDA-approved drug (the ALK inhibitor ceritinib) that is not currently used to treat high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC). Based on a novel mechanism of action we have discovered and the synergistic activity of the ceritinib + PARP inhibitor combination, we propose additional preclinical studies to better understand the mechanism by which this combination kills ovarian cancer cells in tissue culture and in ovarian cancer patient- derived xenografts in vivo. In addition, we propose to perform a phase 1b clinical trial of ceritinib in combination with the PARP inhibitor olaparib with an expansion phase in HGSOC to assay toxicity, assess potential activity, and explore biomarkers of response identified in the mechanistic and PDX studies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Does Protecting Service-Connected Disability Income Motivate Return to Work in Veterans with TBI and PTSD?

PHR: Background: Tinnitus and hearing loss are among the most common service-connected disabilities with Veterans being at particular risk for severe hearing loss. Comprehensive hearing health services are available within the VA to qualifying veterans. The delivery of optimal hearing healthcare mandates tailored treatments are offered based on degree of hearing loss and patient preferences. These options are defined in practice guidelines including the VA since 2004. Significance/Impact: Despite the prevalence of hearing loss among Veterans, there are few projects studying the management of those with severe hearing loss. Ensuring appropriate treatments for those most severely affected represents an important access to care issue with implications for patients’ communication, quality of life and overall health. This also facilitates patient communication in health care settings as being able to hear is a cornerstone of participation in shared-decision making. Innovation: The VA is the ideal setting to study management of severe hearing loss as this is a prevalent condition among veterans, interested patients are offered comprehensive treatments for hearing loss and longitudinal audiometric data are available to allow identification of factors associated with receipt of particular treatment strategies. Stakeholder engagement including interviews with affected Veterans and providers are incorporated in the study design. Specific Aims: 1. Define the prevalence, modes of treatment and time to treatment of Veterans with severe  hearing loss using the Audiometric Repository, a national database of audiograms and a  registry of assistive listening devices, hearing aids and cochlear implants within the VA,  between 2005-2017. 2. Identify which factors are associated with different treatment approaches for Veterans with  severe hearing loss using the Audiometric Repository linked to administrative data from the  electronic medical record during years 2005-2017. 3. Identify facilitators and barriers for distinct management of severe hearing loss among hearing  aid users (including referral for cochlear implants) through semi-structured interviews with  current VHA providers (audiologists, otolaryngologists and primary care providers) and  affected Veterans. Methodology: A mixed methods study using a sequential explanatory design will be employed. Data from the Audiometric Repository will be linked to administrative data from the electronic health record to understand management of Veterans with severe hearing loss. Interviews will be conducted with various stakeholders including Veterans and providers to identify barriers and facilitators to particular treatment modalities. Next Steps/Implementation: Results from this pilot will provide new information on barriers and facilitators of management of severe hearing loss. In addition to a planned manuscript describing our findings, we will develop educational materials for providers on CI indications and criteria for referral. We will also develop an educational brochure for Veterans and families to address potential attitudinal/knowledge barriers. These materials will form the basis for a Merit application to study trajectories of hearing loss and to develop and test an implementation approach to achieve best practices in the treatment of severe hearing loss.

PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 4 Novel treatment options for women with recurrent ovarian cancer are desperately needed. The overarching goal of Project 4 is to develop and test genetically engineered natural killer (NK) cells to be more effective at identifying and killing ovarian cancer cells. Project 4 will leverage advanced gene editing techniques to remove an intracellular signaling protein that dampens NK activation (CISH gene) and insert a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) that was developed specifically for NK cells, targeting the prevalent epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) tumor antigen mesothelin (MSLN). Our central hypothesis is that gene editing can be used to overcome signaling inhibition and improve NK targeting, persistence and function, thereby resulting in improved therapeutic outcomes for women with recurrent EOC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall The overall goal of this ARTNet Center is to understand the biological drivers of acquired drug resistance in acute myeloid leukemia – an aggressive form of leukemia. We will employ novel experimental approaches, advanced models, and a large biorepository of primary samples to study causes of resistance that are intrinsic to the AML tumor cells as well as causes of resistance that are driven by the tumor cells interacting with their local environment. This knowledge will be leveraged to identify and prioritize novel drug combination regimens and translate these new therapeutic strategies into the clinics to prevent drug resistance and improve outcomes for patients with AML.

PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT: THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER PROJECT NARRATIVE The NCI-Designated University of New Mexico Comprehensive Cancer Center leads impactful cancer research, cancer care delivery, cancer education and training, and community-based cancer prevention and control efforts across the New Mexico catchment area, in partnership with its Consortium Partner (Lovelace Biomedical/The Lovelace Respiratory Research Institute), Tribal Nations, and community health systems statewide. The Center's overall mission is to reduce the cancer burden and overcome the tremendous cancer health disparities of the New Mexico catchment area and the nation through ground-breaking transdisciplinary research, translation of discoveries to clinical and community interventions, impactful bi-directional community engagement, training of a more diverse cancer workforce, and the delivery of exceptional cancer care.

PHR: Narrative Depression and substance use disorders (SUD) in persons living with HIV (PLWH), when untreated, threaten HIV care continuum outcomes such as engagement in care and treatment adherence. HIV, mental health (MH), and SUD, disproportionately affect rural and Southern states due to proximity to medical care and a lack of mental health and addiction providers. Through enhanced screening (patient-reported outcomes) and linkage to expanded treatment options (telemedicine), this proposal will optimize care of depression and SUD, a critical step towards ending the HIV Epidemic.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PROJECT 4) The overall goal of Project 4 is to understand the relationship between expression and activation of the master regulator transcription factor ONECUT2 (OC2), lineage plasticity, chromosome instability and nuclear shape instability. We have found these to be shared features of both treatment-naïve de novo metastatic prostate cancer (PC) and metastatic castration-resistant PC, suggesting these properties are inherent to one or more subtypes of aggressive PC. We will use model systems, human data and tissues, and a range of molecular and computational approaches to identify new therapeutic approaches to lethal forms of PC. Project Narrative Page 700

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The identification of targetable driver oncogenes, such as EGFR, has been a revolutionary advancement in the treatment of lung cancer, and inhibitors can cause dramatic reductions in tumor bulk markedly improving clinical outcomes for patients. However, these drugs do not completely eradicate tumors leaving residual cells that are not killed by the initial treatment, called drug-tolerant persister cells (DTPCs) which eventually resume growth and metastatic spread. To tackle this, we aim to characterize at the single cell level a large and valuable collection of EGFR mutant DPTCs and drug resistant preclinical models that were established in order to investigate new therapeutic approaches for the early targeting of DTPCs to prevent resistant disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Current antibacterial treatment strategies for peri-implantitis lack efficacy in resolving the destructive inflammation that causes loss of jawbone, which necessitates the comprehensive study of microbial biofilm pathogenicity around implants. This study aims to understand the role of V. parvula in the polymicrobial shift that takes place in the pathogenesis of Titanium-mediated peri-implantitis by focusing upon its ability to cross- protect pathogenic bacteria from oxidative environmental stress.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin, the protein-DNA complex responsible for genome organization, is tightly regulated to control gene expression, and aberrant chromatin regulation has been implicated in a wide variety of cancers and other diseases. The F99 portion of this proposal seeks to investigate mechanisms by which the oncovirus Hepatitis B Virus evades host regulatory pathways to maintain a stable minichromosome and promote oncogenesis within chronically infected cells. The K00 phase of this proposal shifts from focusing on HBV as a case-study of chromatin regulation to structurally and functionally interrogating healthy and oncogenic mutants of the CHD class of chromatin remodeling enzymes, which have diverse roles in modulating chromatin architecture.

PHR: Overall Program Narrative This Program Project will develop novel statistical methods for integrating multiple data types to address the etiology and prognosis of cancer through a collaboration across four closely related projects, drawing upon the resources of three shared facility cores and coordinated by an administrative core. This goal will be achieved by a combination of methodological developments, simulation studies closely keyed to real data projects, user-friendly software packages that implement new methods, and applications to several studies of cancer.

PHR: Project 1: Narrative Associated with high-dimensional omic features there is a rich set of functional and regulatory  annotations, pathway information, and disease-specific knowledge from previous studies that is  routinely used to interpret analyses of omic data. In this project, we propose to develop integrative  high-dimensional regression methods capable of incorporating this array of external information  a priori, to improve prediction performance, selection of predictive and associated features, and  to gain insight into potential biological mechanisms.

PHR: Project 1: Integration of Omic Data to Estimate Mediation or Latent Structures  Project Narrative This project focuses on the development of statistical approaches for the integration of multiple omics data that  are suspected, a priori, to act on a disease or trait outcome via mediation or a latent structured model. The  approaches span the analysis of studies with multiple omic measures on the same individuals to summary  statistics from omic data measured from multiple studies. These methods will have a direct impact on applied  investigations by facilitating a better understanding of potential biological mechanisms driving underlying  cancer etiology via identifying novel factors, estimating connections between those factors, and identifying  subgroups of individuals with potentially different associated mechanisms.

PHR: Narrative The UC San Diego Faculty Institutional Recruitment for Sustainable Transformation (FIRST) Program seeks to employ a faculty cohort model to transform cultures of inclusive excellence and sustain our commitment to diversity and inclusion in biomedical research. We will create and foster an institutional environment of faculty hiring, sponsorship, continual mentoring, and support for professional development to cultivate an academic culture of inclusive excellence. We will develop and implement an evaluation plan to demonstrate how cluster hires and implementation of structured system-wide evidence-based faculty development programs enhance underrepresented faculty academic advancement and success, lead to institutional inclusive excellence, increase diversity and improve institutional climate for all faculty.

PHR: Project 2: Narrative  The availability of high-volume ‘omic’ data, including gene expression, metabolome, methylation, and  microbiome, provides new opportunities to identify gene-environment (G×E) and omic × E interactions.  This project will develop statistical methods to leverage omic data to improve power for identifying  novel interactions as well as to inform the biological mechanism by which genes and exposures affect  cancer outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop a new, promising, and clinically relavant class of nanotherapeutics – spherical nucleic acids (SNAs) – as immunostimulatory agents for treating advanced melanoma, a disease where traditional cancer treatments including chemotherapy and radiation are largely ineffective, thereby significantly and positively impacting human health. SNAs offer an innovative approach to elucidate nanoscale structure-activity relationships, and deliver multiple immunostimulatory cues for generating enhanced antitumor responses. Broadly, this work will inform the rational design of new classes of cancer vaccines, resulting in significant advances in immunotherapy development for various forms of cancers.

PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the role that genes play in life is a key issue in biomedical sciences, yet the overwhelming majority of sequences in public databases remain uncharacterized. Functional annotation is important for a variety of downstream analyses of genetic data, yet experimental characterization of function remains costly and slow. This project therefore proposes three Aims focused on improving our understanding of functional genomics, thereby allowing better translation of data to knowledge impacting human health.

PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE Cellular immunotherapy has enormous potential to improve the therapy of lymphoma. The SPORE research plan outlined in this renewal application seeks to develop more effective cellular immunotherapies by increasing their antitumor activity against lymphomas in children and adults, reducing treatment-related complications, and simplying therapies to use banked allogeneic products that are immediately available. Results of these studies will lay the foundation for future comparative trials and licensing investigations.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE The three projects of this P01 focus on allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation as a potentially curative therapy for many malignant diseases whose applicability has been impeded by the development of its most serious complication, GI GVHD. Projects 1 and 2 focus on the role of mitochondrial damage in intestinal stem cells and the role of the enzyme RIP1 that causes their death. Project 3 conducts two risk adapted clinical trials that determine treatment based on GI damage as measured by serum biomarkers.
